West Ham made seven changes to their lineup following recent losses to Manchester United and Southampton. Cheltenham's exit from the competition ended League Two's representation in the EFL Cup.

A hospital radiographer, Aidan McNicholl, died in a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion. Andreas Werner, who failed to see McNicholl on his motorbike, was found guilty of causing death by careless driving. He was fined £1,000 and banned from driving in the UK for two years.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old from Southall, west London, is facing life imprisonment for his role in the Syrian conflict. He left the UK last January, calling himself Abu Daigham al-Britani, and joined the group Rayat al Tawheed, affiliated with Islamic State. Khawaja was involved in propaganda efforts, including videos and pictures of his activities. He was considered so dangerous that he was held in a special unit for high-risk terrorism suspects at London's maximum security Belmarsh prison. Khawaja has admitted four offences, and his cousin Tahir Bhatti has pleaded guilty to assisting an offender.

Wrexham's 22-year-old forward, Jackson, scored four goals in 36 appearances last season. He is Barnsley's third signing for the upcoming season, ahead of their League One play-off final at Wembley. Jackson turned down a contract offer from Wrexham and will fit in well with Barnsley's playing style due to his pace and ability to take on defenders.

A container of 'Vanish' bottles is believed to have gone overboard from a ship during stormy weather near Land's End in May. The National Trust is clearing the bottles away from Poldhu Cove and other nearby coves as they pose a risk to wildlife, with some bottles having leaked detergent. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency stated there is no evidence that the bottles washed up on the Cornish coast are from the lost container, but the National Trust and Cornwall Council are monitoring the situation and advising the public to avoid the bottles.

A crash occurred on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness at about 14:00. Several people received minor injuries, and the road was closed with diversions put in place via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road. Police Scotland stated that inquiries into the incident were ongoing.

Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back, made 14 appearances last season, helping Wanderers secure promotion to the Championship. He joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014 and has made 83 appearances in all competitions. Dervite has signed a new contract with Bolton, following the footsteps of David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan.

The Lib Dems and Labour have previously collaborated to defeat government bills on various issues, including Brexit. However, their cooperation ended when MPs rejected their amendments, leading to accusations from the Lib Dems that Labour was giving in to the government's plans. Labour, in turn, accused the Lib Dems of creating false hope and grandstanding. Despite this, Baroness Ludford expressed optimism about future collaboration, while a Labour source predicted ongoing tensions.

Barcelona paid £48.6m for Neymar, with his parents receiving £34m of the fee. The total cost of the player, including signing-on fee, wages, agents fees, and this latest tax payment, is £106.8m. Last month, Sandro Rosell resigned as Barcelona president following accusations he misappropriated money. A judge in Spain ruled there was sufficient evidence against Barcelona to continue investigations into the transfer. The club denies any wrongdoing and has made a complimentary tax declaration of 13,550,830.56 euros.

Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old delivery driver from Nottingham, was killed in a motorway crash caused by Albert Kenneth Newman, who was driving the wrong way. Luciw's family believes that older drivers should undergo regular driving tests, while Age UK argues that it is crucial for older people to be able to drive for as long as possible. Currently, drivers over 70 in the UK must fill out a self-assessment form every three years to renew their licenses, which does not include a medical or driving test. The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) has stated that there are no plans to restrict licensing based on age, as evidence does not show that older drivers are more likely to cause serious accidents than other drivers. The DVLA requires all drivers over 70 to renew their licenses every three years and to report any medical conditions that may affect their driving. If a driver does not meet the appropriate medical standard, their license is immediately revoked.

The Scottish government commissioned an independent review of transvaginal mesh implants, which concluded that the procedures should not be offered routinely to women with pelvic organ prolapse. The report recommended offering patients a range of treatments and ensuring they have the information to make informed choices. However, two patients on the original review group quit in protest, claiming the report was watered down. An independent expert, Alison Britton, will now examine the final report and the process by which it reached its conclusions. Despite calls for a ban, the health secretary stated that the government does not have the power to ban the procedures, as that lies with the Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency. The chairwoman of the independent review, Tracey Gillies, apologized for failing to unite all panel members around the controversial final report. Over 20,000 women in Scotland have had mesh or tape implants over the past 20 years, with some suffering painful and debilitating complications. More than 400 women are currently taking legal action against Scottish health boards and manufacturers as a result of mesh implant surgery.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old Scottish athlete, broke a 25-year-old record set by Eilish McColgan by 14 seconds at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow, with a time of 14 minutes and 49.12 seconds. McColgan raised concerns about whether Muir's race met all the criteria for record-breaking attempts, as she was the only competitor in the race. However, British Athletics confirmed that Muir's time would be classified as official. McColgan praised Muir's performance and believes she has the potential to run even faster and win world medals.

Jung won the event aboard Sam, a late replacement for Fischertakinou, who was unable to compete due to an infection. France's Astier Nicolas won silver, and American Phillip Dutton won bronze. Great Britain's William Fox-Pitt finished 12th, despite a faultless performance in the final show-jumping phase. Fox-Pitt, who was competing just 10 months after being placed in an induced coma following a fall, led after the dressage phase but dropped to 21st after incurring several time penalties in the cross-country phase. Ireland's Jonty Evans finished ninth on Cooley Rorkes Drift.

The match between Murray and Fognini lasted 2 hours and 39 minutes, with Murray winning 6-2 4-6 6-1 7-5. Murray will play Frenchman Benoit Paire in the fourth round on Monday. Murray expressed relief at avoiding a long, drawn-out contest, as he was penalized a point for a visible obscenity following a gesture, and Murray complained to the umpire that the Italian was taking too long between points.

Joe's Bar in Dungiven was closed for three months after a sudden death occurred there on 6 October 2014. The bar was found to be serving alcohol as late as 04:49 BST, despite licensing laws. The license holder, Colleen O'Neill, and her partner, James Thomas, were charged with allowing the consumption of liquor outside licensing hours. The judge expressed concern over the appalling record of the bar and the lack of proper management. Both O'Neill and Thomas were fined, with O'Neill fined £3,000 and Thomas fined £1,000.

Mike Nesbitt, leader of the Ulster Unionist Party, launched the party's manifesto with the statement, "Domination doesn't work, partnership does." The party aims to make the election a referendum on the Renewable Heat Incentive debacle. Nesbitt's comments have shifted the focus onto the party itself. He denied any regrets or mistakes and emphasized the importance of the post-election scenario, indicating a preference for coalition with the SDLP over Sinn FÃ©in. The manifesto, titled 'Real Partnership,' addresses various issues, including tackling waiting lists, increasing PSNI numbers, and addressing the impact of Brexit. Nesbitt also addressed the controversy surrounding his remarks about transferring votes to the SDLP, expressing confidence in his position and the party's strategy.

Justice Minister Claire Sugden confirmed that a motion will be presented to the assembly to approve automatic pardons for men convicted of now-abolished sexual offences, similar to plans announced for England and Wales last month. The motion will allow for pardons both posthumously and for living individuals, aligning Northern Ireland with the provisions of what is being referred to as 'Turing's Law'. The minister has secured executive agreement for the assembly to pass a legislative consent motion to pardon convictions related to abolished sexual offences, with arrangements to be implemented as soon as possible to ensure equal treatment for gay and bisexual men in Northern Ireland as in England and Wales.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old Scottish athlete, finished second in a race with a time of 4:19.12, breaking the previous Scottish record of 4:22.60 set by Yvonne Murray in 1994. Muir, who also holds the Scottish 1500m record, is now aiming to secure a spot on the Great Britain team for the Rio Olympics. She fits her training around her veterinary studies and is expecting to run well this season.
The passage provides information about Scotland's 26 "most excellent" beaches for water quality, featuring some of the author's photographs.

The Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC stated that suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi had no personal motive to kill, suggesting that the Russian state was the sponsor of the plot and had reasons to wish harm or death to Mr Litvinenko. UK officials believe the suspects poisoned Mr Litvinenko in London in 2006, leading to his death from a fatal dose of radioactive substance polonium-210. Mr Horwell emphasized that the evidence suggested Russian state involvement in the murder, but not necessarily involving President Vladimir Putin. The risk to the general public from polonium radiation remains unknown, and attempts to extradite the suspects have failed.

Steve Smith, 26, has been appointed as the captain of the Australian cricket team in both one-day and Twenty20 formats, following the retirement of Michael Clarke, 34, after the Ashes series. David Warner, 28, has been named as Smith's vice-captain. Despite disciplinary issues in the past, Warner's maturity and development as a senior figure in the team led to his appointment. Smith had previously captained the side in three Tests against India last summer during Clarke's recovery from injuries. The appointments come after Clarke's decision to retire following a heavy defeat by England at Trent Bridge, which gave the hosts a 3-1 lead in the Ashes series.

Mr. Farron, who was elected leader of the Liberal Democrats, refused to answer whether he believed homosexual sex was a sin. He stated that he was passionate about LGBT rights and that defending equal marriage would be a top priority. He also mentioned wanting to extend marital rights to transgender people. When asked why he voted against the Equality Bill in 2007, he said he supported equality and LGBT rights and that the bill was voted against due to concerns about individual liberties. He emphasized his support for equal access to law for all people regardless of their sexuality.

French-based Sanofi closed its drug manufacturing site in Fawdon in 2015, resulting in the loss of 450 jobs. Now, Accord Healthcare is set to use the plant for pharmaceutical production, with the hope that many of the jobs will be filled by ex-Sanofi staff. The firm is confident that the investment will have an "extremely positive" impact on the area. Newcastle City Council leader Councillor Nick Forbes stated that the announcement is fantastic news for Newcastle and the North East, as it strengthens the region's reputation as a home for the science and healthcare sector. Accord Healthcare, a global player in the pharmaceutical industry, develops, manufactures, and distributes over 130 pharmaceutical products to about 60 countries worldwide.

Richard Ellis, Ciaran Monaghan, and Ewan Sutherland are leaving the council. Ellis is the former interim director of corporate governance and has been acting as deputy chief executive for several months. Monaghan is head of the chief executive's office, and Sutherland is head of human resources and customer services. The departures are under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. Stephen Flynn, the leader of the opposition SNP group, said the departures were indicative of the council's inability to hold on to senior staff and expected further departures in the coming months. Council chief executive Angela Scott thanked the trio for their "dedication and professionalism".

English rider Ian Martin crashed at this year's TT, and the Fireblade bike has been plagued by mechanical problems. Martin initially announced his retirement from road racing but later clarified that he would not be racing on Hondas for the remainder of the year. He did not race at the North West 200 due to his team-mate's crash, and he will not compete in the Ulster Grand Prix next month. Martin described the TT as a disaster and felt like a test rider rather than a competitor. He expressed a desire to race classics and oddball stuff in the future.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of 28 governor posts in the recent elections, marking the Peoples Democratic Party's (PDP) most significant defeat since military rule ended in 1999. APC leader Muhammadu Buhari will be inaugurated on 29 May after defeating President Goodluck Jonathan. The PDP lost in key northern states like Katsina and Kaduna, as well as in Adamawa, one of three states affected by Boko Haram's insurgency. However, the PDP retained control of Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub. The APC failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, which could pose a concern for President-elect Buhari as militant groups could disrupt oil production. The elections were more peaceful than in previous years, raising hopes for Nigeria's democracy. Analysis suggests that the PDP will need to undergo introspection and rebuild under new leadership after 16 years in power.

Mighty, a US-based environmental lobby group, has accused the agricultural commodities trader Olam and its main stakeholder, Singapore state-owned investment company Temasek, of contributing to haze in Southeast Asia through unsustainable palm oil trading practices. Olam sources 99% of its palm oil from third-party suppliers and claims to have a strict no-burn policy. However, Mighty alleges that Olam's secretive market for palm oil suppliers has allowed unsustainable practices to continue. Olam has denied the allegations, stating that it is committed to sustainable practices and will remove suppliers who do not comply. Temasek has also denied the allegations, stating that it does not direct the business operations of its portfolio companies. The palm oil industry has a troubled track record, with accusations of unfair labor practices, deforestation, and burning of plantations. Mighty has also raised concerns about Olam's operations in Gabon, where it alleges that the company is bulldozing rainforests to establish monoculture palm oil plantations.
A restaurant began serving puppy platters after a new law allowed dogs to eat at restaurants, as long as they were outdoors.

Fernando Forestieri is doubtful due to a knee injury, having only played as a substitute in the last two games. Derby County's David Nugent may return from a groin injury after missing the Huddersfield draw. Jacob Butterfield is aiming for a recall following his late equalizer against Huddersfield.

Pakistan's telecoms regulator lifted the ban on YouTube after Google launched a Pakistan-specific version of the platform. The Pakistan Telecommunication Authority confirmed that all internet service providers had been directed to open access to YouTube. The Pakistan Telecommunication Company Ltd and the ministry of information technology also confirmed the lifting of the ban. However, YouTube denied claims that authorities could filter content, stating that government requests for content removal would not automatically be granted. The lifting of the ban follows the Supreme Court's imposition of the ban in 2012 after the US-made film Innocence of Muslims was uploaded, sparking widespread protests in the Muslim world.

Domenico Scala, head of Fifa's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, is Swiss-Italian, as is one of the five presidential candidates, Gianni Infantino. Scala excused himself from the 2015 elections due to sharing nationality with a candidate, Swiss Sepp Blatter. Musa Bility, LFA boss, says he will go to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw by Thursday. Scala also stepped aside in the 2015 elections between Blatter and Prince Ali of Jordan for the same reason. However, Andreas Bantel, a spokesman for Scala, says there is no conflict of interest as there is no such provision in the regulations. Bility wrote a letter to Scala on Monday, stating that any member of the Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee with a conflict of interest must be replaced. Bility hopes to participate in the elections himself but was denied by the Electoral Committee in November after failing an eligibility check. The election, which will take place in Fifa's headquarters in Zurich, will be voted on by Fifa's 209 members.

Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were killed in a flashover explosion at Harford Attachments on Monday, 09:00 BST. The men were believed to have been working in a paint-spraying area, and their bodies were removed from the site on Tuesday afternoon. A forensic search was conducted at the company, which manufactures buckets for diggers. Significant progress has been made with forensic inquiries and obtaining witness statements, with evidence suggesting a flashover explosion caused by a build-up of toxic fumes and some form of ignition. The Health and Safety Executive will be gathering evidence.

Tunisia faced expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations until they apologized to Caf for complaints lodged during the 2015 Nations Cup. Morocco was only able to enter the 2017 qualifying draw after the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned a ban on their participation. Both nations are now preparing for a positive future in the competition. Tunisia will face Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti in Group A, while Morocco will face Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome in Group F. Tunisia's participation seemed in doubt until a meeting with Caf president Issa Hayatou led to a resolution.

Chelsea won the game 3-1 against City, which resulted in the dismissal of City's Aguero and Fernandinho. Chelsea's Fabregas will not face further action. City's manager apologized for the incident. Aguero received a four-match ban for violent conduct, his second this season. Fernandinho received a three-match ban. Both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge.

England won the match against Pakistan by a day to spare at Old Trafford, leveling the series. England's Joe Root was named man of the match after scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 off 48 balls in the second. Root also took four catches in Pakistan's first-innings 198 and claimed a wicket in his only over as Pakistan were bowled out for 234 on Monday. Pakistan's captain Misbah-ul-Haq expressed disappointment, stating that the team was short of confidence and shot selection really cost them.

Warren Gatland, head coach of the British and Irish Lions, has appointed Rob Howley as part of his backroom team for the New Zealand tour. Forwards coach McBryde will assume head coach responsibilities for the third time, leading Wales on tours in 2009 and 2013. McBryde expressed his honor and excitement for the opportunity. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) will appoint assistant coaches for the summer tour, with discussions underway to confirm the full management team next week. Union chairman Gareth Davies, also on the Lions' selection panel, believes the involvement of Welsh coaches will benefit the national team and provide valuable development opportunities.

A motorcyclist from the local area was killed in a collision with a tractor on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa, at approximately 14:15 BST. The tractor driver was unharmed. The police have not released any further details about the motorcyclist and are appealing for witnesses to come forward. The B1191 was closed in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction in Woodhall Spa and the A158 Jubilee Way junction in Horncastle.

President Ivanov cancelled an investigation into abuse of power claims, citing a desire to end the turmoil ahead of early elections. His decision was condemned by the opposition and EU officials, who deemed it illegal and detrimental to Macedonia's EU membership ambitions. The crisis began with covert recordings revealing alleged government corruption and misconduct, which the president denies.

Curtis and Paul Williams will manage the upcoming match against Bournemouth following Bob Bradley's dismissal. The club aims to appoint a new manager promptly, with Paul Clement being their top choice. Curtis, who has been with the club since their rise from near bankruptcy, believes that the team has lost its identity since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014. Curtis is confident that the current squad is capable of avoiding relegation and emphasizes the importance of the club's history and current status to new players.

Dagenham & Redbridge, managed by John Still, needed a victory to keep their slim survival hopes alive in League One. Despite goals from Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona, they lost 3-2 to Leyton Orient, with Armand Gnanduillet scoring the winner. This loss relegated Dagenham, who had reached the Football League for the first time in 2007 but now return to the National League. Dagenham has struggled this season, with the worst goal difference in League Two and conceding 20 more goals than last season. John Still, who returned for his third spell as manager in December, is committed to helping the Daggers gain promotion from the National League next season.

Steven Gerrard, a former Liverpool captain and England skipper, is set to return to his former club as a youth coach in February. This marks his first job since retiring as a player. Gerrard expressed his desire to become a manager in the future, and Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp described his appointment as "wonderful news." Gerrard, who retired in November after a 19-year career, is working towards his Uefa A coaching licence, which is required to manage in the Premier League.
Morton took the lead through McManus and Forbes, but Alloa pulled one back before half-time. McManus and Johnstone scored in the second half to secure a comfortable win for Morton.

Ofsted has found evidence of children being taught in squalid conditions in three illegal schools in Birmingham, which have now closed. The owners of these schools are being investigated for running an illegal school, which could result in a jail term of up to 51 weeks. Ministers are consulting on plans to regulate places teaching for more than 6 to 8 hours a week. Ofsted and ministers are concerned that some places are taking advantage of the legal right to home educate to operate illegal schools. The government has provided funding for a team of six inspectors to investigate illegal schools. The education secretary has now said she intends to go further and has asked Ofsted to prepare cases for prosecution against unregistered schools.

Lilliard Gin is produced at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, ahead of proposals to open the region's first whisky distillery since 1837. Lead distiller Kate Macinnes stated that the potential to make the Scottish Borders a "region of distilling excellence" was "really exciting". The gin production is on a completely different scale to the other distilleries in development, with one of the smallest production stills in the UK. The entire operation fits into a cowshed, but if people like their gin, that's all that matters. The gin takes its name from a legendary Borders figure, Lilliard, who was the heroine of the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545, fought just north of the distillery.

Harry Whitlam died after being hit by a tractor driven by Gary Green, who was over twice the legal driving limit for alcohol. Green was jailed for 16 months and two weeks for failing to ensure the safety of others, as the incident occurred on private land. The Health and Safety Executive found that Green's behavior was reckless, and the incident had a profound impact on Whitlam's family.

Luis Suarez, a Uruguayan striker, was suspended from all football-related activities for biting an Italian player during the 2014 World Cup. His lawyers appealed the ban, and the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) ruled that the ban was too severe. Suarez is now allowed to train and play in friendly matches but cannot participate in organized games. He will still have to serve the remaining eight games of his ban in competitive international games. Suarez moved to Barcelona last month for £75m and can now attend matches and take part in promotional activities. His competitive Barcelona debut is likely to be at Real Madrid on 26 October in El Clasico.

Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won the race, beating Vytautas Kirkliauskas and his wife Neringa Kirliauskiene of Lithuania. The race involved a 380-metre course with hurdles, a steep slope, and water pistols. Competitors came in various combinations, including men carrying men and a woman carrying a woman. The winners will now compete in the World Championships in Finland in July.

The paper system for car tax discs will be replaced with an electronic system in October 2014, allowing people to pay by monthly direct debit. The change may lead to a reduction in the amount of refunds received and the withdrawal of the tax disc, which may result in changes to job roles and the need to train on new processes. Any reductions in the number of people needed for these activities will be managed through redeployment to other growth areas of the business.

Hungary's right-wing Fidesz government, led by Prime Minister Viktor Orban, is under pressure from European institutions to withdraw three laws, two of which have already been passed. The EU objects to Hungary's tight controls on asylum seekers and NGOs, as well as a higher education law that could lead to the closure of the prestigious Central European University, founded by philanthropist George Soros. Thousands of Hungarians have protested against the laws in recent months. Hungary's minister of foreign affairs and trade, Peter Szijjarto, stated that the EU should not interfere with "domestic issues" and that Poland would veto any move to strip Hungary of its EU voting rights.

The film, which will be released in US cinemas on 17 March 2017, is a live-action adaptation of the 1991 animated version of the film. Emma Watson will play Belle, Dan Stevens will play the Beast, and Luke Evans will play Gaston. Josh Gad will play LeFou, Gaston's sidekick. Kevin Kline will play Maurice, Belle's father. Bill Condon will direct the film, which begins filming in May at Shepperton Studios.

Adrian Gill, a renowned journalist and columnist for the Sunday Times, passed away after a battle with cancer. Known for his wit, intelligence, and fearless writing, Gill was described as a giant among journalists and the heart and soul of the paper. Despite his illness, Gill remained stoical and expressed that he did not feel cheated by life. His final column, about coming to terms with his diagnosis, will be featured in tomorrow's Sunday Times. Gill's writing often caused controversy, including describing the Welsh as "dark, ugly little trolls" and shooting a baboon in Tanzania. He was engaged to his partner of 23 years, Nicola Formby, with whom he had two children.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, the lead singer of the band Khar Sarnai, was attacked in Ulan Bator, allegedly by a Russian diplomat. He was hit over the head with a bottle and repeatedly kicked in the face, resulting in a coma and serious brain injury. The Russian embassy called local press reports distorted but is investigating the incident. The swastika, a traditional symbol in Mongolia, was embroidered on Sukhbaatar's red deel, which he wore during the performance. The suspect has not been arrested due to his diplomatic status, but an investigation is ongoing.

On Monday, campaigners from the action group Plane Stupid staged a demonstration on the northern runway of an airport at 03:30 BST to oppose the airport's expansion plans. The individuals involved have been charged with aggravated trespass and entering a security-restricted area of an aerodrome, and they are scheduled to appear in court on 19 August. In response to the protest, the Metropolitan Police stated that security at the airport would be reviewed.

Glamorgan's Nick Selman scored a century, his second in first-class cricket, while Gloucestershire struggled against Glamorgan's bowlers. Selman expressed relief at scoring runs after a series of low scores, while Gloucestershire's Matt Taylor was pleased with his team's bowling performance.

Craig Hughes, 33, of Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police in August after chatting online with the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee. He admitted to two charges at Mold Crown Court on Friday and will be sentenced next week. Hughes had a previous conviction for possessing a firearm in 2009. He made threats to shoot police officers while drunk and late at night. The threats were made on two occasions, and Hughes had not intended to kill himself or carry out any threat to kill police officers. The threats were made while Hughes was on bail, awaiting trial for firearms offences, of which he was subsequently cleared. The Hope Line centre offers confidential support and counselling to people experiencing difficulty.

Yorkshire posted a score of 255-7, with Davies and Ben Foakes sharing a 130-run stand. Yorkshire's run-chase was undermined by a three-wicket burst from Stuart Meaker. Tim Bresnan made 68 but was the last to go as they were all out for 236. Surrey's Davies and Foakes were quite magnificent, with their partnership blowing the game wide open.

A 56ft (17.1m) converted trawler was 6 miles (10 km) west of South Stack when it radioed coastguards at 07:00 BST. The boat's pump was unable to cope with the incoming water. The RNLI lifeboat crew placed a pump and towed the vessel to Holyhead.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old middle-distance runner, will miss the 2024 Commonwealth Games in Australia due to her veterinary medicine exams scheduled for May. Despite this, she expresses optimism about her future in running, mentioning the potential for at least two to three more Olympic Games. Muir reflects on her recent achievements at the World Athletics Championships, where she set a new outdoor personal best in the 5,000m race. She also hints at her intention to participate in the World Indoor Championships in March, pending the completion of her final year of studies.

The East Ayrshire Council plans to build a £45m facility in Kilmarnock, which will include primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare center. The council intends to name the campus after the renowned writer William McIlvanney, who was born and educated in Kilmarnock. McIlvanney began his career as an English teacher before becoming a full-time writer in 1975. He gained recognition with his first novel, Remedy Is None, and is known for his contributions to Tartan Noir, the Laidlaw trilogy, and other works set in Glasgow. The council leader, Douglas Reid, expressed his delight in preserving McIlvanney's name in Kilmarnock, highlighting the writer's passion for providing good education for young people.

An area near the swimming pool in Gourock was evacuated for most of the morning and early afternoon due to the discovery of a British sea mine from the 1940s or 1950s. Residents were advised to open windows, stay indoors near walls, and avoid going outside. An exclusion zone was established on the river and at sea while experts made the mine safe. The evacuation affected three streets, with wider safety advice issued to residents within 500m of the device. Ferry services were disrupted, and small boat owners were told not to sail during the operation. The evacuation was a precautionary measure, as there was no immediate danger to the community of Gourock.

Team GB has had its funding cut by more than £4m to £25.98m. Badminton England chief executive Adrian Christy said he was "staggered" by the "incomprehensible" decision to remove the sport's funding. A total of £345m will be invested in 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports - £2m less than the record £347m allocated for the Rio Games. As a result, UK Sport has set Team GB a target of winning 51-85 Olympic medals, and 115-162 Paralympic medals in Tokyo. Badminton, which was set a target of winning a medal in Rio, is the only sport that earned a podium place in the summer to have its funding removed.

Three Victorian hotels in Bournemouth, Bay View Court, The Cottonwood, and the Ocean View, will be demolished to make way for a six-storey, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks. The development, which will include a 90-room hotel and 122 assisted-living apartments in nine-storey and seven-storey buildings, is supported by the council for its potential to boost tourism and improve living conditions for older residents. However, English Heritage strongly objected to the scale of the development, stating it would cause "severe harm" to the designated conservation area. Despite this, the council voted seven to three in favor of the plans, with supporters arguing that the benefits outweigh the loss of the historic buildings and trees.

Pte Matthew Boyd, a 20-year-old soldier from the Royal Gibraltar Regiment, was attacked and killed by Jake Vallely in Brecon. Vallely was convicted of manslaughter, while his friend Aaeron Evans was cleared of any involvement. The incident occurred outside a bar called The Cellar, where Vallely had been on a seven-hour drinking binge and had boasted about being the "hardest man in Brecon." CCTV footage showed Vallely punching and beating Pte Boyd until he was unconscious and then dragging his body away. The jury cleared Evans of manslaughter, as he had left the scene before the attack began. Pte Boyd's family described him as a loving, caring, and loyal person who had a promising career ahead of him. They also expressed their gratitude for the support they received from the community in Brecon.

Andrew Travers left the Barnet council by mutual agreement after an error led to voters being turned away from all 155 polling stations in the borough. An independent investigation has been launched, and the council has apologized for the problems, offering emergency proxy votes to those affected. Mr. Travers had made a valuable contribution to the council during his three and a half years as chief executive, according to a council spokesperson. Deputy chief executive John Hooton will take over temporarily while longer-term arrangements are put in place. The council's review will conclude by the end of May, and the findings will be presented publicly to the General Functions Committee.

Gateshead beat Wrexham 2-1 in a match where both teams had their moments. Gateshead took the lead through a fine free-kick by Josh Gillies, but Wrexham equalized before half-time with a fine set-piece by Sean Newton. Ryan Bowman scored the winner for Gateshead with a header from a cross by Craig Baxter. Wrexham had chances to equalize, with Connor Jennings missing a header and Adam Smith having a shot saved. Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby praised his team's second-half performance, while Wrexham manager Gary Mills expressed disappointment with his team's second-half display.
The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 ranks Norway as the best country for those over 60, while Afghanistan and Mozambique rank the worst.

The OneWeb project, a collaboration between Airbus and OneWeb, aims to establish a large constellation of at least 600 spacecraft, potentially growing to over 2,000, to provide global broadband coverage, with a focus on connecting every school. This project necessitates a significant shift in satellite manufacturing towards high-volume, low-cost production, similar to automotive and aviation industries. Airbus has introduced new assembly lines in Toulouse, France, and plans additional lines in Florida, featuring trolley robots for automated satellite production. The first 10 satellites are scheduled for launch in April of the following year, with subsequent launches increasing the constellation size to over 800 by mid-decade. The project faces competition from other companies like SpaceX and Boeing, all vying for regulatory approval and financing. OneWeb has raised $1.7bn in equity and is in talks for further funding. The project emphasizes debris mitigation, committing to de-orbit satellites within two years, aligning with global efforts to reduce space debris.

Mr Swinney, the Scottish government, argues that the UK government's spending review has placed unprecedented pressure on public expenditure in Scotland. Despite the UK government's claim that Scottish ministers would have £390m more in spending available to them next year, the Scottish government argues that cuts imposed by the UK government since 2010 and the recent spending review mean that its discretionary budget will be 12.5% lower in real terms by 2019-20 than it was in 2010-11. Mr Swinney said 4.2% of that reduction would come between now and 2019-20. He said the chancellor has imposed real terms cuts on Scotland every year from now until 2020, and more than £1bn of those cuts are still to come between now and the end of the decade. Mr Swinney said schools, hospitals, and the police service in Scotland would "not be sacrificed to the chancellor's austerity obsession". He added that in recent years, the Scottish government has been able to deliver better outcomes for the people of Scotland, such as more police, lower crime, better schools,

The text discusses the challenges faced by individuals with severe disabilities and their families when accessing suitable toilet facilities while out in public. It highlights the inadequacy of standard accessible toilets and the need for Changing Places toilets, which offer enhanced features and more space. The text also emphasizes the importance of making Changing Places toilets compulsory in larger buildings to ensure inclusivity and accessibility for all.

A group of Italian consumers' organisations has made a formal complaint to the European Commission, accusing McDonald's of forcing franchisees to pay excessive rents and high fees. McDonald's responded by stating that they share risks and rewards with their licensees and are committed to supporting them. The Service Employees International Union (SEIU) and European unions, including the Bakers Food and Allied Workers Union in the UK, are supporting the antitrust complaint. They claim that McDonald's abuse of its dominant market position hurts franchisees, consumers, and workers. The European Commission has stated that it will study the submission and may launch an investigation if the allegations are founded. The consumer organisations claim that franchisees are prevented from switching to competitors due to longer-than-average contracts and are forced to lease premises from the company at above market rates. This, they say, leads to poorer consumer choice and higher prices in franchise stores compared to those owned directly by the company. Franchisees own and operate 73% of McDonald's restaurants in Europe, and McDonald's received $9.27bn (Â£6.40bn) in revenues from its franchised restaurants worldwide in 2014.

A social media campaign supporting 13-year-old Joshua Martin, who was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve, has gained global attention. The campaign began as a hashtag on Facebook and Instagram by Bangor Elim Church, where Joshua's father is on the pastoral staff, and has since gone viral. A mystery donor paid for a massive billboard with the hashtag #prayforjosh to be erected at Holywood playing fields. The campaign has received an overwhelming amount of support from people all over the world, including Joshua's classmates who have used the hashtag to show their support.

The UK government plans to close Brecon Barracks, a historic military site in Brecon, as part of a military restructuring. The closure has been condemned by local MP Chris Davies, who plans to fight it. The barracks have been operational since 1805 and have been involved in every conflict since then. The closure is expected to affect about 175 civilian and military personnel, although their jobs are not believed to be at risk. A new specialist light infantry center will be created at St Athan, Vale of Glamorgan, as part of the restructuring.

The UK fishing industry is concerned about being marginalized in Brexit negotiations, despite the industry's small size. The Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) is unpopular among fishers, who hope Brexit will allow them to regain control of UK waters and increase exports. However, shared fish stocks and the need for continued market access may complicate this. The House of Lords recommends retaining elements of the CFP and basing quotas on scientific advice. The industry is optimistic about Brexit, believing it will lead to fairer shares and better management. The government aims to ensure maximum trade freedom and review fisheries management for sustainability and a healthy marine environment.

OpenAI is backed by Tesla Motors and SpaceX CEO Elon Musk, Paypal co-founder Peter Thiel, Indian tech giant Infosys, and Amazon Web Services. The venture expects its research to focus on a positive human impact, free from financial obligations. Scientists have warned that advances in AI could threaten humanity, with Mr. Musk stating that AI is humanity's "biggest existential threat." British theoretical physicist Stephen Hawking also warned that AI could potentially "re-design itself at an ever-increasing rate" and outpace humans. However, other experts argue that the risk of AI posing any threat to humans remains remote. OpenAI's goal is to advance digital intelligence in a way that benefits humanity as a whole, unconstrained by a need to generate financial return. The statement on OpenAI's website said that AI should be an extension of individual human wills and, in the spirit of liberty, as broadly and evenly distributed as is possible safely. Only a tiny fraction of the $1bn pledged would be spent in the next few years.

L/Bdr Parkinson, who was injured in a bomb attack in Afghanistan in 2006, carried the Olympic torch in Doncaster on 26 June. He has received thousands of friend requests on Facebook, but the site limits personal pages to 5,000 friends. Despite his injury, L/Bdr Parkinson has maintained his sense of humor and intelligence, and spends 12 hours a day in the gym and rehab. He is also an active fundraiser for military charities and a patron of the Pilgrim Bandits. His mother, Diane, has been overwhelmed by the support and friendship shown to him, with his page receiving 19,000 hits on an update.

The poverty rate in the US was 15% in 2011, with 46.2 million Americans living in poverty. Real median income dropped by 1.5%, and income inequality, as measured by the Gini index, increased by 1.6%, the first rise since 1993. The percentage of Americans without health insurance fell to 15.7% from 16.3%. Poverty reached a record high in 2010, at 15.1%.

Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old cricketer who moved to the Red Rose from Somerset in 2013, has signed a new deal that will keep him at the club until 2019. He is known for scoring England's three fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball ton against Pakistan. Ashley Giles, cricket director and head coach, praised Buttler's talent and presence in the team, stating that his experience benefits the squad. Buttler, who is currently playing in the Indian Premier League with Mumbai Indians, will return to Lancashire for a T20 Blast home game against Durham.

The decommissioned Type 22 frigates HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall are currently moored in Portsmouth Harbour. Bidders had until 23 January to register an interest in the former Devonport-based ships. No proposals to preserve the ships have been submitted. A final decision is not expected until the spring. The government's Disposal Services Authority, which is handling the sale, wants to award at least one of the frigates to a UK ship recycler to determine the capacity of the UK's industry in the field. Penny Mordaunt, Conservative MP for Portsmouth North, said it was important UK recyclers had the chance to prove themselves in the field but she was also keen to see at least one of them saved from the scrapyard. She added: "For anyone that has served on a ship it's your home, you've literally been through the wars with it... and you want them to have a noble second life. "My preference is to go for the reef and diving attraction. "We've got to get best value for the budget but a reef would also generate income for part of the country through tourism." The Ministry of Defence has

Fiji has experienced significant political instability and international isolation since 1987, marked by four coups and a series of adverse events, including the introduction and withdrawal of a constitution enshrining indigenous Fijian political supremacy. These events have caused harm to the economy, particularly the tourism industry, and Fiji's international reputation. The population is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, with informal segregation running deep at almost every level of society. Fiji has a diverse economy, relying heavily on the sugar and tourism industries, but has been hampered by persistent trade and budget deficits, making it one of the world's largest per capita recipients of aid.

Syria missed the deadline to hand over its entire stockpile of chemical weapons, with Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad stating that a shipment was attacked twice. Mekdad also condemned US Secretary of State John Kerry's criticism of the government's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, where 246 people, including 73 children, have been killed in the last five days. Mekdad denied that the government had bombed civilian areas and accused the US of supporting terrorist elements in the country. The Syrian government denied reports that rebels had seized most of Aleppo's central prison, but the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights and rebel groups claim otherwise. The OPCW has admitted that security concerns have slowed down the process of destroying Syria's chemical weapons, which total about 1,300 tonnes.

The Booker Prize is open to all authors writing in English for the first time this year. The winner will be announced at London's Guildhall on Tuesday night. The shortlist includes three British writers, two Americans, and one Australian. Howard Jacobson, who won in 2010, is nominated for his futuristic love story J. Mukherjee's The Lives of Others begins in Calcutta in 1967 and focuses on the secrets and rivalries within a family against a backdrop of political activism. Ali Smith's How To Be Both tells two interlinking stories, one about a renaissance artist in 15th Century Italy, the other about a child of the 1960s. Joshua Ferris's To Rise Again at a Decent Hour looks at atheism through the eyes of a New York dentist. Karen Joy Fowler's We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves is the best-selling novel on the shortlist.

A celebrity, referred to as PJS, is appealing against a ruling that lifted a ban on naming him in the media in England and Wales. The Supreme Court will hear arguments on whether to grant the appeal and decide if it should be allowed or dismissed. An interim injunction remains in place until the end of the hearing. PJS, who has young children and a spouse in the public eye, has until 10:00 BST on Tuesday to apply to take the case to the UK Supreme Court. The Sun on Sunday wants to publish an account of alleged extra-marital activities by PJS, but he argues he has a right to privacy and has taken legal action. The story has been published in various places, making it difficult to maintain confidentiality.

Fosse Park, located near junction 21 of the M1, was purchased in August for £345.5m. Plans are underway to improve parking, traffic congestion, and the appearance of units. The new owners have met with Blaby District Council to address planning questions. The goal is to enhance the entrance to the city and address the quality of common areas, including walkways and parking facilities.

The live-action remake of Beauty and the Beast sparked controversy after it emerged it would feature a "gay moment", with the Malaysian Censorship Board (LPF) approving the screening but with a minor edit concerning the gay moment. Homosexual activity is illegal in Muslim-majority Malaysia, although the country's tourism minister has said banning the film is "ridiculous". The film was granted a "P13 parental guidance classification", and the LPF Chairman Datuk Abdul Hamid said, "We have approved the film so there is no more issue. Once a film receives approval, it means it can be screened." However, the date of screening and where the screening takes place is not under LPF's jurisdiction. Local cinema chains have been offering refunds for customers who have purchased tickets in advance. Beauty and the Beast director Bill Condon has spoken about the "exclusively gay moment" in the film, which involves LeFou - the sidekick of the film's main antagonist Gaston - who tries to come to terms with feelings for Gaston that swing between lust and admiration, as a side-plot to the main story.

Southampton City Council estimates there are 1,500 unlicensed Houses of Multiple Occupation (HMOs) in the area. Landlords with properties housing more than three unrelated people must apply for an HMO licence, which can cost up to ??1,000. Despite facing fines of up to ??20,000 for non-compliance, many landlords are deterred by the cost. Tenants in unlicensed HMOs frequently express concerns about eviction and poorly maintained properties. Nationally, mandatory licensing applies to properties of three storeys or more occupied by five or more unrelated people. In Southampton, the licences apply to properties in specific areas, including Bargate, Bevois, Portswood, Swaythling, and Shirley Freemantle, Millbrook, and Bassett. The council has prosecuted one firm and 13 individuals for non-compliance.

Enda Kenny of Fine Gael and Micheál Martin of Fianna Fáil aim to prevent a second election. Fianna Fáil will assist in forming a minority government but will not endorse a program for government. Water charges are a significant issue in reaching an agreement. A commission to consider the future of Irish Water is being considered. Fianna Fáil wants to remove water charges immediately, while Fine Gael supports their continued use. Fine Gael has 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23, and the Labour Party 7. No party has been able to form a majority government, and TDs have failed to elect a taoiseach.

The Sorrento, a ferry owned by Atlantica di Navigazione, caught fire on one of its car decks about 27km (17 miles) from Mallorca while traveling to Valencia. The fire quickly got out of control, leading to the evacuation of passengers onto lifeboats, which were later picked up by another ship, the Puglia. At least three people were injured, with one in serious condition, and were taken to hospital by helicopter. Spanish officials stated that the rescued passengers were on their way back to Palma de Mallorca and were expected to arrive in a few hours. The Balearic Islands port authority indicated that the Sorrento may sink at its current location.

The Electoral Commission reported that 38 MPs raised concerns about individuals, including students, potentially voting twice, which is a criminal offence. They suggested that better integration of individual electoral registers run by councils could help identify duplicate entries. Labour cautioned against making it harder for young people to register to vote. A record 46.8 million people were registered to vote in the 8 June election, with a 68.7% turnout, the highest since 1997. Several constituencies saw an increase in electorate size by more than 10%, including those with large student populations. Between 1 December 2016 and the 22 May deadline, about 4.9 million applications to vote were submitted, the majority online. However, the net increase in the number of entries on the electoral register was only 1.4 million, suggesting a significant proportion of applications were likely duplicates. The lack of a direct link between electoral registers and the online registration service, which is used by most people, is a contributing factor. The Electoral Commission called for clearer information on registration sites, potentially including a verification function, to address the issue. They also recommended that people registered in two seats choose in advance which one

Lawrence Phillips, a former NFL player, was believed to have committed suicide in prison. He was a star player in the 1990s but had a troubled career and life, with multiple convictions for assault. Despite his intelligence and good qualities, he struggled with anger issues and personal demons.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram and the 30th in a line of mascot rams, was promoted to the rank of lance corporal in the Mercian Regiment for "good behaviour". He joined the regiment in February 2014 and has since participated in various events, including switching on the Christmas lights in Ashbourne and meeting Prince William.

The UK government will keep Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland updated about Brexit negotiations. The government wants to hold monthly meetings to share analysis and allow the devolved administrations to voice their views. The meeting was constructive and amicable, with different standpoints being discussed. However, the Scottish government is seeking greater clarity and transparency on the UK government's intentions, particularly regarding membership in the single market and customs union. The Scottish government will oppose the UK government in the Supreme Court during the appeal of the High Court judgment on how Article 50 will be triggered.

The passage describes a study on cloned sheep, including Dolly's identical twin sisters, to determine if they age normally and are healthy. The study focuses on three common age-related diseases: cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis. The results, which could impact the future of cloning, will be published next week.

Trainer John Gosden's unbeaten 4-7 favorite, Shutter Speed, won the Musidora Stakes by a length and three-quarters over Vintage Folly. Shutter Speed will race next at Chantilly, while stablemates Enable and Coronet are top contenders for the Epsom Oaks. William Haggas trained Tasleet to victory in the Duke of York Stakes. Frankie Dettori, who rode Shutter Speed to victory, noted that the soft ground was challenging but believes she will perform better on better ground. Gosden is concerned about the ground for his colt Cracksman in Thursday's Dante Stakes and will decide whether he runs in the Derby trial after walking the course.

The currency initially slipped against the dollar and euro, then recovered in mid-afternoon trading before falling again. The volatility index, a measure of investors' uncertainty, hit levels last seen in the 2008 financial crisis. The Leave campaign argued that the pound simply retreated to March levels. The pound was down 0.2% against the dollar at $1.4226, down 0.6% against the euro at €1.2605, and weakened by 1% against the Japanese yen to just over 151. Investors were spooked by data showing the chances of a Remain vote had fallen, although markets had also been rattled by global economic worries. With 10 days to go before the referendum vote, two polls at the weekend put the Leave camp ahead, while betting firm Betfair said the implied probability of a vote to Remain had now fallen to 68.5% from almost 80% a week earlier. How trade and the UK's economy are affected by membership of the EU. "We expect incoming polls to move the pound more aggressively than before," said Charalambos Pissouros, senior analyst at Iron

The Iron are currently sixth in the National League, one point and one place outside the play-off spots. Despite a six or seven-hour journey and conceding a goal after five minutes, manager Cowley remained positive after their loss to a very good Barrow team. Cowley praised the team's efforts so far, acknowledging the challenges of being a part-time team facing their toughest challenge to date.

The passage discusses a significant change in the planning system in Northern Ireland, where, starting April 2015, local councils will take over planning decisions from the Planning Service. This shift is seen as an opportunity for local development by some, like Michael Corr from PLACE, but others, like James Orr from Friends of the Earth, are concerned about potential discrimination and favoritism in planning decisions. The change also raises concerns about transparency and the influence of political relationships with developers. The new system requires strict enforcement of a code of conduct to ensure fairness and transparency. Additionally, there is a debate about the transparency of political donations, with some arguing for more disclosure to prevent undue influence on planning decisions.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was found injured by her owner in NiddryView, Winchburgh, after being shot three times with an airgun. The cat had to have one of its legs amputated due to the severity of the injury. The Scottish SPCA is investigating the incident and is urging anyone with information to come forward. The charity's chief superintendent, Mike Flynn, has called for the Scottish government to implement a licensing system for airguns, as the incident highlights the danger such weapons pose. Last year, the Scottish government held a consultation on licensing air weapons, but a majority of respondents opposed the plan.

Liverpool have signed Christian Benteke from Aston Villa for £32.5m, making him their second most expensive signing. Benteke, who scored 49 goals in 101 games for Villa, is expected to revive Liverpool's attack after a disappointing season. The Belgian international has signed a long-term contract and is excited to work with manager Brendan Rodgers. Liverpool have also signed Danny Ings, Roberto Firmino, and Divock Origi to strengthen their attacking options.

The study, commissioned by Tablets for Schools, examined the impact of tablet devices in schools. It found no clear evidence of academic improvement for students using these devices. However, many students reported taking internet-connected devices to bed to continue social media conversations. The study also found that tablet computers are now being used in 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools. In some schools, every pupil had an individual tablet device. The highest use of tablet computers was found in academy schools. The underlying trend is for an increasing number of tablet computers in schools, with the number expected to rise significantly between 2014 and 2016. Despite the lack of clear academic improvement, head teachers reported a positive impact, including motivation for disengaged pupils and increased family involvement. The role of technology in schools is expected to grow, with Dr. Barbie Clarke stating that it will almost seem ridiculous if some schools are not using technology.

The exhibition Growing Up in the City at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 photographs capturing over 100 years of childhood life in Liverpool. The images span from the 1880s to the 1990s, showing how childhood and special occasions have changed over time. The exhibition was curated by Kay Jones, who selected the photographs from hundreds of images in the National Museums Liverpool's collections. The exhibition includes images of children at play, working, and attending events like a fancy dress ball.

Anderson, a 27-year-old centre-back, has left Barrow by mutual consent to join their National League rivals. He has previously played for Aldershot, Exeter, and in Italy. He could face his former club on 18 February. Keating, a 21-year-old striker, has joined Torquay United, subject to international clearance. He has previously played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps. Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson has praised both signings, highlighting Anderson's leadership and Keating's potential. Torquay United are currently four points above the relegation zone and have won only one of their last six games.

The law permits 12-year-olds to work for others with parental authorization. Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera said the new legislation reflects Bolivia's needs as one of South America's poorest countries. The law sets a 30-year jail sentence for child homicide. More than 500,000 children work in Bolivia to supplement family income, according to the United Nations Children's Fund (Unicef). Many work in mines and agricultural fields under extreme conditions. The International Labour Organisation says children under 15 should not work, but allows a minimum working age of 14 for developing countries. The ILO is studying the legislation to decide whether it breaches international regulations on child labor.

Rosie O'Donnell experienced a heart attack after helping a woman struggling to exit her car. She recognized her symptoms by searching online and took aspirin. The next day, a cardiologist inserted a stent into a 99% blocked artery. O'Donnell emphasized the importance of recognizing heart attack symptoms in women and calling emergency services.

A 16-year-old boy, Che Labastide-Wellington, was stabbed and killed at a party in Kenton on Saturday evening. The police believe he was not involved in an earlier altercation with a group of youths who were denied entry to the party, which appeared to be well-run with appropriate adults present. A 21-year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of murder, and three other boys, aged 15, 16, and 14, have been arrested or bailed in connection with the incident.

The passage describes a new approach to cancer diagnosis in Denmark, implemented due to poor cancer survival statistics. The changes include fast-track diagnosis for patients with alarm symptoms, diagnosis centers for patients with undiagnosed symptoms, and "yes-no" centers for patients with minor symptoms. The results have been positive, with improved survival rates and better organization of resources. The changes have not led to an increase in GP referrals but have improved the speed of diagnosis and treatment for cancer patients.

Powys has won a competitive bidding process to take over the role of the OFT in issuing warning and banning orders against dishonest estate agents. They will receive £170,000 a year for this work. Complaints will still be handled by local authority trading standards, who will refer cases to Powys if they believe the Estate Agents Act has been breached. Powys hopes this will lead to more contracts and outside work in the future.

NHS Employers has approved a plan to reshape the NHS workforce, following a Nuffield Trust review that found nurses could take on additional tasks with more training. The review highlighted examples of nurses filling in for doctors and pharmacists. However, unions warned against using this as a quick fix for NHS problems. The report suggested that reshaping the workforce could help address gaps in junior doctor rotas and GP shortages, as well as adapt to the changing nature of care. The report also noted that doctors make up only about one in 10 of the workforce, so more is needed from other health staff. The report's author, Candace Imison, said there were "huge opportunities" in reshaping the workforce, while NHS Employers chief executive Danny Mortimer said the challenge now is to take forward the learning and recommendations in the report. However, British Medical Association leader Dr Mark Porter said this should not be done "at the expense of good quality training for doctors or indeed doctors themselves". Unison head of health Christina McAnea added that the squeeze on funding in the health service meant there was often no funding for training courses, and developing the NHS support workforce must not be seen as a quick and cheap fix for chronic shortages of nurses and

The A36 road in Bath was closed at Rackfield Place due to a crash at 03:00 GMT, causing disruption and delays during rush hour. The road was reopened at 14:00 GMT. Investigations into the collision are ongoing. First bus services were affected, but they are expected to return to a normal schedule by the evening commute. The managing director of First expressed gratitude to the public and staff for their support and cooperation.

NRW estimated that the lagoon would result in 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout dying each year as they migrate to and from local rivers. TLP disputed these figures, claiming that NRW refused to share its methodology for calculating them and that the figures were based on unrealistic scenarios. TLP estimated that the lagoon would kill 2% of all species of fish in a worst-case scenario. The UK government is considering the findings of a six-month review of the viability of the scheme, which has yet to be published. Wales' Environment Secretary Lesley Griffiths said the Welsh Government was very supportive of the scheme but needed clarity on the UK government's position in the very near future. NRW strongly disagreed with TLP's criticism and stated that they had received a vast amount of evidence from the applicant and had held detailed discussions for a year and a half, during which they shared a huge amount of information, data, and methodology.

Stormont's Enterprise, Trade and Investment (DETI) Minister Arlene Foster announced the development of a new industry-led agri-food marketing body, similar to Scotland Food and Drink, to be developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB). Foster emphasized the importance of Northern Ireland's agri-food industry, which employs nearly 100,000 people in farming, fishing, retail, and distribution. Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill welcomed the announcement, noting the need for better coordination of marketing activities and expressing interest in discussing the plans with AFSB.

The Woodland Trust is organizing a tree-planting event at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley on Saturday afternoon, inviting the public to participate in planting 40,000 native trees to commemorate the millions who died during WW1. The project aims to create four new woods across the UK, with Brackfield Wood specifically honoring the estimated 40,000 people from the island of Ireland who lost their lives in the conflict. The trust's director, Patrick Cregg, emphasized the significance of the event, encouraging local people and visitors to join in and make a personal contribution to the project. The charity will provide saplings, and volunteers are advised to wear sturdy footwear. The event will take place just off the Glenshane Road, with limited parking available for participants.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award in Harrogate on Thursday. The book was described as "an emotionally exhausting and powerful story" by one of the judges, Alison Graham. US author Sara Paretsky, who created detective VI Warshawski, received an outstanding contribution honour. The panel felt Hilary's winning book was "so finely written and tightly written", and the subject matter was well done and well plotted. The other books on the shortlist were also noted. Sara Paretsky was chosen for the outstanding contribution to crime fiction award after her 23-year career writing about VI Warshawski, a female private investigator from Chicago.

Mitch Santner, a 24-year-old left-arm batsman and spinner, broke his finger in his second game for Worcestershire in 2016. Director of cricket Steve Rhodes expressed a desire for Santner to return, as his absence was a significant blow to the team's hopes of qualifying for further competitions. Santner, who made his Test debut in 2015, will rejoin the Rapids following the ICC Trophy in England in June. He expressed a desire to make up for lost time and have a positive impact on the team with both batting and bowling. In August, Worcestershire signed Australian pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season across all formats.

Barry Pring, a 47-year-old millionaire, was killed in 2008 in Kiev when a speeding car hit him as he tried to hail a taxi. His wife, Ganna Ziuzina, who was 19 years younger, returned to a restaurant for a missing glove at the time of the incident. The coroner recorded a verdict of unlawful killing, stating that the evidence, though circumstantial, was overwhelming. Ziuzina tried to claim Pring's assets within days of his death, and his family believes he was murdered in a staged hit and run accident. Ziuzina sold Pring's assets and moved funds from his bank account after his death. Despite the Ukrainian police closing the initial inquiry, they relaunched it in 2011 as a murder investigation, which remains active but not actively pursued.

Sophie Fearns' son Charlie, who is from Merseyside, needs to fly back to Seattle, America for experimental treatment that is unavailable in the UK. Charlie urgently needs more T-Cell Therapy at Seattle Children's Hospital after the last transplant failed. Charlie has been ill since the age of three, and after a third relapse in April, there was "no option" left for treatment for him in the UK. Charlie's family was left "heartbroken" when the first T-Cell transplant did not work. Charlie's family was left "heartbroken" when the first T-Cell transplant did not work. The family was left "heartbroken" when the first T-Cell transplant did not work. The family was left "heartbroken" when the first T-Cell transplant did not work.

Apple has introduced a two-step verification system to enhance the security of its iCloud service, following reports of third-party software being used to steal celebrities' intimate photos. This system requires users to enter a four-digit code, sent to a trusted mobile number, in addition to their username and password when accessing iCloud from a new device. The system also sends an email notification when a backup is downloaded. While some experts recommend making this system the default, others argue that it should be optional. Vladimir Katalov, the owner of Elcomsoft, the company behind the software used in the hacks, acknowledged that Apple's changes would prevent his software from accessing iCloud data in the same way.

Billericay, an English football club currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, is in the process of finalizing a deal that would see 30-year-old Ian Wright buy 20% of the club. Wright, who was a runner-up on I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here in 2011, played non-league football for several clubs, including Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds. The club was recently taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who is "comfortable" investing £10,000 a week. The club has also recently signed former England international Paul Konchesky.

Mr Ashley has been asked to provide evidence regarding the treatment of his workers following a BBC investigation into the working practices at his Derbyshire warehouse. He has been given until 21 March to respond to a letter from Hartlepool MP Iain Wright, who also chairs the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee. The committee is keeping the treatment of low-paid workers and the enforcement of the national minimum wage under review. Mr Ashley has been invited to a meeting at his company's base in Shirebrook but has not agreed to attend any of the proposed dates. The committee has warned that failure to attend could result in further action, including seeking the support of the House of Commons for any complaint of contempt. Sports Direct has not responded to the BBC's request for a comment.

The report, Putin. War, compiled by Ilya Yashin and colleagues of a murdered opposition politician, accuses President Vladimir Putin of waging war in Ukraine for personal gain. The report, based on facts from Russian and foreign media, details the human and economic cost of the conflict. It presents evidence that Russian soldiers and equipment were crucial in major victories claimed by pro-Russian rebels in Donetsk and Luhansk. The report also reveals that Russian spending on the conflict is calculated at 53bn roubles (£665m; $1bn). Despite the evidence, critics argue that the report may not galvanize protests against Putin, as previous reports have not.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, was found dead at the Woodhead Tunnels off the A628 in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday. The 34-year-old from Wath-Upon-Dearn in Rotherham died from head injuries. A 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield by South Yorkshire Police in connection with the death and remain in custody.

The Welsh government was not consulted on the Article 50 letter, which was a source of frustration for Carwyn Jones. Despite this, the UK government emphasized its commitment to developing a negotiating framework for the whole of the UK, with Wales being specifically mentioned in the letter. However, there was uncertainty regarding which powers would be devolved to Wales and whether there would be funding to accompany them.

Two cars were damaged in Newry's Nursery Drive and Parkhead area on Friday night. The Assistant Chief Constable, Stephen Martin, expressed his dismay at the attacks on PSNI officers and the Newry community. The PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook page stated that police were attacked while performing their duties and appealed to parents to be aware of their children's activities.

Mr Charney, the founder and former CEO of American Apparel, was ousted due to employee complaints and accusations of fund misuse. The board does not expect him to return. Charney's lawyer denies the company's allegations of illicit emails and racial taunts. The board argues that Charney's conduct violated company policies and that hiring him would pose a risk to the company and its shareholders. American Apparel obtained a restraining order against Charney, preventing him from making negative statements about the company and attempting to remove board members.

The game between Greece and Britain will be covered on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app. Earlier this month, Greece won against Britain in Patras, Greece, with a score of 92-64. However, three members of the Greek team will be missing at the Copper Box, giving Britain a chance for revenge. The game will be Britain's only home game before they compete at FIBA EuroBasket 2017, which starts at the beginning of September. After the game against Greece, coach Joe Prunty's team will travel to a four-team tournament in Poland for their last warm-up games before EuroBasket starts. The game will be played at the Copper Box, and British guard Teddy Okereafor, who is from Stratford, expressed his excitement about playing there and believes the atmosphere will be great.

The passage describes the transformative impact of the iPhone, which was introduced by Steve Jobs in 2007. It highlights the skepticism surrounding the iPhone's potential before its launch and the subsequent revolution it brought to the world of technology and communication. The author, who initially doubted the iPhone's significance, later acknowledged its profound influence on various aspects of life, including photography and mobile internet use. The passage also mentions the rapid advancements in technology by other companies like Amazon and Google, emphasizing the continuous evolution in the tech industry.

The RSPCA confirmed that all cats near Victor Avenue in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, had ingested a toxic substance. In the most recent case, a seven-month-old cat named Meereen died on Monday after consuming antifreeze. The RSPCA is unsure whether the poisonings were accidental or deliberate. Three other cats in the area have died in the last seven days, and another cat died two weeks ago. Meereen's owner, Adria Pearce, is devastated by her cat's death. The RSPCA is appealing to residents to ensure pesticides and chemicals are stored safely, especially antifreeze, as it is the time of year when it is commonly used in cars.

The Syriza government in Greece is set to agree and implement more austerity and liberalisation measures, mandated by creditors. Despite this, Greece's resorts are teeming with tourists, with Athens airport expecting 25 million arrivals this year, up from 21 million. The Greek people are not protesting against the austerity measures, possibly because they are waiting for more information on the new bailout deal, or because they are aware of the near-death experience Greece had in July, which may have turned Syriza into disciples of TINA ("there is no alternative"). Despite conspicuously failing to deliver an end to fiscal austerity, Tsipras remains remarkably popular. However, the new bailout will only hold if Tsipras can offer hope of better times ahead. Many argue that good economics and politics require creditors to ease the burden of Greece's unsustainably large debts by between a third and a half.

Grant Mitchell, a memorable character from EastEnders, will make a brief return to the show to reunite with his family following the announcement of Dame Barbara Windsor's character's death. Kemp, who played Grant from 1990-1999 and then again in 2005 and 2006, will return to bring the Mitchell family back together. The Mitchell brothers will be reunited with their mother for the last time, as her character will be killed off after a cancer diagnosis. The return of the Mitchell brothers is an opportunity to showcase Ross Kemp and Steve McFadden at their very best.

Alice Ruggles was fatally attacked by Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon, who had stalked her. Her parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, had a premonition that Dhillon was responsible when police arrived at their door to inform them of her death. Dhillon was found guilty of murder and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years in prison. In response to their daughter's tragic death, her parents established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about the dangers of stalking.

EDF, the French firm financing the £18bn Hinkley Point project in Somerset, approved the funding at a board meeting, with contracts to be signed on Friday.
