The study, which tracked adult drinking patterns at the county level, found that 8% of Americans were considered heavy drinkers and 18% were binge drinkers in 2012. The increase in drinking rates is attributed to changing social norms, increased affordability due to lower taxes, and increased alcohol advertising. Public health experts suggest that the rise in binge drinking is linked to changing social norms, with women trying to catch up to men in drinking habits.

The United Nations has warned that doctors are performing caesarean sections too readily, putting the health of women and their babies at risk. The procedure should only be carried out when medically necessary due to the risks of infections and even death. In England, just over a quarter of women now have a caesarean, a rate that has more than doubled since the early 1990s. The World Health Organization recommends that the rate should ideally be between 10% and 15% due to the dangers and costs involved. A planned caesarean costs the NHS an average of £2,369, compared to £1,665 for a natural birth. The WHO also said that doctors were carrying out the procedure too often and underestimating the risks.

A woman, Michelle Filkins, 44, of West Wareham, was arrested after allegedly breaking into a home on Martha's Vineyard, living there for at least a week, and selling items belonging to the owners in a yard sale. She was discovered by the owner, Mark Conklin, on April 17. Filkins was charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. She fled the scene in a gray Nissan pickup truck but was later arrested after attempting to re-enter the home. Filkins is scheduled to appear in court on May 14. The police are asking anyone who received items from the home to return them to the Edgartown Police Department.

A lost iPhone was returned to its owner, Bella Crooke, after police at Albury Police Station posted a series of humorous photos and messages on her Facebook page. The officers used the unlocked phone to post selfies and humorous updates, assuring Bella that her phone was safe and in good hands. Bella, who had lost her phone at a friend's birthday party, was eventually able to reclaim it without providing her name, as the officers recognized her from her Facebook page. The police's lighthearted approach was well-received by Bella and her friends, who praised the officers for their sense of humor and quick action in returning the phone.

A five-day-old hippopotamus was caught in a fight between two adult hippos in Isimangaliso Wetland Park, South Africa, and was thrown into the air. The calf was killed hours later, with its mother watching in horror. The mother had tried to protect her calf from other hippos, but the calf was grabbed by one of the adults during the fight. The mother attacked the hippo to get her calf back, but the calf was flicked into the air and died from its injuries.

Starbucks announced that a computer outage affecting registers at 8,000 stores in the US and Canada has been resolved. The outage, which began in the early evening on the east coast and late afternoon on the west coast, prompted baristas to give away free drinks. The company did not explain the cause of the outage, which affected 7,000 stores in the US and 1,000 in Canada. Starbucks released a statement saying the outage was caused by a failure during a daily system refresh and that they are actively working to resolve it. The outage also affected Evolution Fresh and Teavana stores. Twitter users spread the word about the giveaway and shared photos of their free drinks. Some stores closed their doors to avoid giving away free products during the shutdown. The potentially costly tech snafu comes just one day after Starbucks posted record quarterly earnings with net revenues of $4.6 billion.

Terrorists are undergoing training in rural areas of West Wales, including Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire. Locations in these areas are also being used to radicalise Muslims. Those involved in such activities participate in seemingly ordinary activities in the community but have an ulterior motive. Speaking to Ceredigion Council, Detective Constable Gareth Jones stressed that issues surrounding terrorism were not confined to large cities. Incidents of Islamic extremist activity in Wales can be traced back to 1998, when hate preacher Abu Hamza sent a group of 10 extremists to train in the Brecon Beacons in Powys. The area is one of several locations used by the British military for training. In 2005, two of the 7/7 bombers, Mohammad Sidique Khan and Shehzad Tanweer, were photographed white water rafting at the National Whitewater Centre in Bala, North Wales. Five years later, three would-be terrorists from Cardiff were arrested as part of an Al-Qaeda-inspired gang who plotted a `Mumbai-style' series of terror attacks on Britain. Michael Adebowale, one of the men convicted of murdering Fusilier Lee Rigby,

A species of whale, the Omura's whale, feared to be extinct, was found washed up on a remote beach in West Australia, providing scientists with an opportunity to learn more about the mammal. The whale, a 5.68 m juvenile female, was identified using DNA profiling. The discovery was significant as very little was known about the species, which was only described in scientific journals for the first time in 2003. The whale, usually found in Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan, has a sleek body shape and several unique skeletal features, including 53 vertebrae and four digits on each pectoral fin. The carcass has been buried, and the skeleton will be recovered in a few years for further scientific investigation and possible public display in museums.

A female businesswoman in Texas, Cheryl Rios, argues that Hillary Clinton should not be president due to concerns about her hormones potentially leading to irrational decisions, such as starting unnecessary wars. Rios believes that women's hormones make them less suitable for leadership roles, despite supporting equal rights. Studies show that women leaders take fewer unnecessary risks than men, and male hormones have impaired some male leaders' decision-making throughout history. Rios' views reflect a broader bias against women in the workplace, as evidenced by the underrepresentation of women in leadership positions and the persistent gender stereotypes that affect how women are perceived and treated in professional settings. The article argues that gender equality benefits everyone, including families, companies, and society as a whole.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy is auctioning off his extensive collection of antiques, valued at £100,000, as he downsizes his home. The collection includes over 200 items, such as a hand-painted limewood diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, early Victorian furniture, a portrait of Hardy holding a longbow, and a variety of other antiques, including paintings, furniture, swords, flintlock rifles, silverware, and crystal chandeliers. The auction will take place on Saturday at Dominic Winter Auctioneers in South Cerney, Gloucestershire, featuring 238 lots. Hardy, a military historian and expert on the medieval longbow, has expressed sadness over parting with his cherished collection but hopes it will bring joy to its new owners.

Michael Scott Shemansky is on the run after being named a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, in Winter Garden, Florida. He was supposed to have a supervised visit with his son on the day his mother's body was discovered, but he failed to appear. An out-of-state family member had called for a well-being check, and foul play was determined in the investigation. Shemansky is already on parole for battery on law enforcement, has a history of bipolar mental illness, and was involuntarily committed to a psychiatric ward for an attempted suicide. His estranged wife has filed a domestic violence injunction against him and is preparing to protect herself in case he arrives at her home. Anyone with information on his whereabouts is urged to contact authorities.

The city of Eugene in the United States has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. The International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) Council decided to bypass the usual bidding process due to a unique strategic opportunity to host the event in the USA for the first time. Eugene had previously failed to secure the hosting rights for the 2019 event, which was awarded to Doha. The IAAF Council emphasized the strategic importance of the decision, highlighting the collaboration between public authorities, the private sector, the national Olympic committee, NBC, and an enthusiastic public. This marks the second time the IAAF has awarded the championships without a bidding process, the first being the 2007 event in Osaka, Japan. Mo Farah won gold in the men's 10,000 meters during the 2013 IAAF World Athletics Championships in Moscow.

Cesc Fabregas, a Chelsea midfielder, has been struggling in the second half of the season, including a poor performance in Spain's 2-0 defeat by Holland. Despite a strong start to the season, Fabregas' form has declined, with only one assist in his last five games for Chelsea. His former club, Barcelona, noted his tendency for a late-season slump. With nine games remaining, Chelsea needs Fabregas to regain his form to secure the Premier League title.

West Ham is discussing a deal for Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford, who has impressed on trial with the club's academy. Beckford, a 17-year-old from Montego Bay United, has also received offers from Belgian clubs and is considered one of the top prospects from the Caribbean. West Ham is also closing in on signing Beckford and has announced affordable season ticket prices starting at £289 to fill their new stadium for the 2016-17 season.

Police have dropped an investigation into a vicious assault on a huntsman, despite a wealth of evidence pointing to the identity of a suspected attacker. The victim, Mike Lane, 40, who was beaten by balaclava-clad protesters armed with iron bars on ropes, condemned the decision by police as "pathetic." Lane, who is joint master of the Tedworth hunt, was sent flying to the ground and kicked in the head during the incident, resulting in concussion, broken teeth, and memory loss. A video of the incident and a dossier of evidence, including names of saboteurs and their car registration numbers, was given to Wiltshire police after the assault. Despite this, Wiltshire police confirmed they had stopped the investigation pending further information.

Chinese parents are passionate about raising child prodigies, such as 10-year-old university entrants or four-year-old Michael Jackson dance-alikes. A new basketball superstar is on the rise, as a viral video shows a five-year-old boy named Mai Zizhuo displaying basketball skills that would put many professional players to shame. Mai has been shooting hoops since he was two and a half years old. The video shows him scoring a succession of hoops before running around dribbling two basketballs, with his eyes focused on the camera. His incredible skills have won him legions of fans across China. Netizens have left thousands of comments, with some feeling ashamed of their own basketball skills in comparison to the kid.

Tom O'Carroll, a former key activist for the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE), which campaigned to legalize child sex in the 1970s and 80s, has joined the supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off. O'Carroll attended a Hacked Off rally in the Houses of Parliament on February 25 to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation. Hacked Off is campaigning against the Independent Press Standards Organisation, which it sees as biased and unfair, and wants MPs to set up a statutory body to regulate the press, as recommended by the Leveson Inquiry. O'Carroll's support for Hacked Off will be an embarrassment to the group. PIE was formed in 1974 to campaign for sex with children to be legalised and formed an alliance with the National Council for Civil Liberties (NCCL), which lobbied parliament for the age of sexual consent to be cut to ten as long as the child "understood the nature of the act" and apparently consented. O'Carroll was on the NCCL's gay rights sub-committee and was jailed in 1981 for "

Bondi's Icebergs Club pool was drained on Thursday to create a unique catwalk for Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. The empty pool was used as the unusual catwalk setting for the Ten Pieces presentation. The lifestyle brand, headed up by Icebergs restaurateur Maurice Terzini and his partner Lucy Hinckfuss, produces unisex collections of ten pieces designed to be worn in 20 different ways. Guests were treated to nibbles by Icebergs and drinks from Santa Vittoria as they took in the minimalist, androgynous designs. The collection was presented in an entirely monochrome style, with models walking through the concrete pool and along the break wall with a backdrop of the ocean. The show took place on an unseasonably warm 28 degrees Celsius day, with beautiful blue skies.

Amir Khan, a Bolton-born boxer, spent a family day at a safari park in Northern California, where he posed with and fed a rare white tiger, as well as giraffes and sea lions. Khan was accompanied by his wife Faryal Makhdoom Khan and daughter Lamysa. Earlier in the week, Khan announced his next fight against former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30.

A Palestinian teenager's name, Mohammed Abu Khdeir, was included on an Israeli memorial commemorating fallen soldiers and victims of terrorism, but his family and others objected to his inclusion. Abu Khdeir, 16, was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July, according to prosecutors. His father, Hussein Abu Khdeir, stated that no one asked for his permission to put his son's name on the wall. Almagor, an organization that works on behalf of victims of terror in Israel, also opposed Abu Khdeir's inclusion on the memorial, describing his death as a rogue attack and not a terror victim. The national insurance institute of Israel, which maintains the memorial site, will remove Abu Khdeir's name from the memorial following his father's complaints.

A young boy in California, filmed by his YouTube user father Lionel Hutz, chases the family cat around the garden in an attempt to use it as a pillow. The cat initially licks its fur before the boy lies on it, causing the cat to move away. The boy follows and repeats the process until the cat wanders indoors. A subsequent video shows the boy and cat have made up, with the boy feeding the cat treats.

A police corruption trial in Philadelphia is ongoing, with witness Robert Kushner, a former drug dealer, losing his varsity coaching job at the Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after testifying about his past and implicating undercover officers in a 2007 incident where they allegedly stole $81,000 and 7 pounds of marijuana from him. Kushner had passed a background check when he was hired in 2010 and was open about his past arrests, which were expunged as part of a probationary sentence. However, he was arrested again in 2011 and sentenced to four years of probation. Kushner testified that he never meant to deceive the school and believes he is innocent of the 2011 charges. The defense for the six former drug squad officers accused of racketeering claims the government's case is based on lying drug dealers and a rogue ex-cop.

An explosion at a chemical plant in China's Fujian province caused a fire and injured six people. The plant, located in Zhangzhou city, produces paraxylene, a chemical used in polyester production. The blast occurred after an oil leak, and more than 600 firefighters were deployed to control the fire. The plant had previously experienced an explosion in 2013, and its construction had sparked protests due to pollution concerns.

Jack Grealish, an Aston Villa teenager, is known for wearing his socks low and using children's shinpads due to superstition. Despite referees advising him to change, Grealish remains steadfast in his routine, as it has kept him injury-free. He made his first Premier League start in a 3-3 draw against QPR and is hopeful for more opportunities this season.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, the daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has global and irreversible brain damage, according to her grandmother. She is no longer in a medically induced coma but remains unresponsive. Her father, Bobby Brown, stated that she is awake and watching him, but her grandmother and a source close to the situation have said that she remains unresponsive. Bobby Brown's wife, Alicia Etheredge-Brown, said that Bobbi Kristina has made it out of ICU, opened her eyes, and started a long and hard rehabilitation.

Russia is on the brink of making the Fed Cup final with a 2-0 lead after Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point to beat Germany's Sabine Lisicki on Saturday. Pavlyuchenkova saved the match point in the second set before going on to beat Lisicki 4-6, 7-6 (4), 6-3, after Svetlana Kuznetsova beat Julia Goerges in straight sets in the opening rubber. Pavlyuchenkova said Lisicki's power caused her problems: "In the first set, I believed I could win, but I couldn't find the rhythm because she plays a bit boom-boom." Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova of Russia beat Germany's Sabine Lisicki for a 2-0 lead in their Fed Cup tie. Svetlana Kuznetsova had earlier beaten Julia Goerges in straight sets. Both players had problems on their serve - Pavlyuchenkova racked up 13 double faults but Lisicki's 63 unforced errors proved crucial. "It was very close and I had a match point,

Nina Moric, a model who appeared in Ricky Martin's "La Vida Loca" video, denied claims that she tried to take her own life. She stated that she collapsed due to low blood pressure and was treated in the hospital. Italian media reported that her boyfriend, Luigi Mario Favoloso, suggested that she was a victim of people who wanted to harm her. However, Moric reassured her fans that she was recovering at home after the accident.

Kate and William are expecting their second child, and the British public is hoping for a traditional name. A YouGov survey for The Sunday Times revealed that Diana is the favorite name if the baby is a girl, with Alice and Charlotte also being popular choices. If the baby is a boy, James and Alexander are the most favored names. A quarter of the 2,200 people polled wanted the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge to have a female baby, with only three percent hoping for a younger brother for George. The poll also showed that the majority of Brits support William's decision to take six weeks of paternity leave from his pilot job.

A suicide bomber killed 17 people and wounded 64, including an Afghan lawmaker, near a group of protesters in Khost, Afghanistan. The Taliban denied responsibility, and no other group has claimed the attack. The protesters were heading to a larger rally against the provincial governor when the attack occurred around 10 a.m. local time.

Dani Alves is set to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer. Alves, who has been with Barcelona for seven years, winning four Spanish titles and the Champions League twice, was unable to agree on a new deal. His representative, Dinorah Santana, stated that the negotiations are over after Alves rejected a three-year contract extension that required him to play in 60% of matches.

Pablo Osvaldo, who is currently on loan at Boca Juniors from Southampton, has expressed his desire for Italian legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at the Argentine club. Osvaldo, who has scored three goals in six games since his move, believes that the duo would be a good fit for Boca and that the fans would love to see them play at La Bombonera. Osvaldo has played with many great players over the years and considers Pirlo and Totti to be among the best. He feels that their South American style would make them perfect for Boca and that the fans would go absolutely crazy for players like them. Pirlo is widely regarded as one of the best midfielders in the world, while Totti is a Roma legend who would be equally loved if he moved to Argentina.

Lewis Ferguson, an 18-year-old amateur jockey, became an internet sensation after a spectacular fall from the favorite horse, Merrion Square, at Wincanton. Despite the fall, Ferguson was back riding out and undeterred from getting back in the saddle. He only suffered a cut on his nose from the ordeal. Ferguson described the fall as a blur and mentioned that he couldn't understand what had happened until he watched the replay in the weighing room. He expressed gratitude for being lucky and mentioned that he had received some abuse from fellow jockeys and gained a few hundred Twitter followers, which he considered good banter. Ferguson also joked about considering a gymnastics career after finishing racing, given the somersaults during the fall.

The new Avengers: Age of Ultron movie was released this week. James Haskell, the London Wasps captain, showed his excitement by dressing up as Iron Man and posting the photo on Instagram. Haskell has had a successful rugby career, playing for various teams including Wasps, Stade Francais, Ricoh Black Rams, and Highlanders. He returned to Wasps in 2012 and has since surpassed the 100 appearances mark for the club.

The wide-leg trouser trend is gaining popularity, with various styles such as denim, cropped, printed, and striped. This trend is appealing due to its effortless look and offers an alternative to the skinny jean. The wide-leg trouser has made a comeback since the seventies, with designers like Gucci, Celine, and Stella McCartney showcasing this style on the runway. High-heeled shoes are recommended to complement the wide-leg trouser, as they elongate the leg. Pairing the trousers with a simple knit or shirt can keep the outfit proportionate and current. The wide-leg trouser is versatile and can be dressed up or down, making it a great addition to any wardrobe.

The University of Michigan decided to proceed with a screening of the film "American Sniper" despite objections from some students. More than 200 students signed a petition asking the school not to show the movie as part of UMix, a series of social events the university stages for students. Bradley Cooper was nominated for an Oscar for his portrayal of Chris Kyle, a Navy Seal and the most lethal sniper in U.S. military history. Kyle was fatally shot at a Texas shooting range in 2013. Some students believed the movie's depiction of the Iraq War reflected negatively on the Middle East and people from that region. Michigan's Detroit metropolitan area is home to the nation's largest Arab-American population. However, there was a backlash to the decision to cancel the movie, and a counter-petition asked school officials to reconsider. On Wednesday, E. Royster Harper, the University of Michigan's vice president for student life, said in a statement that it was a mistake to cancel the showing of the movie "American Sniper" on campus as part of a social event for students and that the show would go on. The initial decision to cancel the movie was not consistent with the high value the

Two French tourists allegedly set a quokka on fire on Rottnest Island, off Perth, Western Australia, on April 3. The quokka, a small marsupial the size of a domestic cat, survived but was singed by the flame. The men, aged 18 and 24, were charged with animal cruelty and evicted from the island. They will appear in court on April 17.

A 102-year-old dancer, Alice Barker, who performed in New York nightclubs during the 1930s and 1940s, had never seen herself dance until now. With the help of filmmakers, a video of her performances was created, and she was able to watch it at her nursing home. She was delighted with the experience.

The art of washing one's own car appears to be declining in Britain, with a third of men admitting they have never washed their own car. The study by vehicle leasing firm OSV found that 31% of men have never washed their own car, with only 12% of those who do saying they do it regularly. Factors behind the decline include shops now opening on Sundays and more live football on TV, meaning more people put off the chore at the weekend. The rise of hand car washes has also been blamed for the decrease in drivers washing their own cars.

Martin Skrtel has praised Steven Gerrard's impact on him since his arrival at Liverpool in 2008. Gerrard, the Reds captain, is set to feature in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa at Wembley on Sunday. If Liverpool wins, Gerrard will end his Anfield career in the final on his birthday, May 30, before moving to LA Galaxy. Skrtel believes Gerrard is still one of the best players in the world and has set a high standard during his time at Liverpool. Skrtel, who was signed by Rafael Benitez from Zenit St Petersburg seven years ago, has become a mainstay in Liverpool's defense. Skrtel revealed that Gerrard helped him settle at the club. Skrtel admits Liverpool will be a different side without Gerrard but believes they have potential replacements.

Jack Nicklaus, at 75, hit a hole-in-one at the par-3 contest at Augusta National during the Masters week. This marked his first ace on the course, though it was overshadowed by Camilo Villegas, who achieved two holes-in-one that day. Nicklaus, a six-time Masters champion, became the youngest to wear the green jacket in 1963 and won it again in 1986.

Several storms brought tornadoes to Kansas on Wednesday night, with a tornado reported about 6 miles northwest of Goddard, less than 17 miles west of Wichita. The storm moved northeast, missing Wichita but posing risks to other communities. Chad Myers, a CNN severe weather expert, warned that nighttime tornadoes are the most deadly and dangerous. Other tornado sightings were reported in southwestern Kansas, and a possible tornado touched down in Potosi, Missouri, about 70 miles from St. Louis. The storms also caused wind damage and flooding in Potosi, with one Instagram user posting a photo of a fallen tree and aerial footage showing damage to roofs and a street overtaken by water. In Leadington, a Twitter user reported seeing baseball-sized hail. More storms are expected in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes on Thursday.

Robert Bates, a reserve sheriff's deputy, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter in the shooting death of Eric Harris. Bates claims the shooting was accidental, as he meant to use a taser. The victim's family is upset that Bates is vacationing in the Bahamas during this time, feeling it shows a lack of remorse. Bates' lawyers claim the upcoming preliminary hearing will allow them to address the facts in court, rather than in the media. Bates' training records have been released by his lawyer, who claims they prove Bates had proper law enforcement training.

Conor McGregor, an Irish fighter, is set to challenge Jose Aldo for the featherweight title on July 11 in Las Vegas. Ahead of the fight, McGregor revealed a new tattoo of a tiger on his stomach, which he claims signifies that if you see the tiger, it's too late, and you're food. McGregor has a gorilla eating a heart tattooed on his chest. The pair have a fractious relationship, with McGregor grabbing Aldo's belt during a promotional tour in Dublin in front of 5,000 home supporters. McGregor claims he has greater motivation to win the title than Aldo has to defend it.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott skolled a beer at an Australian rules function, drawing criticism from anti-drinking campaigners who claim he is glorifying binge drinking and associating masculinity with heavy drinking. Cultural studies professor Julie Robert stated that it was problematic for the Prime Minister to showcase his masculinity in this way, as it sets up a culture that drinking is about how quickly and how much you can drink, rather than socializing with friends. Health Minister Sussan Ley defended Abbott, stating that there was nothing wrong with his actions and that he promotes fitness and health.

Indiana has experienced a significant increase in HIV cases, with 120 confirmed and 10 preliminary positive cases in Scott County, primarily among intravenous drug users using the painkiller Opana. The state's largest-ever HIV outbreak led to a temporary needle exchange program approved by Governor Mike Pence, which has provided 5,322 clean syringes and collected 1,400 used ones. The program's future is uncertain, as Pence opposes needle exchanges and money for the program has not been allocated. The program's success hinges on gaining the trust of intravenous drug users, and its fate is tied to upcoming legislative decisions and potential changes in policy.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former DEA informant, faces deportation after 27 years of service. He fears for his life if deported to Colombia due to his work with the DEA and the Medellin cartel. Toro's information led to the prosecution of cocaine overlord Carlos Lehder and former Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega. Despite promises of US citizenship, Toro remains in limbo, unable to collect social security benefits or secure a green card or passport. He is now technically living in the US illegally after declining health forced him to retire.

A 14-year-old girl in India set herself on fire after allegedly being gang-raped by five men from her village. She is now fighting for her life in Delhi's Safdarjung Hospital with 70% burns. The accused men have been arrested. This incident comes amid heightened sensitivity to sexual assault in India, following the ban of a documentary about the gang rape and murder of a student in Delhi. Recent attacks have led to street protests and calls for more protection for women.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal has revealed that he has been dreaming of beating rivals Manchester City in Sunday's derby at Old Trafford. However, he will have to do so without Robin van Persie, who has been ruled out due to injury. Van Gaal also ruled out a potential return for Luke Shaw, stating that neither player is fit enough to feature. Despite this, Van Gaal is looking forward to sampling the derby atmosphere at Old Trafford and is confident that his side can move towards their target of finishing as high as second or third in the table.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans left their seats empty at the Emirates Stadium for the first 10 minutes of their match to protest rising ticket prices. The protest was in response to the Premier League's £5.14 billion TV rights deal, with tickets starting at £64. Fans held banners inside and outside the stadium, expressing their frustration with the high costs. The organizers called the prices "extortionate" and emphasized the need for tangible reductions. Further protests were expected after the game.

A newborn baby named Star Reader was diagnosed with biliary atresia, a life-threatening liver condition, shortly after birth. Her parents, Jade Reader and Matthew Bygrave, were told that a liver transplant was necessary for her survival. Neither parent was a suitable match for the transplant, but her maternal aunt, Shanell Reader, offered to donate part of her liver. The transplant was successful, and Star has since made a good recovery. Shanell did not hesitate to donate part of her liver to save her niece.

Chelsea players Eden Hazard, Nathan Ake, Loic Remy, and Willian participated in Audi's football challenge. In the first round, Hazard and Ake won 5-3 by shooting balls into the boot of a car from close range. In the second round, they won 6-0 by playing over a makeshift tennis court net replaced by an Audi R8 V10 Plus. In the final round, Remy and Willian won by shooting at cars from long range. However, Willian accidentally smashed the wing mirror off one of the Audis with a long-range effort.

Robert Dellinger, a former Fortune 500 executive, was sentenced for causing a highway crash that killed a Vermont couple and their unborn baby. He pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and assault for the fetus's death. Dellinger's wife testified that he was not suicidal and had lived a life of ethics and integrity. Dellinger's defense claimed he was suffering from ambien withdrawal, a psychiatric drug overdose, and prozac, as well as advanced symptoms of multiple sclerosis. He faces 12 to 24 years in prison.

Lacey Spears, convicted of murdering her son by poisoning him with salt, was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison. Her ex-husband, Chris Hill, expressed his desire for her to be placed in general population, fearing for her safety. Spears' lack of emotion during the sentencing was noted, with the judge acknowledging her mental illness. Prosecutors argued that Spears made her son ill for attention, while her lawyer claimed negligence by the hospital and plans to appeal the verdict. Spears' social media posts about her son's medical issues were used as evidence in the trial.

The arrival of an improved influenza vaccine in Australia has been delayed by a month due to the inclusion of protection against two new strains, H3N2 and B/Phuket, which caused spikes in flu-related deaths in Europe and the United States. The vaccine, which also protects against H1N1, is expected to be a good match for the circulating strains and will be available for free to high-risk groups from April 20. Experts recommend that everyone get vaccinated to protect themselves and those around them.

3. Robert Downey Jr. became agitated during a Channel 4 interview about his private life.
4. The Kardashians sparked a new trend: lip plumping by sucking on a jar to resemble Kylie Jenner, now known as the #kyliejennerchallenge.

8. Johnny Depp appeared nearly unrecognizable in the 'Black Mass' trailer.

Serena Williams became the latest recipient of a giant celebration present after she clocked her 700th career victory at the Miami Open. The day following Andy Murray’s 500th win, another huge cake was wheeled out to mark Williams reaching the semi-final with a 7-6, 1-6, 6-3 progression over Germany’s Sabine Lisicki. Williams’s hopes of another meeting with sister Venus were dashed by her elder sibling’s defeat to Spain’s Carla Suarez Navarro, but the world No. 1 was intent on staying alive in what is the nearest thing she has to a hometown event. Williams will face Romania's Simona Halep for a place in the final after the third seed beat Sloane Stephens 6-1, 7-5.

Sabeen Mahmud, a Pakistani cafe owner, was shot dead by two gunmen after hosting a discussion on the topic of missing persons in Baluchistan. Known for her advocacy of free speech, human rights, and women's entrepreneurship, Mahmud was a figurehead for humanism, love, and tolerance in Pakistan. Despite receiving death threats in the past, Mahmud continued to speak out on controversial topics, such as the situation in Baluchistan, where she believed mainstream media and academia were silenced. Her cafe, T2F, was a hub for those seeking secular wisdom and freedom of thought, decorated with socially critical graffiti and a daring image of Marilyn Monroe. Mahmud's death has been met with grief and gratitude from those who knew her, with many expressing their condolences on social media and via email.

FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto is considering a move to Chelsea, who have made a £4 million offer for the player. Chelsea would loan Muto to Vitesse Arnhem next season, but Muto wants to join a club where he will play regularly and develop. Real Zaragoza boss Ranko Popovic, who gave Muto his debut, believes Muto could be a big hit at Chelsea due to his intelligence, speed, strength, and confidence. Chelsea's commercial interests, including a £200 million sponsorship deal with Japanese tyre manufacturer Yokohama Rubber, may also play a part in their transfer policy.

Australia has changed its policy to allow the selection of overseas players, recognizing the need to pick the best players regardless of their location. England is urged to follow suit, with Stuart Lancaster being allowed to select top players like Matt Giteau and Drew Mitchell, who excel in France. The policy change is seen as necessary for England to have the best chance of winning the World Cup, with players like Steffon Armitage and Nick Abendanon showing significant improvement since moving abroad. The argument emphasizes the importance of selecting the best team, regardless of players' locations, to avoid regrets and ensure England's success in the World Cup.

Open Garden's Firechat app enables off-the-grid messaging without web or mobile signals, leveraging iOS and Android's multipeer connectivity framework. The Greenstone device, an egg-shaped beacon, enhances these wireless mesh networks by extending message range and acting as a booster. Firechat, downloaded over five million times, allows secure, anonymous messaging within a 30-foot range. Greenstone, currently in development, extends this range to 20 feet with a one-year battery life, storing up to 1,000 messages. Open Garden plans to partner with manufacturers to produce and sell Greenstone, aiming to provide resilient communication in various scenarios, such as events or areas with poor connectivity.

Lillian Bustle, a burlesque performer from New Jersey, is on a mission to eradicate negativity surrounding the word "fat" by embracing it as a body-positive description of her physique. In her TED talk, she highlighted that words like "fat," "short," and "wife" are simply honest descriptions of who she is. She emphasized that "fat" should not be synonymous with "ugly" and shared that size discrimination in the workplace has risen by 66% in the past 30 years. Lillian also mentioned that the more people are exposed to body diversity, the more they tolerate, accept, and even prefer different body types. She hopes her burlesque performances, which showcase a "fat" body in a positive and glamorous light, will change people's perceptions. Lillian also shared that the experience of performing burlesque has been empowering and incredibly body-positive for her. Despite a few negative comments, the response to her TED talk has been mostly positive, with many viewers sending her letters of thanks and personal stories.

Theo Walcott, along with six Arsenal teammates, has been featured in a photoshoot for Lanvin, Arsenal's official tailor since 2013. The photoshoot, which also included a runway model, took place with the players sitting on a bench. Walcott has spent much of the season on the bench, being named as a substitute for 17 of Arsenal's 33 Barclays Premier League games. He came on as a substitute in the last six minutes of Arsenal's 0-0 draw with Chelsea on Sunday.

An auction of props and puppets created by legendary make-up effects artist Rick Baker will take place on May 29 at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles, California, and on propstore.com. The collection, valued at an estimated $746,100, includes items from more than 50 productions, such as Men in Black, Batman Forever, and How the Grinch Stole Christmas. Notable items include the alien Edgar bug from Men in Black, valued at $40,000, and the Grinch costume from How the Grinch Stole Christmas, valued at $8,000. The auction presents a unique opportunity for collectors and fans to own a piece of Hollywood history.

A seven-year-old British boy, Carwyn Scott-Howell, died in the French Alps after falling over a 164ft drop while skiing with his family. Carwyn, described as daring, outgoing, and determined, became separated from his mother and headed into dense woodland. His mother, Ceri, desperately searched for him, but Carwyn's body was eventually found by police following footprints in the snow. Carwyn, who was a very competent skier and snowboarder, was said to have modeled himself on TV adventurer Bear Grylls. The family had been enjoying their last run of the day when Carwyn pressed on ahead, and his mother and sister continued to the bottom of the piste. Carwyn's family described him as an adorable, caring person who gave so much love and made life full of laughter. The community in Wales has rallied behind the Scott-Howells, with friends writing in a condolence book and pupils at Carwyn's school expressing their devastation.

Marco Rubio, a presidential candidate, has stated that people are born with a sexual preference but believes that the definition of marriage should be between one man and one woman. He does not believe same-sex marriage is a constitutional right and that state legislatures should decide on the issue. Rubio has also said that he would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer, even if he did not agree with their decision, as he cares for them. He has also noted that, as a Catholic, he believes divorce is wrong but would not stop loving someone if they were divorced. Rubio has announced his candidacy for president and has already received monetary commitments exceeding the $51 million he will likely need for the presidential primary season.

A Texas couple who celebrated their wedding in 2012 is suing Premiere Photos for allegedly printing a racial slur on the bottom of their photo booth snapshots. The couple, who wishes to remain anonymous, hired attorney Cathy Hale to represent them in their lawsuit against Premiere Photos and its owner, James Evans. The couple claims that the photo booth printed "poor n*gger party" on the bottom of the pictures, which they only discovered many months after the event when the bride's sister informed them. Evans has denied all allegations and claims that there is no evidence linking the company to the offensive caption. The couple is seeking an apology from Evans and claims that their lawsuit is not about money.

England full-back Mike Brown is unsure when he will return to action after suffering a concussion. He is taking a cautious approach to recovery, following advice from leading medics and increased awareness of the symptoms of concussion. Brown emphasizes the importance of honesty and not rushing back to action, as well as the dangers of long and short-term concussion effects. He is determined not to suffer an extended break and will not push through the pain.

The frequency of sexual activity among British couples has been declining since the emergence of the internet, with a typical heterosexual couple now having sex three times a month, compared to five times a month in 1990 and four times a month in 2000. Professor David Spiegelhalter, a statistician at Cambridge University, suggests that the decline may be due to the erosion of boundaries between home, work, and the outside world, as well as an increasing number of competing demands on people's time. He also quotes Catherine Mercer, a researcher on the British National Survey, who suggests that sex is falling down the list of priorities for many people.

Tibetan mastiffs, once valued up to £1.2 million, are now being sent to slaughterhouses in China due to a decline in popularity. This decline is attributed to the Chinese government's anti-corruption crackdown, which discouraged the giving of mastiffs as gifts to officials. Additionally, recent bans on owning dogs over 50 kg in several Chinese cities have further impacted the breed's popularity. Animal welfare workers recently rescued 20 mastiffs en route to a slaughterhouse, where they were found in cramped, inhumane conditions. The dogs' meat is used in cheap hotpots, and their skin for leather belts. Unscrupulous breeders and gangs stealing mastiffs from the streets also contribute to the dogs' plight.

The survey of 600 women in Paris revealed that every woman had experienced some form of sexual harassment on public transport, with half of them experiencing this before the age of 18. The harassment ranged from insults to sex attacks or rape. This has led to six out of ten women being afraid of being attacked on public transport, compared to three out of ten men. The report called for a campaign to stem sexist or threatening behavior on buses and trains, as women must be able to move about and occupy public spaces without being placed in danger or threatened.

Direct Line, a company based in Leeds, ran a competition called #everydayfix, asking groups to design products to solve common problems. Three products were shortlisted: Snooze, an alarm clock that silences phone notifications; Forget Me Lock, a device that reassures users their door is locked; and Nipper, a mobile phone charger that uses household batteries. The product with the most retweets by April 4th will go into a Kickstarter campaign and be developed. The competition aimed to address common daily emergencies, such as not being able to sleep, forgetting keys, and running out of phone battery.

Vera Baird, the police and crime commissioner for Northumbria, is under investigation for allocating over £500,000 of public funds to a charity, Victims First Northumbria, where she serves as a director. The charity's chair, Sue Sim, is the Northumbria chief constable, and both are facing a Ministry of Justice probe for a potential conflict of interest. Critics, including Labour chairman Keith Vaz, have called the arrangement inappropriate. Baird and Sim deny any wrongdoing, with Baird stating that all procedures were followed. Sim is set to retire in June, amid previous allegations of bullying staff.

Three people have been sentenced to prison, and two others are awaiting sentencing for their roles in a brutal assault on a 53-year-old man. The victim, Greg Valecce, was beaten, tied to a chair, and subjected to offensive tattoos by a gang known as the "tattoo terrorists." The ringleader, Corry "Corey" Campbell, 21, believed Valecce had harmed his cat and was sentenced to 20 years in prison. Valecce, an unemployed drug addict, was tortured for three days in Campbell's mother's basement in Mayfair, Philadelphia. The incident, which lasted 42 hours, resulted in Valecce suffering three busted ribs, two broken wrists, and fractured bones in his face. Valecce has since had the tattoos removed but says the incident has left him with irrevocable damage.

Professor David Spiegelhalter, a statistician at Cambridge University, suggests that the decline may be due to the erosion of boundaries between home, work, and the outside world, as well as an increasing number of competing demands on people's time. Catherine Mercer, a researcher on the British National Survey, adds that dealing with work emails late in the evening can leave people too connected to focus on their partner at bedtime.

Animal welfare workers recently rescued 20 mastiffs en route to a slaughterhouse, where they were found in cramped, inhumane conditions. Paul Merson and Andros Townsend have been involved in a public disagreement, with Merson initially criticizing Townsend's inclusion in the England squad. However, after Townsend scored a goal for England against Italy, Merson admitted his mistake and expressed his happiness for Townsend. Despite this, Merson continued to criticize Townsend, this time for his performance in Tottenham's 0-0 draw with Burnley.

Chelsea have made a formal offer to FC Tokyo for 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto. If the move is completed, Muto will join Chelsea's Dutch partner club Vitesse Arnhem on loan next season. The offer is not connected to Chelsea's recent £200 million sponsorship deal with Japanese company Yokohama Rubber. Muto, who graduated from Keio University with an economics degree two weeks ago, would be the first Japanese player to represent Chelsea. A £4 million deal has been mooted for the player, who scored 13 times in his debut season with FC Tokyo and was named in the J-League's best XI. Muto has scored three goals in four games so far this season.

The study found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be fat as toddlers. The researchers suggested that antibiotics may be contributing to the obesity epidemic, just as they are used to make farm animals put on weight. The study compared the weight and height of more than 12,000 healthy two-year-olds with records on antibiotic prescription. Children who had taken antibiotics as young babies were particularly likely to be overweight. Repeated prescriptions before the age of two also raised the odds of being a fat toddler. Boys seemed particularly prone to weight gain after being given antibiotics. The study didn't prove that antibiotics were causing weight gain, but if they do, it may be because they kill off bugs in the gut that would normally feed on some of the food eaten.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard, an incident captured on camera by a tourist. The soldier, embarrassed by the fall, quickly got to his feet and continued his duties. The fall was caused by the metal protectors on the soles of his boots.

A&E networks are remaking the 1977 miniseries "Roots," which had over 100 million viewers. The new version will air in 2016 and will be a simulcast on A&E, Lifetime, and History. LeVar Burton, who played Kunta Kinte in the original, will co-executive produce the new miniseries. The remake will draw more from Alex Haley's novel and consult scholars in African and African-American history for added authenticity. The new version aims to reach a new generation of viewers and will reflect current racial issues in the U.S.

A former royal footman, Christopher Lawler, claimed that palace aides tried to force him into an orgy on his first day working at Clarence House in January 1978. He reported the incident but was ignored for months before the police were finally notified. The police are now investigating the claims, which involve an alleged attempted abuse by two men, one a senior member of staff, who tried to undress him and perform a sex act on him. Lawler, now 64, said he was haunted by the incident for years and was recently told by the Palace that they would work cooperatively with any police probe.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced their pregnancy in a rap video set to the theme song from '90s television sitcom 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air.' The video, featuring the couple rapping in a car, has been viewed over 1.7 million times on YouTube. The Meeks made the video so loved ones living far away could know about the baby. The original song, sung by star Will Smith, details how his character grew up in West Philadelphia and moved to his aunt and uncle's home in their wealthy Los Angeles neighborhood. In the Meeks' parody video, Melissa raps about how friends and family pressured them to have children, and Jesse raps about how they thought it would take longer than the two months they spent trying to conceive. The couple told KPTV it took five takes to film the clip. After finding out the gender of the child, another video is a possibility for the Meeks, the couple told the Fox affiliate.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh in the 1939 film Gone With the Wind sold for $137,000 at auction. The dress, which has faded from its original slate blue-gray color, was part of a private collection amassed by James Tumblin, who began collecting memorabilia in the 1960s. The auction also featured other notable items from the film, including a straw hat worn by Leigh, which sold for $52,500, and trousers and a jacket from a suit worn by Clark Gable, which sold for $55,000.

A two-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his parents dangled him over the edge. The boy was rescued by his parents and taken to the hospital with minor injuries. The incident occurred around 3 pm on Saturday, and the boy is currently in stable condition. The parents are facing child endangerment charges, and the exhibit has been closed.

A speed camera in Handsworth, Birmingham, has been turned to face a house, despite not working for two years. Around 300 speed and traffic cameras in the West Midlands were turned off in March 2013 due to obsolete technology. The city council is aware of the camera and plans to take appropriate action, but the camera will not be included in a new pilot scheme using digital technology.

Usain Bolt will compete in the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas next month as part of the Jamaican team. He expressed his excitement about the event and his readiness to run. The Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association (JAAA) expressed their pleasure in having Bolt on the team and anticipated some sprint magic on the track. The full team list will be announced shortly.

Neymar and Dani Alves, teammates at Barcelona, attended a Euro League basketball match between Barcelona and Real Madrid, which Barcelona won 85-80. Despite the victory, Real Madrid still leads the division. Neymar also helped Brazil defeat Chile 1-0 in a recent match.

Italy is experiencing a surge in migrants from Africa and the Middle East seeking to reach Europe. Over the weekend, 8,480 migrants were rescued, with 20 boats in distress on Monday alone. Save the Children fears 400 migrants are missing after a ship carrying 550 capsized off the Libyan coast, though the Italian coast guard has not confirmed this incident. The International Organization for Migration reports that over 10,000 migrants arrived in Italy in the first quarter of 2015, with about 2,000 rescued at sea in early April. Since the year's start, at least 480 migrants have died due to bad weather and overcrowded vessels used by smugglers.

Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger is pleased that Alexis Sanchez chose to join Arsenal over Liverpool, despite Liverpool's potential interest in Sanchez being used as leverage in negotiations for Luis Suarez. Sanchez, who was courted by several elite clubs, has made an instant impact at Arsenal, scoring 19 goals so far this season. Wenger believes Sanchez's quick adaptation to a new environment proves he is one of the best players around. Wenger also played down speculation linking him with a move for Liverpool's Raheem Sterling.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt to break the UCI Hour Record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome. The event will take place at the Lee Valley VeloPark, with tickets going on sale on April 19. Wiggins, who finished his Team Sky career at the Paris-Roubaix, will ride in the Tour de Yorkshire before preparing for the Hour. The current Hour record is 52.491km, set by Australian Rohan Dennis in February. Wiggins, who has four gold, one silver, and two bronze Olympic medals, is expected to set a mark that will last for some time. The event will be broadcast live on Sky Sports.

Serena Williams, the world No. 1 tennis player, struggled to beat Sara Errani in the Fed Cup, winning 4-6, 7-6(3), 6-3. Williams expressed that the match was an eye-opener, realizing she was not as prepared for the clay court season as she thought. The US team, including Williams and Alison Riske, lost 3-2 to Italy, resulting in their relegation to World Group II. Williams acknowledged that she needs to adjust her playing style for clay courts, as she was playing as if it were a hard court.

River Plate is interested in signing Manchester United striker Radamel Falcao, who spent eight years with the Argentine side before leaving for Porto in 2009. Vice president Matias Patanian stated that the club "dreams of Falcao" and that "the doors are open" for his return. Falcao has struggled during his loan spell at Manchester United, scoring only four Premier League goals. However, he has been in good form for Colombia, scoring three goals in two games and equaling Colombia's all-time goalscoring record with 24 goals. Falcao joined River Plate at the age of 15 in 2001 and scored 34 goals in 90 appearances during his four seasons in the first team.

Ella Henderson, the X Factor finalist and pop star, has become the face of Batiste's 2015 'Ready For It' campaign, marking her first brand collaboration. The campaign features Henderson with various hairstyles, including glossy, wavy hair and a tousled half-ponytail. The partnership between Henderson and Batiste, facilitated by the MILES agency, launched with a TV advertising campaign featuring Henderson's latest single, Mirror Man. Henderson has expressed her excitement about working with Batiste, a brand she uses regularly. Mark Hargreaves, CEO of Crown Talent & Media Group, which manages Henderson, has commented on the natural synergy between the artist and the brand, expressing excitement for the collaboration in 2015.

A billboard featuring the officer who fatally shot Aaron Siler, Pablo Torres, was erected in Kenosha, Wisconsin, by the Kenosha Professional Police Association. The billboard was intended to thank the community for its support, but Siler's family and friends found it disrespectful and are asking for it to be taken down. The shooting occurred after Siler, who was wanted on an active felony probation and parole warrant, armed himself with a weapon following a confrontation with Torres. The incident came just 10 days after Torres shot a 66-year-old man, Terry Knight, who was armed with two knives. The investigation into Siler's death continues, while the investigation into the shooting of Knight was deemed justified.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the border with Pakistan. Three militants were killed by Iranian forces in the fighting in the southeastern town of Negur. The militants crossed into Iran from Pakistan, according to Iranian officials. A militant group called Jaish al Adal claimed responsibility for the attack. Iranian authorities have asked Pakistani authorities to catch the surviving assailants. Jaish al Adal is an anti-Iranian group that has emerged in recent years in areas of Balochistan, the restive Pakistani province that borders southeastern Iran. The Sunni Muslim group has targeted Shiites and says it aims to thwart Iranian influence in Pakistan. Iranian authorities say that after similar attacks, the militants have fled back into Balochistan. The Pakistani government condemned Monday's attack, calling it an "act of terrorism." If the militants entered Pakistan after the attack, "they will be apprehended and brought to justice," the Pakistani government said.

Japan's Defense Minister Gen Nakatani revealed that the country's Air Self Defense Force (ASDF) has never encountered an extraterrestrial unidentified flying object. This revelation was made in response to a query from former wrestler-turned-lawmaker Antonio Inoki during a Upper House Budget Committee meeting. Nakatani stated that while the ASDF scrambles fighter jets to visually observe any detected unidentified flying objects, they have never found any believed to have come from other than Earth. Inoki, who is known for his political achievements and maverick nature, had previously asked if aircraft were scrambled to meet extraterrestrial threats and if research was being done into alien visitors.

A passenger, Jin Pai, was hospitalized with deep cuts on his leg and buttocks after the toilet he was squatting on in Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in Hefei, China, broke and cut him in several places. He had not wanted to let his bottom touch the seat due to cleanliness concerns. The injured man was found bleeding on the toilet floor after calling his traveling companions for help. He was too embarrassed to shout for help and hoped his companions would assist him, but he was too badly hurt for anything other than an immediate trip to the hospital. Authorities and emergency personnel arrived to check him into a Hefei hospital, where he received several dozen stitches on his left leg and buttocks. The authorities believed the incident was an accident.

A Pennsylvania man, Kevin Rebbie, 56, of Limerick Township, was arrested for allegedly sexually abusing a girl in her home over a four-year period and filming her and others with a hidden camera in a bathroom. Rebbie faces several charges, including aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy. The investigation began when the now-15-year-old girl found a hidden camera under the sink in her bathroom. Investigators found 41 videos from the hidden camera, 34 of which showed victims showering. Rebbie admitted to filming several victims, including other juveniles, and had purchased the camera specifically to record the now-15-year-old victim while she undressed and showered. Rebbie's preliminary hearing is on May 1, and he is being held on a $500,000 bail.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama has created a series of images for his latest book, "Daughter and Salary Man," featuring fathers leaping into the air next to their daughters. The daughters stand po-faced while their fathers pull dramatic poses, with some of the older fathers looking pained. The fathers are dressed in sharp suits, while the daughters wear casual clothing. The images are taken in front of various Japanese landmarks. The photographs are drumming up plenty of interest online.

Paul Downton was dismissed as England's managing director, which may allow Kevin Pietersen to return to the international set-up. Pietersen, who last played for England during a disastrous Ashes tour in Australia, has rejoined Surrey to try to force his way back into the Test team. He was in a jovial mood at the Surrey team photo shoot, joking with teammates and photographers, but also took a moment to reflect.

Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, a Romanian club facing relegation, sacked Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week. Despite being reinstated after a previous firing, Ze Maria was fired again following a loss to FC Botosani. Ze Maria, a former Brazil defender with 25 caps, had replaced Florin Marin in January as the club's third coach of the season. He will be replaced by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

Radamel Falcao's former Monaco team-mate Nabil Dirar believes that the Colombian must be regretting his failed loan move to Manchester United, despite not being happy in France. Dirar thinks that Falcao would have been better off staying at Monaco, where he would have played and participated in the Champions League. United will have to pay £46million to make Falcao's transfer permanent, but having only scored four goals all season, it is unlikely that they will take up that option.

A man wearing a distinctive cartoon mask robbed a Christchurch dairy on Saturday, making off with the till and approximately $1500 in cash. The offender was described as very tall and was wearing a fluoro orange sweatshirt and an oversized mask. Police were called to the Union St dairy in east Christchurch at about 12.30pm after receiving reports of a masked man demanding cash from the owner's daughter. The man threw the cash register to the ground and fled. Police are appealing to the public for information that may help identify the offender.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested for having sex with a 15-year-old student in her car on two consecutive nights in January. This arrest came a month after she was first arrested for having an inappropriate relationship with another 15-year-old student. Granado was initially arrested for allowing a student to touch her breasts and was released on bail. She was suspended from teaching and put on administrative leave. After her initial arrest, Granado admitted to kissing a student and allowing him to touch her breasts. She was arrested again on Monday and released after posting a $50,000 bail.

A video of a crocodile swimming through a marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead dog in its jaws has been viewed over half a million times. The dog belonged to the owner of a local bike shop. The crocodile, which can grow up to 6 meters in length, is a common sight in the area due to urbanization and the presence of a nearby sanctuary. The incident occurred when the dog curiously approached the water's edge. Social media users have expressed horror and disdain for the crocodiles, despite their commonality in the area.

Steve Bruce, manager of Hull City, is confident that the team can avoid relegation from the Premier League despite a recent 2-0 defeat by Southampton. Bruce had initially targeted 10 wins for survival but now believes that 9 or 8 wins might be sufficient. Despite a strong start to the campaign, Hull has only managed to secure 6 wins so far. The team has been plagued by long-term injuries to key players, which Bruce believes has contributed to their struggles. Despite the challenges, Bruce remains optimistic and believes that the team can still avoid relegation.

A teacher, Ian Guffick, was banned from the classroom after allowing pupils to change their exam answers, invalidating the SATs results for Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire. Guffick altered some answers himself before the papers were submitted. The Department for Education annulled the entire school's SATs results following an investigation by the local education authority. Guffick admitted to the allegations and accepted that his actions amounted to unacceptable professional conduct. Despite this, the panel noted that his conduct did not amount to fraud or serious dishonesty, and he showed remorse and insight.

Anders Lindegaard, a Danish goalkeeper for Manchester United, has struggled to secure playing time in the Premier League since his 2010 move from Aalesunds. Despite this, he married Swedish model Misse Beqiri in a romantic beach wedding in Mauritius last year, and they have a son together. Lindegaard, who has over 17,000 Instagram followers, recently posted a picture of himself enjoying a day off with his wife, reminding fans of their marriage.

The 13 letters that once hung over Yankee Stadium failed to sell at a Sotheby's auction, despite being expected to fetch between $300,000 and $600,000. The letters, purchased by Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson after the stadium's final game in 2008, were estimated to be worth $300,000 to $600,000. However, the only bid came from a Sotheby's employee for $260,000. In contrast, a New York Mets bullpen car from the late 60s sold for $112,500, exceeding its estimated value of $20,000 to $30,000.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers has reminded Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe about their professional responsibilities after they were pictured inhaling nitrous oxide and smoking shisha pipes. Despite the incident, Rodgers has not disciplined the players and wants to move on from the matter. Rodgers also spoke about the return of captain Steven Gerrard, who is available for selection after serving a three-match suspension.

Arsenal playmaker Mesut Ozil enjoyed his home comforts after returning to London from the international break, posting a picture of himself relaxing with his dog. Ozil was in fine form as Germany beat Georgia 2-0 in a Euro 2016 qualifier on Sunday. He missed Arsenal's last game against Newcastle through illness but is expected to start against Liverpool at the Emirates Stadium. Ozil has been in fine form since returning from injury, racking up four assists and scoring three goals since January. He claims he is finally adjusting to English football and prefers playing in many matches.

Barcelona club president Josep Maria Bartomeu has insisted that the club has no plans to replace Luis Enrique, who has impressed during his tenure. Bartomeu says the club is 'very happy' with Enrique, who has a contract until 2016. Enrique only took charge at the club last summer and is six games away from winning the title.

Liverpool midfielder Jordan Henderson has agreed to a new long-term contract, extending his stay at Anfield until 2020. The deal is worth around £100,000 per week and will see him potentially replace Steven Gerrard as club captain. Henderson, who has been one of the most improved players under Brendan Rodgers, has contributed 13 assists and seven goals from midfield this season. The England international's new contract follows extensions for Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho, as Liverpool looks to secure the futures of key players.

Filipe Luis wants to stay at Chelsea until the end of his contract, despite interest from Atletico Madrid. He has struggled to secure the left back position at Chelsea. Luis is focused on the Premier League title run-in and says that manager Jose Mourinho always asks for the team to be focused and concentrated on winning every game.

Nathan Hughes's three-match ban for accidentally knocking out George North was overturned on appeal. Hughes, a Wasps No 8, was initially suspended for three matches after a disciplinary panel ruled he had been reckless in colliding with North's head while scoring a try. The ban was overturned after an appeal by Wasps, with the appeal panel concluding that no act of foul play took place as the incident was accidental. Hughes missed his side's Champions Cup quarter-final loss against Toulon last Sunday and is now free to return to action immediately.

A series of wildfires in southeastern Siberia, started by farmers burning grass in their fields, quickly grew out of control due to strong winds on April 14, destroying dozens of villages in the region. The lingering smoke from these fires was picked up by atmospheric winds and carried across the Pacific Ocean to the Pacific Northwest, resulting in dramatic sunsets in Washington, Oregon, and British Columbia. The intense red color of the sunsets is caused by smoke particles filtering out shorter wavelength colors from the sunlight, with the colors appearing especially vibrant during sunrise and sunset due to the longer path light must travel through the atmosphere. As the smoke begins to dissipate, air quality will improve and the reddish hue of the sunsets will fade.

A Missouri mom, Becky Schoenig, had her brand new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway. The car was returned to her a month later, but not without some changes. The thieves had spray-painted the rims red, added red detailing to the sides, and put orange accents on the steering wheel. Instead of getting upset, Schoenig took to Facebook to thank the thieves for "pimping out" her car. She also plans to honor the man who found her car by creating a smoothie named after him at her restaurant.

Manchester City players have incentivized contracts to stay within financial fair play rules, with around £12 million in bonuses at stake if they qualify for the Champions League. Failure to do so would result in a £500,000-a-man loss in bonuses for star players like Sergio Aguero, David Silva, Joe Hart, and Yaya Toure. The team is currently in fourth place, but a defeat in the Manchester derby and potential victory for Liverpool could narrow the gap to just four points. City manager Manuel Pellegrini has admitted the team's season has disintegrated, with early exits in the FA Cup and Champions League contributing to their struggles.

The Manchester United Under 18 team defeated Manchester City 1-0 in a match that took place at Altrincham's Moss Lane stadium. The game was free to attend, and close to 1,000 people attended. The match was part of the Barclays Under 18s Premier League end-of-season play-off series. The winning goal was scored by Callum Gribbin, who is an England Under 17 star. The match was noted for its high level of skill and commitment, with both teams showcasing promising young talent.

England goalkeeper Joe Hart praised Italian veteran Gianluigi Buffon as a 'legend of the game' after Buffon earned his 147th cap. Hart, who earned his 50th cap for England in the same match, expressed admiration for Buffon's longevity and skill at 37 years old. Hart also spoke about his pride in reaching the 50-cap milestone and his desire to continue adding to his international appearances.

Chipotle has partnered with Postmates to offer delivery services in 67 cities, marking its entry into the $70 billion food delivery market. The service will include a 9% service charge and delivery fees starting at $5, depending on distance and demand. This move comes after Chipotle reportedly declined previous collaboration offers with third-party delivery services. The company has been expanding its presence, with presidential candidates like Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton recently spotted at Chipotle outlets.

The parents of the youngest victim of the Boston Marathon bombings are pleading to take the death penalty off the table for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who was found guilty on all 30 charges related to the bombings. They argue that the continued pursuit of the death penalty could bring years of appeals and prolong their pain. They believe it is time to turn the page, end the anguish, and look toward a better future for themselves, Boston, and the country.

A mystery billionaire has converted a Boeing 747 into a luxury home, costing £400 million and taking three years to customize. The plane, which can normally carry 600 passengers, has been adapted for a single owner but can still accommodate dozens of guests. It features a large dining room, a kitchen, a lounge, a state room, and an 'aeroloft' with eight full beds on the top deck. The master bedroom includes a huge bed, an armchair, and a sofa. The plane also has a conference room, a lounge resembling a luxury hotel, an office or guest bedroom, and a dining room attached to a kitchen for a private chef.

SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying an uncrewed Dragon cargo spacecraft from Cape Canaveral, Florida, to the International Space Station. The launch was successful, but SpaceX was unsuccessful in its attempt to land a rocket stage on a floating barge for the first time. SpaceX founder Elon Musk tweeted that the rocket landed on the droneship but was too hard for survival. SpaceX has said it will keep trying and, after it masters landing at sea, hopes to someday land rockets on the ground. Usually booster rockets burn up in Earth's atmosphere or, like NASA's space shuttle boosters, they fall back into the ocean. SpaceX has said it will keep trying and, after it masters landing at sea, hopes to someday land rockets on the ground. The smaller, top part of the rocket will carry the Dragon into orbit and then break away from the cargo ship and burn up in Earth's atmosphere. The Dragon will dock with the space station a couple of days after launch to deliver more than 4,300 pounds (1,950 kilograms) of supplies, including research equipment and ISSpresso, an espresso maker that astronauts can use to make coffee and tea. The space station

Priscilla Presley will witness the first wedding at the new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas. The contest for the wedding is a collaboration with NBC's Today show, with the winning couple announced next Monday. The prize includes a free wedding reception, hotel suite for two nights, airfares, and concert tickets. Priscilla Presley emphasized that the wedding chapel is not a joke and will be first-class. The chapel is part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit of Elvis artifacts outside his Memphis home. Couples must submit a video or photos and an explanation of why they deserve the prize.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his side can catch Manchester City in the Premier League after a tough season and a recent win against Newcastle United. Liverpool and Manchester City are currently separated by four points, with City in the lead. Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet both equaled the record for most appearances in the top five European leagues this season. Liverpool won 2-0, with goals from Raheem Sterling and Joe Allen.

Roma ended their four-month winless streak at home with a victory over Napoli in Serie A, which is crucial for Champions League places. Miralem Pjanic scored the first goal for Roma in the 25th minute after a swift counter-attack. Napoli had several chances in the second half, but Roma's goalkeeper, Morgan de Sanctis, made crucial saves to protect the lead. The win moved Roma four points ahead of city rivals Lazio, who played later that day. Napoli's winless streak was extended to five matches, and they remained in fifth place. Security was tight for the match due to a previous incident involving a Napoli fan.

Doncaster Rovers had an uninspired season in League One, with a goalless draw against Fleetwood Town being a highlight of their season. The match highlights video was only 27 seconds long, with only 14 seconds of actual match action.

A man, Roland Giroux, has a unique and close relationship with his blood parrot cichlid fish, which involves him regularly interacting with it by dipping his hand in the fish tank to stroke and massage the fish. The fish responds positively to this interaction, swimming away and then returning for more strokes. This behavior is observed daily, with the fish becoming more sociable and even showing signs of frustration if not played with daily. The fish, a hybrid of the midas and redhead cichlid, first bred in Taiwan around 1986, used to share its tank with two other fish, which were removed due to bullying. The man spends at least 15 minutes daily playing with his fish.

Ben Stokes, a fiery character in the England cricket team, has returned to the team after breaking his wrist punching a locker last year. Stokes has a reputation for being aggressive, which he must channel in the right way. He has been advised to control his aggression while maintaining his character. Stokes is an exciting prospect for England, and they want to help him reach his full potential.

Wales' Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium at the Cardiff City Stadium has sold out, with both teams tied at the top of Group B with 11 points. Wales' recent 3-0 victory over Israel has increased expectations of qualifying for the tournament in France. The Welsh squad prefers playing at the more intimate Cardiff City Stadium, where they have not played since 2011.

England coach John Peacock has named his squad for the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria, where they are the defending champions. The squad includes players from various Premier League clubs, such as Chelsea's Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo, and Arsenal's Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi. The team will face Italy, Holland, and the Republic of Ireland in the group stage.

Manchester City is interested in signing 14-year-old Anderlecht playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis, who is considered one of the best talents from Anderlecht's youth system. Patoulidis has also attracted interest from Arsenal and Barcelona but rejected a move to Barcelona's La Masia academy at age 12 to continue his studies. City has discussed a compensation package with Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock. Manager Manuel Pellegrini aims to build for the future by signing Patoulidis.

A 33-year-old transgender escort, Vanessa Santillan, was found dead in a Fulham flat, having been strangled and beaten. A 23-year-old man was arrested in connection with her death and bailed. Scotland Yard is appealing for information from anyone who had contact with her in the hours before her death. The police are investigating all possible motives, including her profession as an escort.

A woman named Dawn, who had seven miscarriages, accused her friend Jamie of stealing money set aside for her baby's grave stone. A lie detector test confirmed Jamie's guilt, causing Dawn to break down on The Jeremy Kyle Show. Jamie had previously denied taking the money, but the test revealed the truth.
