Dawn was devastated, as the money was intended for a headstone for her baby Daniel James, and she felt betrayed by someone she trusted.

ISIS released more than 200 Yazidis, a minority group that was killed, captured, and displaced when the Islamist terror organization overtook their towns in northern Iraq last summer. Most of those released were women and children, while the rest were ill or elderly. The freed Yazidis were received by Peshmerga and sent to the Kurdish regional capital, Irbil. The reason for the release is unclear, with one official asserting that Arab tribal leaders helped coordinate it, while another official did not provide a reason. Since attacking the Yazidis' towns last year, ISIS has previously released scores of other Yazidis, largely children and the elderly.

Harry Kane, a young Tottenham and England striker, is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Season awards. A video produced by Copa90, titled 'Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?', features some of Kane's best goals and celebrations from the season, using still photographs to create an animated effect. The video showcases his long-range strike against Chelsea, a headed goal against Arsenal, and his goal on his England debut.

Jamie Carragher supports Brendan Rodgers as the right leader for Liverpool despite a trophyless season and likely failure to finish in the top four. Carragher emphasizes the importance of proper signings for the team's future success and expresses hope that his community work can inspire and support young people in deprived areas of Merseyside.

A four-year-old boy, James Hayward, had his toy gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport. The toy, a brightly colored plastic Nerf gun that fires sponge darts, was packed in his hand luggage for a flight to Lanzarote. Security officers, described as 'over-zealous' by the boy's father, took exception to the toy, deeming it a security risk. They confiscated the toy and performed a thorough pat-down and inspection of the child. The boy's father, Phil Hayward, criticized the security checks as 'ludicrous' and 'over-zealous.' After returning from their holiday, the family bought a replacement toy gun for the boy. East Midlands Airport apologized for the inconvenience but defended their decision, stating that all security regulations are set by the government and that no items resembling prohibited items may be permitted through security.

A 31-year-old man named Rich from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, posted an advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife. The advertisement detailed his requirements for a partner, including being fit, attractive, non-drinker and non-smoker, reliable, honest, loyal, good around the house, a good cook, and great in bed. Rich described himself as athletic, white, heavily tattooed, brown hair and eyes, non-drinker, non-smoker, non-drug user, who enjoys traveling, the outdoors, sports, fishing, and camping. He also mentioned that he owns his own properties, makes great money, is successful, and loves cars and bikes. Rich stated that he is not shy of spending money on his woman and that his potential partner would receive lots of benefits. He also mentioned that former partners need not apply and that all reasonable offers will be considered. Daily Mail Australia unsuccessfully attempted to contact Rich.

The Football Association chairman Greg Dyke is seeking to implement significant changes to increase the number of home-grown players in club squads, raising the minimum from eight to 12. Dyke is facing opposition from the Premier League on these proposals. Five former England managers, Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren, have shown their support for Dyke's plans in a letter to the Daily Telegraph. They argue that failure to support these changes could hinder England's chances of success in international football. The letter highlights the decreasing number of English players in top-level football, which they believe is a disadvantage for England managers. They also point to the success of young English players like Harry Kane, Ross Barkley, Raheem Sterling, and others as evidence that England can still produce top talent. However, they argue that these players need more opportunities to develop and succeed.

The article discusses the rapid progression of a character's pregnancy in a TV show, highlighting the unrealistic timeline and the audience's reaction to it. It mentions the character's quick transition from announcing the pregnancy to giving birth, which has been a topic of discussion among fans. The article also references a similar situation with another character's pregnancy in the same show, indicating a pattern.

Leicester City manager Nigel Pearson has urged his team to focus on their own performance and not be distracted by their relegation rivals. Despite being bottom of the Premier League, Leicester has won their last two games, including an injury-time winner against West Brom, which has given them a realistic chance of survival. Pearson emphasized the importance of maintaining focus and not getting carried away with other teams' results.

Varvara, a North Pacific gray whale, has set a new record for the longest migration of a mammal, swimming nearly 14,000 miles from Russia's Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico. This journey has led scientists to question the classification of western gray whales, as Varvara's travels suggest she may be an eastern gray whale, potentially reducing the number of western gray whales to around 150.

A 1,000ft stretch of seabed along the coast of Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu on Hokkaido Island, Japan, was forced to the surface overnight, with some areas rising 50ft above sea level. Geologists believe the emergence was caused by a landslide, when melting ice and snow caused a section of land to drop, pivoting the underwater area into the air. The new stretch of land, which measures roughly 1,000-1,640ft long and 100ft wide, came as a complete surprise to locals, as there were no indications of the land movement overnight. Authorities do not expect the landmass to expand further. Marine organisms such as seaweed and sea urchins are still attached to the landmass.

Gregory van der Wiel has denied rumors that he will leave Paris Saint-Germain in the summer, stating that he is happy at the club and wants to sign a new contract. Despite a recent falling out with manager Laurent Blanc, van der Wiel insists that he loves the club, city, and his teammates. However, the club continues to be linked with Barcelona star Dani Alves, which could impact van der Wiel's future at the club.

Carlos Tevez, who joined Boca's youth academy in 1996, has expressed his desire to leave Juventus and return to Boca Juniors in Argentina. Despite being on course to win a second Serie A title with Juventus and still having a shot at European glory, Tevez has reportedly told the club he wishes to leave this summer. Boca has confirmed they are close to completing a deal for the 31-year-old, but club president Daniel Angelici has stressed that Tevez must terminate his contract with Juventus first. Tevez has always said he intends to finish his career back at his first club Boca Juniors in Argentina.

Bayern Munich manager Pep Guardiola ripped a hole in his trousers during a Champions League match against Porto, which Bayern won 6-1. The incident occurred during an exciting night for Bayern, who led 5-0 at half-time. Guardiola joked after the match that he would need to buy new trousers for the next game. Bayern's European rivals may be concerned after their outstanding display, as they showed they were a cut above a shell-shocked Porto side.

A multi-vehicle crash involving three vehicles occurred on the Brisbane Valley Highway, 2km south of Fernvale, on Wednesday afternoon. Ten people, including four children, were involved, with three being airlifted to Princess Alexandra Hospital in Brisbane. Six others, including an infant and two young girls, were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries. The highway has been closed off, with diversions in place south of Fernvale.

Arsenal playmaker Mesut Ozil is eagerly anticipating the upcoming match against Chelsea, as he recently acquired a new Apple Watch. Ozil expressed his excitement on Instagram, comparing the watch to the fictional character Michael Knight from Knight Rider. The match is crucial for Arsenal, as they trail Chelsea by 10 points with only six games remaining. Additionally, Arsenal has been boosted by the return of Jack Wilshere, who is considered a key player for the team's future.

Mark Clattenburg, a highly regarded Premier League referee, has been appointed to officiate the Manchester derby between United and City at Old Trafford. Despite accusations of favoring United, Clattenburg has only sent off two players in the Premier League this season, both from United. City captain Vincent Kompany was recently sent off by Clattenburg during an international break, resulting in a suspension for an upcoming match. Clattenburg will be joined by assistants Simon Beck and Jake Collin, with Jonathan Moss serving as the fourth official.

Bob Katter, an MP of Lebanese descent, accused the Queensland Government of viewing Billy Gordon, an embattled MP, as a "black puppet on a string." Katter, who has faced racist attitudes from both major parties, sympathized with Gordon. Katter's statement sparked criticism, with some questioning his terminology. Katter defended his statement, stating he used the term because of his personal experiences and to call out racial overtones.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Illinois with cerebral palsy, creates dance videos to challenge stereotypes and inspire others. Despite facing bullying and stares, she aims to change perceptions and encourage people to look beyond disabilities. Dayna has produced multiple dance videos, including one to Taylor Swift's "Shake It Off," and has begun motivational speaking at local schools.

Orlando City, a Major League Soccer (MLS) club, is interested in signing Manchester United's Javier Hernandez. Hernandez, a Mexican international, has struggled during his loan spell at Real Madrid and is linked with a move to Orlando, who have a large Latin-American fanbase. Eight European sides, including Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, and Everton, are also interested in Hernandez, who is valued at around £8million by Manchester United. Hernandez has one year left on his contract. Meanwhile, Manchester United has made a revised contract offer to 19-year-old Andreas Pereira, who has attracted interest from several European clubs, including Paris St Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven, and Feyenoord, after rejecting United's opening offer.

A gang of at least three people set a car on fire at a South Los Angeles gas station after an argument with the driver. The driver and two passengers were unharmed, but the car was completely ruined. The suspects remain at large, and the Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident as an arson.

A southern Iowa chiropractor, Charles Manuel, has surrendered his state license after admitting to swapping services for sex and performing exorcisms on patients. Despite this, he has received outstanding evaluations for patient satisfaction on HealthGrades.com. The Iowa Board of Chiropractic released a report detailing the charges against Manuel, who signed an agreement admitting his misdeeds and pledging not to apply for reinstatement for at least 10 years. The agreement requires Manuel to prove that the circumstances surrounding the revocation of his license no longer exist before he can resume practicing chiropractic in the state.

A U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane was intercepted by a Russian SU-27 Flanker over the Baltic Sea in international airspace north of Poland. The U.S. crew deemed the Russian pilot's maneuvers as unsafe and unprofessional. Russian state news agency Sputnik reported that the U.S. plane was flying toward the Russian border with its transponder switched off, but this claim was denied by an official with the U.S. European Command. The Pentagon and State Department will file a complaint with Russia through diplomatic channels. This is not the first time the U.S. has complained about an incident involving a RC-135U and a SU-27, with a previous incident occurring a year ago over the Sea of Okhotsk.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle was stolen from a Salt Lake City hotel parking lot just days before President Obama's visit. The rifle was inside a hard case secured to a truck safe with padlocks and chains in the agent's car, which was parked at the Marriott Springhill Suites. The thief is believed to have broken the car's rear right passenger-side window, tied a rope around the rifle case's handle or a cable lock, and used the momentum from another vehicle to break the case's handle free from the lock. The hotel does not have surveillance cameras. The FBI agent's gear bag, backpack, clothing, and tools were also stolen, with some of his belongings found at a nearby Residence Inn. The rifle has not been recovered, and its serial number has been entered into the National Crime Information Computer.

Luigi Costa, 71, is accused of murdering his elderly neighbor Terrence Freebody in July 2012. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen examined Costa and believes his mental state was declining in the lead-up to and during the attack. Mullen stated that Costa's mood fluctuated, and his confused mental state was indicated by a trail of feces from the crime scene to the toilet where Costa was found. Costa's state of mind is critical to the case, as the jury can return a not guilty verdict if his unstable mindset at the time of the attack can be proven.

Everton manager Roberto Martinez had to defend another penalty fiasco after Ross Barkley, who has never taken a penalty before, took a penalty instead of Leighton Baines, who has a good record of scoring penalties. Barkley's penalty was saved, but it didn't affect the outcome of the game as Everton won 1-0 against Burnley. Martinez defended Barkley's decision to take the penalty, stating that he was happy to have multiple players who can take penalties. Despite the miss, Barkley showed responsibility, according to Martinez, and Baines was happy to let him take the penalty.

Two passengers were found dead in their stateroom on the ms Ryndam, a cruise ship operated by Holland America Line, under circumstances suggesting a murder-suicide. The incident occurred on March 31, 2022, while the ship was docked in San Juan, Puerto Rico, during a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise that departed from Tampa, Florida, on March 29. The FBI is investigating the deaths, which were discovered by the ship's cleaning staff.

Patrick Kluivert, a former Holland forward and assistant coach, has made a winning start as coach of Curacao in World Cup qualifying. Curacao advanced to the second qualifying round in CONCACAF for the 2018 tournament after drawing 2-2 in a second-leg match at Montserrat, winning 4-3 on aggregate. Kluivert's team won 2-1 on Saturday in Willemstad. Curacao will face Cuba in the next round on June 8 and 16.

Esteban Cambiasso, a highly decorated player with numerous European titles, is determined to help Leicester City avoid relegation from the Premier League. Despite being seven points adrift with only eight games left, Cambiasso views the challenge as equivalent to winning a trophy. He has expressed his happiness in England and is open to extending his stay beyond his current contract.

A 23-year-old mother of two, named Gemma, is at risk of being banned from seeing her children due to her partying and drinking habits. Gemma handed over her children to her mother, Debbie, when they were four months old. Debbie has been raising the children alone and is now considering banning Gemma from seeing them due to her behavior. Debbie discovered Gemma's use of legal highs and suspected her of stealing. Gemma admits to stealing money and other items from her mother in the past. Debbie claims that Gemma has been neglecting her children and prioritizing drinking and partying over motherhood.

Chelsea forward Eden Hazard scored to give his side a 1-0 lead against Manchester United at Stamford Bridge on Saturday. The Sky Sports punditry team believed there had been a foul in the build-up to the goal. Chelsea captain John Terry had come in with a strong challenge from behind on United striker Radamel Falcao, which sent the Colombian hurtling to the ground. Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fabregas then collected the loose ball and released it to Oscar before his back-heel sent it into the path of the oncoming Hazard to slot home. The Manchester United striker struggled to hold his ground and lost the ball to Terry near the half-way line. Terry's strong challenge led to a loose ball that was picked up by Fabregas to start the scoring move. During their half-time analysis, pundits Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness agreed that play should have been stopped for Terry's rough tackle on Falcao.

Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott's tour bus caught fire on a Texas freeway, but everyone on board was safely evacuated. The fire started after a rear tire blew out, and the bus was completely destroyed except for Scott's Bible. The band is scheduled to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards on Sunday.

Dr. Adrian Quarterman, a Scottish scientist from Dundee University, is exploring the potential of space lasers to convert sunlight into energy and transmit it back to Earth. These lasers, which will be attached to satellites orbiting the Earth, could revolutionize solar power by making it viable in regions with less sunlight, such as Scotland, and enable the restoration of power in disaster-stricken areas. Initial trials in Scotland have been successful, and Dr. Quarterman is now planning to conduct further trials in Portugal. Unlike the powerful lasers depicted in science fiction, these lasers are not capable of causing harm to living beings or objects, and they are also distinct from the laser system proposed by Tokyo researchers for clearing space debris around the International Space Station. However, Dr. Quarterman acknowledges the importance of considering the potential risks associated with controlling such powerful technology.

Stephen Munden, a convicted paedophile with a fanatical obsession with young girls, has gone on the run after vanishing from a psychiatric unit. He was last seen leaving a hospital near Hook, Hampshire, at 6.15pm on Tuesday. Munden, who was detained under the Mental Health Act for sexually touching a three-year-old girl, is described as about 5ft 8ins tall, of a heavy build, and has dark hair. He may have shaved off his beard before leaving the hospital. Munden was convicted of sexually touching a child under the age of 13 and was detained at the private facility following his sentence last August. He was also convicted of ten unrelated offences of possessing or attempting to possess indecent images of children. Officers are urgently seeking information on his whereabouts.

V. Stiviano, a former female companion of Donald Sterling, was ordered to pay back over $2.6 million in gifts after Sterling's wife, Rochelle "Shelly" Sterling, sued her. The gifts included luxury cars and a $1.8 million duplex. Stiviano argued that there was nothing wrong with the gifts and that she never took advantage of Sterling. The lawsuit was considered a victory for the Sterling family, recovering the money that Donald Sterling had lavished on Stiviano.

Thierry Henry has criticized Arsenal's recent transfer dealings and urged them to purchase four top players in the summer. He believes they need a goalkeeper, center back, defensive midfielder, and striker to have any chance of winning the Barclays Premier League title. Henry also questioned whether Arsenal can win the title with Olivier Giroud as their first-choice striker. He suggested that Arsenal needs to sign players of the caliber of Thibaut Courtois, Nemanja Matic, Cesc Fabregas, and Diego Costa.

A young woman who was subjected to years of abuse by Bega Cheese boss Maurice Van Ryn has told a court of the severe impact it had on her life. The wealthy NSW businessman has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences, including the most serious charge of persistent sexual abuse of a child. The young woman, who cannot be named, said when he abused her as a child she didn't know it was wrong. She said she hadn't spoken up about the abuse until the day she heard he had been caught, and since then had attempted to take her own life. She says she wonders when Van Ryn, who is now in custody, will be out in the community again, and she worries what he did to her will forever affect how she relates to men. She said she has suffered depression since she was 14 and had been hospitalised for self-harm and attempted suicide.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old Arsenal midfielder, is returning after more than a year out due to a serious knee injury. He has not played since March 2014 but is now closing in on a return. Gnabry played 90 minutes for Arsenal's Under 21s against Reading on Monday and is now over his injury worries.

A young accountant, Jacob Phillips, fell to his death from a 70ft cliff after running from a taxi to avoid paying the fare. The incident occurred in Penarth, South Wales, after a night out with friends. Phillips, who was staying with his mother in Cowbridge, had planned to stay at a friend's house but lacked the funds for the journey. The taxi driver, unaware of the danger, pursued Phillips, who ran into the dark and fell down a cliff. The coroner ruled the death accidental, highlighting Phillips' disorientation and lack of awareness of the cliff's danger.

Thousands of holidaymakers faced passport delays last summer, with the passport agency making a £42 million profit during the chaos. Managers received bonuses up to £3,500, while ministers refused blanket refunds to affected families. Only 2,191 compensation applications were approved, totaling £203,066, with the biggest payout at £5,463 and the lowest at £1. The Passport Office could not provide data on rejected claims due to a system failure.

A timewarp home in Horfield, Bristol, which has remained unchanged since the 1930s, is up for sale. The semi-detached property features original stained-glass windows, oil-fired central heating, retro jars of popular food, and the original bathroom and kitchen. The house also has a wood-panelled hallway, vintage cupboards, and a dated bathroom with mint and black colour schemes. The property is unimposing from the outside but boasts quirky and unusual original features inside. The guide price for the house is between £200,000 and £250,000.

Colin Kaepernick began his career as a backup to Alex Smith but became the 49ers' starter in the middle of the 2012 season after Smith suffered a concussion. Kaepernick led the 49ers to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, losing to the Baltimore Ravens.
The 1997 American comedy-drama film Soul Food was produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, and was released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

Anne Rice was born in New Orleans and spent her early life there before moving to Texas and later to San Francisco. Route 495 is a 3.45 mi freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, that connects the New Jersey Turnpike (Interstate 95, I-95) at exits 16E and 17 in Secaucus to New York State Route 495 (NY 495) inside the Lincoln Tunnel in Weehawken, providing access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language terrestrial television network owned by Comcast through the NBCUniversal division NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn, raised in Leytonstone, East London, and Colchester, Essex, attended Stanway School, where he met Graham Coxon and formed Blur. Blur's debut album, Leisure, was released in 1991 to mixed reviews. Albarn's debut solo album, Everyday Robots, was released in 2014 and featured collaborations with Brian Eno, Natasha Khan, and the Leytonstone City Pentecostal Mission Church Choir, as well as samples of Lord Buckley's rants.
The capital and most populous city of Somalia is Mogadishu, also known as Hamar. Many important national institutions are based in Mogadishu.
The song "Happiness in Slavery" is by the American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails, from their debut EP, Broken, released in 1992.
Andrew Kevin Walker is an American screenwriter who was born on August 14, 1964. He has been nominated for a BAFTA award.

The Shooter franchise consists of a 2007 film and a TV series. The film follows Force Recon veteran Bob Lee Swagger, who is framed for murder by a rogue secret private military company unit. The TV series stars Ryan Phillippe as Bob Lee Swagger, an expert marksman living in exile who is coaxed back into action after learning of a plot to kill the president.
House, also known as House, M.D., is an American television medical drama that aired on the Fox network for eight seasons, from November 16, 2004, to May 21, 2012.

Charles Manson was found guilty in 1971 of first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder for the deaths of seven people, including actress Sharon Tate, as well as Gary Hinman and Donald "Shorty" Shea. After his conviction, recordings of songs written and performed by him were released commercially.

Sean Justin Penn, born on August 17, 1960, is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist. He began his acting career in television with a brief appearance in Little House on the Prairie in 1974, directed by his father Leo Penn. Penn made his film debut in the drama Taps in 1981 and gained critical attention for his roles in crime dramas such as At Close Range, State of Grace, and Carlito's Way. He became a prominent leading actor with the drama Dead Man Walking, for which he earned his first Academy Award nomination and the Best Actor Award at the Berlin Film Festival. Penn received two more Oscar nominations for Sweet and Lowdown and I Am Sam before winning his first Academy Award for Best Actor in 2003 for Mystic River and a second one in 2008 for Milk.

Sir Donald George Bradman, also known as "The Don," was an Australian cricketer widely regarded as the greatest batsman of all time. After retiring, he remained active in cricket as an administrator, selector, and writer for three decades.
L.A. Reid has held the positions of chairman and CEO at Epic Records, Arista Records, and the Island Def Jam Music Group.

Brad Wilk is a drummer known for his work with Rage Against the Machine and Audioslave. He began his career with Greta in 1990 and co-founded Rage Against the Machine in 1991. As of 2016, he is playing with Prophets of Rage, alongside Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B-Real, and DJ Lord. Rage is a German heavy metal band formed in 1984 by Peter "Peavy" Wagner.

The Millers is a multi-camera series that aired on CBS from October 3, 2013, to July 18, 2015, running for 34 episodes over two seasons. CBS announced the cancellation of the show on November 14, 2014, after four episodes into its second season.

Dorothy Ann Willis Richards, born on September 1, 1933, served as the 45th Governor of Texas from 1991 to 1995. A Democrat, she gained national attention as the state treasurer of Texas and delivered the keynote address at the 1988 Democratic National Convention. She was the second female governor of Texas and was known for her outspoken feminism and one-liners. She was defeated for re-election in 1994 by George W. Bush. Ann Richards, born on October 1, 1935, was an American jazz singer and the wife of pianist Stan Kenton.
Drake Bell released an EP titled A Reminder independently in 2011.

The 1979 American drama film Boardwalk was written by Stephen Verona and Leigh Chapman and directed by Verona. The actress Janet Leigh, born Jeanette Helen Morrison, starred in the film. She was also a singer, dancer, author, and wrote four books between 1984 and 2002, including two novels.

Simón Bolívar, also known as El Libertador, was a Venezuelan military and political leader who played a crucial role in the independence of Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Panama from Spanish rule.
The Bermuda Triangle, also known as the Devil's Triangle, is a region in the western North Atlantic Ocean where numerous aircraft and ships have reportedly disappeared under mysterious circumstances.

Colin Kaepernick began his career as a backup to Alex Smith but became the 49ers' starter in 2012 after Smith's concussion. He led the 49ers to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, losing to the Baltimore Ravens. In his first full season as a starter in 2013, Kaepernick helped the 49ers reach the NFC Championship, losing to the Seattle Seahawks.
The film Marnie, directed by Alfred Hitchcock, was released in 1964 and is an American psychological thriller.

Advertising is a marketing communication tool that uses sponsored, nonpersonal messages to promote or sell products, services, or ideas. It is communicated through various media, including traditional outlets like newspapers, magazines, television, radio, outdoor advertising, and direct mail, as well as new media such as search results, blogs, websites, and text messages.
The passage describes "Private Lives," a 1930 comedy of manners in three acts by Noël Coward, and a 1931 American Pre-Code comedy film adaptation directed by Sidney Franklin.

Maurice Harold Macmillan, also known as the 1st Earl of Stockton, served as the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 10 January 1957 to 19 October 1963. He was a British Conservative politician and statesman.

Aristotle, an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist, was born in Stagira, Chalkidice, in Classical Greece. He joined Plato's Academy in Athens at the age of seventeen or eighteen and remained there until he was thirty-seven. After Plato's death, Aristotle left Athens and tutored Alexander the Great at the request of Philip II of Macedon, starting in 343 BC.

David Mordechai Packouz, born on February 16, 1982, is an American entrepreneur, musician, inventor, and former arms dealer. He is the CEO of Singular Sound, a music technology company, and invented the BeatBuddy guitar pedal drum machine.

Magic Johnson, a point guard for the Lakers for 13 seasons, won a championship and an NBA Finals Most Valuable Player Award in his rookie season. He won four more championships with the Lakers during the 1980s. After retiring for four years, he returned in 1996 to play 32 games before retiring for the final time. He was named one of America's most influential black businessmen by Ebony magazine in 2009 and has numerous business interests. He was also a part-owner of the Lakers for several years.

Tenacious D is an American comedy rock duo formed in Los Angeles in 1994, consisting of Jack Black and Kyle Gass. They gained popularity in 1997 through their television series and supporting large rock acts. The band has released three albums: Tenacious D (2001), The Pick of Destiny (2006), and Rize of the Fenix (2012).

James VI and I, also known as James Stuart, was King of Scotland, England, and Ireland. He advocated for a single parliament for Scotland and England, achieving his aims in Scotland but facing difficulties in England, including the Gunpowder Plot and conflicts with the English Parliament.

The upcoming eighteenth series of the British reality television series Big Brother, known as Big Brother 2017 or Big Brother 18, will be hosted by Emma Willis and narrated by Marcus Bentley. Bentley, born on October 4, 1967, is a British actor, broadcaster, and voice-over artist most famous for narrating the UK's version of the Dutch reality television program Big Brother since its inception in 2000.

The Free State of Saxony, a federal state of Germany, is bordered by Brandenburg, Saxony Anhalt, Thuringia, Bavaria, Poland, and the Czech Republic. It is the tenth largest state in Germany, with an area of 18,413 km2, and the sixth most populous, with 4 million people. Saxony has a history spanning over a millennium and is a region for quality wine in Germany. It is one of the northernmost wine regions in Europe and one of the two wine regions located in the former East Germany.
East End Park is a former major league baseball park located in the East End neighborhood of Cincinnati, USA. The song "In the End" is by the American rock band Linkin Park.
Mel B. Brown began her solo career with the release of "I Want You Back" featuring Missy Elliott on Virgin Records.
Noah Cyrus is the youngest daughter of Billy Ray Cyrus and the younger sister of Miley Cyrus and Trace Cyrus.

Mohra is a 1994 Indian action thriller film directed by Rajiv Rai, starring Akshay Kumar, Sunil Shetty, Raveena Tandon, and Naseeruddin Shah in the lead roles. The film was released on 1 July 1994 and became the second highest grossing Indian film of 1994. It received nine Filmfare nominations in 1995. Divya Bharti was initially considered for the female lead, but after her death, Raveena Tandon replaced her. The film is also remembered for its chartbuster songs.
The song "Hourglass" is by the British electronic duo Disclosure and is featured on singer-songwriter James Taylor's fourteenth studio album.
Shane Black is an American screenwriter, director, producer, and actor, known for writing the 1987 action film hit Lethal Weapon and his directorial debut with the 2005 film Kiss Kiss Bang Bang.
The fourteenth spy film in the James Bond series, A View to a Kill (1985), is the seventh and final film to feature Roger Moore as the fictional MI6 agent James Bond.

Papua is the largest and easternmost province of Indonesia, comprising most of western New Guinea. It was formerly known as Irian Jaya (before that West Irian or Irian Barat) and comprised all of Indonesian New Guinea.
Augustus likely died from natural causes, although there were unconfirmed rumors that his wife Livia poisoned him.

Jennifer Lopez is a multifaceted entertainer who began her music career in 1999 with her debut album On the 6, featuring the number-one single "If You Had My Love." In 2001, she simultaneously released her second album J.Lo and starred in the film The Wedding Planner, becoming the first woman to achieve a number-one album and film in the same week. After her second divorce, her relationship with Ben Affleck influenced her third album, This Is Me... Then, and overshadowed the release of the film Gigli, which was a critical and commercial failure. She then married Marc Anthony and rebounded with successful films like Shall We Dance? Lopez gave birth to twins in 2008 and returned to prominence in 2011 with her role as a judge on American Idol and her most commercially successful single to date, "On the Floor," which is one of the best-selling singles of all time.

A working animal is a domesticated animal trained to perform tasks for humans. These tasks can range from providing tractive force, such as with draft horses or logging elephants, to assisting with milking or herding. While wild animals can sometimes be trained for work, they are typically used for novelty or entertainment due to their lack of trustworthiness and mild temper.

Billboard Dad is a 1998 American direct-to-video comedy film directed by Alan Metter and starring Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen. Top Latin Albums is a record chart published by Billboard magazine, which is the most important music chart for Spanish language, full-length albums in the American music market. The Regional Mexican Albums is a genre-specific record chart published weekly by Billboard magazine in the United States.

The 2010 Indian drama film Vedam, directed by Radhakrishna Jagarlamudi, is in the Telugu language. The film features a cast including Allu Arjun, Manoj Manchu, Anushka Shetty, Manoj Bajpayee, Saranya Ponvannan, Deeksha Seth, Lekha Washington, and Siya Gautham.

Men in Black II (MIIB) is a 2002 American science fiction action comedy film featuring an ensemble cast including Tommy Lee Jones, Will Smith, Lara Flynn Boyle, Johnny Knoxville, Rosario Dawson, Tony Shalhoub, and Rip Torn.

Sancho Panza is a fictional character in Don Quixote, a novel by Spanish author Don Miguel de Cervantes Saavedra. He acts as a squire to Don Quixote and provides comments known as sanchismos, which are a combination of broad humor, ironic Spanish proverbs, and earthy wit.
The Adventures of Pluto Nash is a 2002 Australian-American science fiction action comedy film starring Eddie Murphy in a dual role and directed by Ron Underwood.
The world premiere of Hedda Gabler by Ibsen took place on 31 January 1891 at the Residenztheater in Munich, with Ibsen present.
Brazzers is a pornographic production company based in Montreal, Canada.
Timothy Simon Roth is an English actor and director born on 14 May 1961.

Juventus Football Club S.p.A., also known as Juve, is a professional Italian association football club based in Turin, Piedmont. Founded in 1897 by a group of young Torinese students, the club is the second oldest active football club in the country. Juventus has traditionally worn a black and white striped home kit since 1903 and has played its home matches in several grounds, with the latest being the 41,507-capacity Juventus Stadium.

Viola Davis is an actress who played supporting and minor roles in films and television series in the late 1990s and early 2000s, including Kate & Leopold (2001), Far from Heaven (2002), and Law & Order: Special Victims Unit.

Jenna Jameson, born Jenna Marie Massoli on April 9, 1974, is an American entrepreneur, webcam model, and former pornographic film actress. She is known as the world's most famous adult entertainment performer and "The Queen of Porn." Jenna started acting in erotic videos in 1993 after working as a stripper and glamor model.

The New Orleans Pelicans are a professional basketball team based in New Orleans, Louisiana. They compete in the National Basketball Association (NBA) as part of the Western Conference Southwest Division.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event produced by Jim Crockett Promotions (JCP) under the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) banner, broadcast via closed-circuit and pay-per-view television from 1983 to 2000. It was a tradition for JCP to hold major wrestling events on Thanksgiving and Christmas, primarily at Greensboro Coliseum. The event was held from 1983 to 2000.
Jack Ryan Falahee is an American actor known for his roles as Connor Walsh on ABC's How to Get Away with Murder and Benjamin Stringfellow on PBS's Mercy Street.

Seohyun, born Seo Ju-hyun on June 28, 1991, is a South Korean singer and actress. She debuted as a member of the girl group Girls' Generation in August 2007 and later as a member of its subgroup TTS. She has also established herself as an actress, participating in various stage musicals. Seohyun debuted as a solo artist with her mini album Do n't Say No on January 17, 2017, becoming the third Girls' Generation member to do so.

The Apple II is an 8-bit home computer, one of the first highly successful mass-produced microcomputer products, designed primarily by Steve Wozniak. The Apple II series is a family of home computers, one of the first highly successful mass-produced text command microcomputer products, designed primarily by Steve Wozniak, manufactured by Apple Computer (now Apple Inc.), and introduced in 1977 with the original Apple II.

A&E is an American cable and satellite television channel, serving as the flagship of A&E Networks, a joint venture between the Hearst Corporation and Disney--ABC Television Group, each maintaining a 50% ownership interest.

L.A. Reid has held several prominent positions in the music industry, including chairman and CEO roles at Epic Records, Arista Records, and the Island Def Jam Music Group. He also founded Hitco Music Publishing and co-founded LaFace Records.

The text describes two films named "Veeram": a 2014 Indian Tamil action film directed by Siva and produced by Vijaya Productions, and a 2016 Indian epic historical drama film written and directed by Jayaraj.

The 1972 made-for-television horror film "Home for the Holidays" was directed by John Llewellyn Moxey and produced by Aaron Spelling. It starred Sally Field, Eleanor Parker, Julie Harris, Jessica Walter, and Walter Brennan. The film premiered on ABC on November 28, 1972. The 1995 film "Home for the Holidays" starred Holly Hunter, Robert Downey Jr., Anne Bancroft, Charles Durning, Dylan McDermott, Geraldine Chaplin, Steve Guttenberg, Cynthia Stevenson, Claire Danes, Austin Pendleton, and David Strathairn.
Taran Killam is an American actor, comedian, and writer born on April 1, 1982.
The Sex Factor is an online reality TV series produced by xHamster, where eight men and eight women compete to become a porn star.
John Hovig Dolmayan, born on July 15, 1973, is a Lebanese-born Armenian-American songwriter and drummer.
Island Records is a British-American record label under Universal Music Group (UMG).
Sikkim is a northeastern state of India.
Christa McAuliffe was a social studies teacher at Concord High School in New Hampshire, starting in 1983.
Ron Weasley is a fictional character in J. K. Rowling's Harry Potter series.
Reign Over Me is a 2007 American drama film written and directed by Mike Binder and produced by his brother Jack Binder. It was distributed by Columbia Pictures and released on March 23, 2007.
Colin Kaepernick is an American football quarterback who is currently a free agent. He was born on November 3, 1987.

Sheryl Lee appeared in Café Society in 2016 and reprised her role of Laura Palmer in the Showtime revival of Twin Peaks in 2017. Sheryl Lee Ralph played Madame Morrible in Wicked on Broadway in 2016.
Matteo Renzi, born on 11 January 1975, served as the Prime Minister of Italy from February 2014 until December 2016.
The Road to El Dorado is a film starring Kevin Kline, Kenneth Branagh, Armand Assante, Jim Cummings, Edward James Olmos, Tobin Bell, and Rosie Perez.

Selena Gomez released her second solo album, Revival, in 2015, which debuted at number one on the Billboard 200. The first three singles from the album, "Good for You," "Same Old Love," and "Hands to Myself," all topped the Mainstream Top 40 chart in the United States.
Weekly Idol is a show hosted by comedian Jeong Hyeong-don and rapper Defconn.

Metal is a genre of rock music that originated in the late 1960s and early 1970s in the United Kingdom and the United States. In the late 1970s, bands such as Iron Maiden and Saxon emerged in the new wave of British heavy metal, continuing in a similar style.
Ashton Kutcher appeared in several romantic comedies, including Guess Who (2005), A Lot Like Love (2005), What Happens in Vegas (2008), and No Strings Attached (2011).

Topman is a high-street men's clothing store chain that is part of the Arcadia Group, which also owns Burton, Miss Selfridge, Wallis, Evans, and Dorothy Perkins. It has stores throughout the United Kingdom and in six cities and towns in Ireland.

Wales transformed from an agricultural society into an industrial nation during the Industrial Revolution, with the development of the mining and metallurgical industries. The exploitation of the South Wales Coalfield led to a rapid expansion of the country's population.
Tool is a Grammy Award-winning band that has performed worldwide tours and produced chart-topping albums in several countries.
YouTube is an American video-sharing website headquartered in San Bruno, California, and is ranked as the second most popular site in the world by Alexa Internet.
Sidse Babett Knudsen is a Danish actress who works in theatre, television, and film. She was born on 22 November 1968.

Conrad Dunn began his screen career as Francis "Psycho" Soyer in the 1981 film Stripes. The film also featured several actors, including John Larroquette, John Diehl, Conrad Dunn, and Judge Reinhold, in their first significant film roles.
The film "Raees" stars Shah Rukh Khan, Mahira Khan, and Nawazuddin Siddiqui.
Asylum Records is an American record label founded in 1971 by David Geffen and Elliot Roberts.
Trollhunters is an American fantasy television series created by Guillermo del Toro for Netflix. It is produced by DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You.

The Armenian Genocide, also known as the Armenian Holocaust, was the Ottoman government's systematic extermination of 1.5 million Armenians, mostly Ottoman citizens within the Ottoman Empire and its successor state, the Republic of Turkey. Other indigenous and Christian ethnic groups, such as the Assyrians and the Ottoman Greeks, were similarly targeted for extermination by the Ottoman government. Their treatment is considered by some historians to be part of the same genocidal policy.
Marcus Morgan Bentley is a British actor, broadcaster, and voice-over artist, born on 4 October 1967.

William Jefferson Clinton, born on August 19, 1946, served as the 42nd President of the United States from 1993 to 2001. His first inauguration was held on January 20, 1993, on the West Front of the United States Capitol Building in Washington, D.C.

Danny Boyle is an English director, producer, screenwriter, and theatre director known for films such as Shallow Grave, Trainspotting, The Beach, 28 Days Later, Sunshine, Slumdog Millionaire, 127 Hours, and Steve Jobs. The Beach is a 2000 adventure drama film directed by Boyle, based on the 1996 novel of the same name by Alex Garland, adapted for the film by John Hodge.
The dress became a viral sensation, with over 10 million tweets mentioning it in the first week after its image surfaced, using hashtags like #thedress, #whiteandgold, and #blackandblue.
Major Bruce Middleton Hope Shand MC and bar was an officer in the British Army. He was born on 22 January 1917 and passed away on 11 June 2006.
Advertising is a marketing communication method that uses sponsored, nonpersonal messages to promote or sell products, services, or ideas.

The Others (2001) won eight Goya Awards, including Best Film and Best Director, making it the first English-language film to win Best Film at the Goyas without any Spanish dialogue. It was also nominated for six Saturn Awards, winning three for Best Horror Film, Best Actress (Nicole Kidman), and Best Supporting Actress (Fionnula Flanagan).
Ralph Fults was a Depression-era outlaw and escape artist who was associated with the Barrow Gang, including Raymond Hamilton, Bonnie Parker, and Clyde Barrow.

The 14th Dalai Lama, Tenzin Gyatso, was born in 1935 in Taktser village, Amdo, Tibet. He was recognized as the Dalai Lama in 1939 and fled to India during the 1959 Tibetan uprising, where he currently lives as a refugee.

The film "Miracle at St. Anna" is set in World War II Italy and follows four Buffalo Soldiers from the 92nd Infantry Division who seek refuge in a Tuscan village, forming a bond with the residents. The story is presented as a flashback, with a survivor reflecting on his experiences in a frame story set in 1980s New York.
Caroline Bouvier Kennedy, born on November 27, 1957, is an American author, attorney, and diplomat. She served as the United States Ambassador to Japan from 2013 to 2017.

The 1995 film "Home for the Holidays" features a star-studded cast including Holly Hunter, Robert Downey Jr., Anne Bancroft, Charles Durning, Dylan McDermott, Geraldine Chaplin, Steve Guttenberg, Cynthia Stevenson, Claire Danes, Austin Pendleton, and David Strathairn.
Anne Rice was born in New Orleans and spent her early life there before moving to Texas and later to San Francisco.
Stephen Hillenburg was born in Lawton, Oklahoma, and raised in Anaheim, California. He became fascinated with the ocean as a child and also developed an interest in art.

Mendicant refers to a way of life followed by various religious orders, including Catholic mendicant orders, Hindu ascetics, some dervishes of Sufi Islam, and the monastic orders of Jainism and Buddhism. A monk is a person who practices religious asceticism by monastic living, either alone or with others. They may dedicate their life to serving all other living beings or choose to live in prayer and contemplation, leaving mainstream society.
The Mod Squad is an American crime drama series that ran on ABC from 1968 to 1973.
The Dark Tower is an American science fantasy western action horror film directed and co-written by Nikolaj Arcel.

Arizona, the 48th state and last of the contiguous states to be admitted to the Union, is located in the southwestern region of the United States. It is the sixth largest and the 14th most populous of the 50 states. About one-quarter of the state is made up of Indian reservations that serve as the home of 27 federally recognized Native American tribes, including the Navajo Nation, the largest in the state and the United States, with more than 300,000 citizens.
Smriti Mandhana is an Indian cricketer who plays for the Indian women's cricket team. She was born on 18 July 1996.

Emma Watson, born on April 15, 1990, is a French-British actress, model, and activist. She was born in Paris and raised in Oxfordshire, where she attended the Dragon School and trained as an actress at the Oxford branch of Stagecoach Theatre Arts.
Angela Bassett began her film career in the mid-1980s after earning a bachelor's degree from Yale University and a master's degree from drama school.

The Congressional Space Medal of Honor is the highest award given by NASA, awarded by the President of the United States in Congress's name on recommendations from the Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. To be awarded the medal, an astronaut must perform feats of extraordinary accomplishment while participating in space flight under the authority of NASA. Frank Frederick Borman, II, born March 14, 1928, is a recipient of the medal.
The Saw franchise grossed over $873 million at the box office worldwide.

The 2003 romantic comedy film Down with Love explores the battle of the sexes in the 1960s. It follows the story of a woman who writes a book advocating for women's independence and a man who writes a book advocating for men's liberation.
Paul Nicholls is a British actor known for his roles as Joe Wicks in BBC's EastEnders and as DS Sam Casey in ITV's Law & Order: UK.
The 2011 French action film Colombiana was co-written and produced by Luc Besson and directed by Olivier Megaton.
Rick Yune was part of the main cast of the Netflix original series Marco Polo until it was cancelled on December 12, 2016.

Kentucky is known for horse racing, bourbon distilleries, coal, the historic site My Old Kentucky Home, automobile manufacturing, tobacco, bluegrass music, college basketball, and Kentucky Fried Chicken.
The film Boyhood, shot from 2002 to 2013, portrays the childhood and adolescence of Mason Evans, Jr. from ages six to eighteen in Texas with his divorced parents, played by Arquette and Hawke.
The film "Hush" (2016) was produced by Trevor Macy through Intrepid Pictures and Jason Blum through his Blumhouse Productions banner.
The Penibaetic System is the southernmost of the three systems of mountain ranges in the Baetic System, located in the southern Iberian Peninsula.

Bonobos is a brand that offers a wide range of men's clothing, including suits, trousers, denim, shirts, shorts, swimwear, outerwear, and accessories. Topman, part of the Arcadia Group, operates high-street men's clothing stores throughout the UK and has outlets in six cities and towns in Ireland.
The song "Roar" by American singer Katy Perry was released as the lead single from her fourth studio album, Prism, on August 10, 2013.
The Saturn Corporation, also known as Saturn LLC, is a subsidiary of General Motors, established on January 7, 1985.

The Armenian Genocide, also known as the Armenian Holocaust, was the systematic extermination of 1.5 million Armenians by the Ottoman government. This event is recognized as genocide by most historians, but Turkey, the successor state of the Ottoman Empire, denies the term genocide as an accurate description of the mass killings that began in 1915.

The Quran is believed by Muslims to be a verbal revelation from God to Muhammad through the angel Gabriel, revealed gradually over 23 years, starting on 22 December 609 CE when Muhammad was 40, and concluding in 632, the year of his death.

The human brain, along with the spinal cord, forms the central nervous system. It consists of the cerebrum, brainstem, and cerebellum. The cerebrum is the largest part and contains various important structures, including the limbic system, claustrum, basal ganglia nuclei, basal forebrain structures, and three circumventricular organs.
T2 Trainspotting is a 2017 British comedy drama film set in and around Edinburgh, Scotland.
AMGTV is an American television network that offers a variety of programming, including drama, sports, movies, entertainment, how-to, hunting and fishing, children's shows, and other features.

Sir Donald George Bradman, also known as "The Don," was an Australian cricketer widely regarded as the greatest batsman of all time. Despite becoming reclusive in his later years, his opinion was highly sought after, and he was still recognized as a national icon. In 2001, more than 50 years after his retirement as a Test player, Australian Prime Minister John Howard called him the "greatest living Australian."

Margaret Hilda Thatcher, also known as Baroness Thatcher, served as the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 1979 to 1990 and as the Leader of the Conservative Party from 1975 to 1990. She was the first woman to hold these positions and the longest-serving British Prime Minister of the 20th century. In 1975, she defeated Heath in the Conservative Party leadership election to become the Leader of the Opposition and the first woman to lead a major political party in the United Kingdom.
Randy Mario Poffo, better known as Macho Man Randy Savage, was an American professional wrestler and color commentator. He was best known for his time in the WWF and WCW.
Alice Cooper, born Vincent Damon Furnier on February 4, 1948, is an American singer, songwriter, and actor with a career spanning over five decades.

EA Black Box, originally known as Black Box Games, was a video game developer based in Burnaby, British Columbia, Canada. It was founded in 1998 by former employees of Radical Entertainment and was later acquired by Electronic Arts (EA).

Baiae was a coastal resort and mineral springs location on the northwest shore of the Gulf of Naples in ancient Italy. Herculaneum was an ancient Roman town located near Naples, destroyed by volcanic pyroclastic flows in 79 AD. The ruins of Herculaneum are located in the commune of Ercolano, Campania, Italy. There are many culturally and historically significant sites near Naples, including the Palace of Caserta and the Roman ruins of Pompeii and Herculaneum. Famous ruins exist worldwide, from ancient sites in China, the Indus valley, and Judea to Zimbabwe in Africa, ancient Greek, Egyptian, and Roman sites in the Mediterranean basin, and Incan and Mayan sites in the Americas.

No Country for Old Men is a cat-and-mouse drama set in 1980 West Texas, starring Tommy Lee Jones, Javier Bardem, and Josh Brolin. Jones plays Sheriff Ed Tom Bell, a Vietnam veteran and Texas welder. Jones is also known for his roles in Lonesome Dove, Men in Black, Batman Forever, Under Siege, Man of the House, The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada, Captain America: The First Avenger, Jason Bourne, and Natural Born Killers.
Palo Alto is a charter city in the northwest corner of Santa Clara County, California, in the San Francisco Bay Area. The name Palo Alto means "tall tree" in Spanish.

Albert Lawrence Brooks, born Albert Lawrence Einstein, is an American actor, filmmaker, author, and comedian. He is known for his work in the film Finding Dory, directed by Andrew Stanton and co-directed by Angus MacLane, with a screenplay by Stanton and Victoria Strouse.

Morse code is a method of transmitting text information using on-off tones, lights, or clicks, which can be understood by a skilled observer without special equipment. The code was designed to increase communication speed by varying the length of each character in Morse inversely to its frequency of occurrence in English. Morse code is less sensitive to poor signal conditions than voice, yet still comprehensible to humans without a decoding device. Many amateur radio repeaters identify with Morse code, even though they are used for voice communications. In emergencies, Morse code can be sent using improvised methods, making it one of the simplest and most versatile methods of telecommunication.
Alexandra Anna Daddario, born on March 16, 1986, is an American actress.

The 2005 Hindu Kush earthquake occurred in northeastern Afghanistan on December 12 at 21:47 (UTC) with a magnitude of 6.5. The Hindu Kush is an 800 km mountain range near the Afghan-Pakistan border, extending from central Afghanistan to northern Pakistan. The highest peak in the Hindu Kush is Tirich Mir, located in the Chitral District of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Pakistan, at 7708 m.
Ripon College, located in Wisconsin, had approximately 840 students as of 2015, with most of them residing on campus.

Fox Sports is a brand name for various sports channels, broadcast divisions, programming, and other media controlled or partially owned by the family of Rupert Murdoch. Murdoch had full control as Chairman and CEO of News Corporation, now the world's second-largest media conglomerate, and its successors, News Corp and 21st Century Fox, after the conglomerate split on 28 June 2013. Murdoch and his family own both 21st Century Fox and News Corp through the Murdoch Family Trust.
Wildfang is a US-based women's apparel company that specializes in tomboyish clothing.
Bessie Smith was an American blues singer born on April 15, 1894, and she passed away on September 26, 1937.

Speech recognition is an interdisciplinary sub-field of computational linguistics that develops methodologies and technologies for recognizing and translating spoken language into text by computers. It incorporates knowledge and research from the fields of linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering.
Aleister Crowley was an English occultist, ceremonial magician, poet, painter, novelist, and mountaineer, born as Edward Alexander Crowley on 12 October 1875 and died on 1 December 1947.
Poldark is a British-American drama television series that first aired on BBC One on 8 March 2015.
Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge, starring Shah Rukh Khan and Kajol, was released on 20 October 1995. The film was shot in India, London, and Switzerland from September 1994 to August 1995.

Timothy Simon Roth is an English actor and director born on May 14, 1961. Tim Roth, born on December 6, 1975, is the guitarist, backing vocalist, and only remaining founding member of the Canadian melodic death metal and progressive metal band, Into Eternity.
Tatum O'Neal married professional tennis player John McEnroe in 1986, and they had three children together.

Sean Penn is an actor who has won two Academy Awards for his roles in the films Mystic River (2003) and Milk (2008). He made his film debut in the drama Taps (1981) and gained critical attention for his roles in the crime dramas At Close Range (1986), State of Grace (1990), and Carlito's Way (1993). Penn became known as a prominent leading actor with the drama Dead Man Walking (1995), for which he earned his first Academy Award nomination and the Best Actor Award at the Berlin Film Festival. He received two more Oscar nominations for his roles in Woody Allen's comedy-drama Sweet and Lowdown (1999) and the drama I Am Sam (2001) before winning his first Academy Award for Best Actor in 2003 for Mystic River and a second one in 2008 for Milk. His fourth feature film, the biographical drama survival movie Into the Wild (2007), garnered critical acclaim and two Academy Award nominations.

The Earth's history began with volcanic outgassing creating the primordial atmosphere and ocean, which was toxic to most modern life. Over time, the Earth cooled, forming a solid crust and allowing liquid water to exist on the surface. Plate tectonics continues to shape the Earth's oceans and continents and the living species they harbor. Human activity significantly affects the atmosphere and other Earth systems, such as the ozone layer, greenhouse gases, and productive soils and clean air and water. Water covers 71% of the Earth's surface.
Nuuk is the capital and largest city of Greenland and the municipality of Sermersooq.

The film "How to Train Your Dragon 2" is written and directed by Dean DeBlois and features the voices of Jay Baruchel, Gerard Butler, Craig Ferguson, America Ferrera, Jonah Hill, Christopher Mintz-Plasse, T.J. Miller, and Kristen Wiig, with new additions Cate Blanchett, Djimon Hounsou, and Kit Harington. The entire voice cast from the first film returned, with Blanchett and Hounsou voicing Valka and Drago, respectively.

Down with Love is a 2003 romantic comedy film directed by Peyton Reed, written by Eve Ahlert and Dennis Drake, and starring Renée Zellweger, Ewan McGregor, Sarah Paulson, and David Hyde Pierce. The film is a pastiche of sex comedies popular in the 1950s and 1960s, particularly those starring Doris Day and Rock Hudson. It was first broadcast in Taiwan on China Television and cable TV Gala Television from January to May 2010.
The Paris album by Paris Hilton incorporates elements of reggae, soul, and pop rock in its production.

Stripes is a 1981 American buddy military comedy film directed by Ivan Reitman, starring Bill Murray, Harold Ramis, Warren Oates, P. J. Soles, Sean Young, and John Candy. Several actors, including John Larroquette, John Diehl, Conrad Dunn, and Judge Reinhold, were featured in their first significant film roles. Joe Flaherty, Dave Thomas, Timothy Busfield, and Bill Paxton also appeared early in their careers.
Janelle Monáe Robinson is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model. She is signed to her own imprint, Wondaland Arts Society, and Atlantic Records.

Jewell is a singer best known for her song "Love or Lust," featured in the film Deep Cover, and for singing choruses in many classic West Coast rap songs, including Snoop Dogg's "Gin and Juice" and Dr. Dre's "Let Me Ride."

The University of Mississippi has a diverse student body, with a majority coming from Mississippi and a significant percentage being minorities. Additionally, the university attracts international students from 90 different countries.
The Mighty Ducks was produced by The Kerner Entertainment Company and Avnet -- Kerner Productions and distributed by Walt Disney Pictures.

Johanna Braddy is an actress known for her roles in various television series. She starred as Jenny Matrix in the web series Video Game High School from 2012 to 2014. In 2015, she co-starred as Anna Martin in the Lifetime series Unreal. Currently, she is starring as Shelby Wyatt in the ABC thriller Quantico.

Martin Van Buren was an American politician who served as the eighth President of the United States from 1837 to 1841. He was a member of the Democratic Party and held several senior roles, including eighth Vice President and tenth Secretary of State under Andrew Jackson. Van Buren was a major supporter and organizer for Jackson in the 1828 election and ran for Governor of New York to boost Jackson's campaign. After serving as Governor of New York for two months, he resigned to become Jackson's Secretary of State. In 1831, following his resignation as Secretary of State, which aided Jackson in resolving the Petticoat affair, Jackson gave Van Buren a recess appointment as American minister to Britain.
Rutgers University-Camden, originally the South Jersey Law School, was founded in 1926. Cooper Medical School of Rowan University opened in 2012.

Michigan is a state in the Great Lakes and Midwestern regions of the United States. It is the tenth most populous state and the largest state east of the Mississippi River in terms of total area. Michigan is unique as it consists of two peninsulas, making it a leading U.S. state for recreational boating.

Penguin Books revolutionized publishing in the 1930s by introducing inexpensive paperbacks, sold through high street stores like Woolworths for sixpence, making high-quality paperback fiction and non-fiction accessible to the mass market.
The film Australia (2008) was produced in Sydney, Darwin, Kununurra, and Bowen.

Billy Ray Cyrus is an American country music singer, songwriter, actor, and philanthropist who helped make country music a worldwide phenomenon. French Montana's debut studio album is titled Excuse My French. Excuse My French is also a 2014 Egyptian film comedy directed by Amr Salama, based on Salama's experiences at a public middle school in Egypt after returning from Saudi Arabia. The film was initially deemed too sensitive by the censorship board, and Salama had to adjust the script while preserving the core concept of religious discrimination.
Derek Hough starred in the 2013 independent dance film Make Your Move, which is a Romeo and Juliet-inspired story set in South Korea and America.

"Bad Romance" is a song by Lady Gaga from her 2009 EP The Fame Monster. After an illegal demo leak, Gaga premiered the final version at Alexander McQueen's Paris Fashion Week show in October 2009. The single's cover art was also released. The song became a global success, selling 12 million copies worldwide and becoming one of the best-selling singles ever. Additionally, a 2011 independent drama film titled "Bad Romance (film)" was released, with the title "Les Mauvais Romans."

DreamWorks Animation has released 34 feature films, including popular franchises like Shrek, Puss in Boots, Madagascar, Kung Fu Panda, How to Train Your Dragon, and Trolls. Other notable films include Monsters vs. Aliens, Rise of the Guardians, The Croods, and Home. The studio also created the Netflix fantasy series Trollhunters.

Christopher Livingstone Eubanks, also known as Chris Eubank, is a British former professional boxer who competed from 1985 to 1998. Christopher Livingstone Eubank Jr., born on 18 September 1989, is a British professional boxer. He has held the IBO super-middleweight title since February 2017 and previously held the WBA interim middleweight title in 2015 and the British middleweight title in 2016. As of May 2017, Eubank Jr. is ranked as the world's fifth-best super middleweight by BoxRec and seventh and eighth best middleweight by The Ring magazine and the Transnational Boxing Rankings Board, respectively.
Sophia Anna Bush is an American actress, director, spokesperson, and activist known for her roles in John Tucker Must Die (2006), The Hitcher (2007), and The Narrows (2008).

Rupert Murdoch is the current chairman and acting CEO of Fox News. He is an Australian, British, American businessman, the younger son of media mogul Rupert Murdoch, who is the CEO of 21st Century Fox and chairman of Sky plc. Rupert Murdoch had full control as Chairman and CEO of global media holding company News Corporation, now the world's second-largest media conglomerate, and its successors, News Corp and 21st Century Fox, after the conglomerate split on 28 June 2013.

Gal Gadot was ranked as the second highest earning actress/model in Israel in 2013, behind Bar Refaeli but ahead of Esti Ginzburg and Shlomit Malka, with the majority of her income coming from acting.
Creedence Clearwater Revival, also known as Creedence or CCR, was an American rock band that was active in the late 1960s and early 1970s.
Calcaneal spurs are detected through x-ray examinations.
The South Wales Coalfield is a region in south Wales known for its abundant coal deposits, particularly in the South Wales Valleys.

The CONCACAF Champions League is an annual football club competition organized by CONCACAF for top clubs in North America, Central America, and the Caribbean. It was first organized in 1962 and was originally known as the CONCACAF Champions ' Cup.

Mary of Teck became queen mother after her eldest son, Edward, ascended the throne in 1936, but he abdicated later that year. She then supported her second son, Albert, who became George VI until his death in 1952. She died the following year during the reign of her granddaughter, Queen Elizabeth II, who had not yet been crowned.
Poseidon, a film, grossed $181,674,817 worldwide, with a budget of $160 million.
The NAACP Image Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Drama Series was first awarded in 1996. Omar Epps and Joe Morton share the record for the most wins, with three each.

Human trafficking is the trade of humans for forced labor, sexual slavery, or commercial sexual exploitation. According to the International Labour Organization (ILO), forced labor alone generates an estimated $150 billion in profits per annum as of 2014. Of the victims, 14.2 million (68%) were exploited for labor, 4.5 million (22%) were sexually exploited, and 2.2 million (10%) were exploited in state-imposed forced labor.
Rio is a 2011 film that has a sequel, Rio 2, released on April 11, 2014.

Francis I, also known as François Ier, was the first King of France from the Angoulême branch of the House of Valois, reigning from 1515 until his death. He was known for his personal involvement in wars against the Holy Roman Emperor and King of Spain, Charles V. When unsuccessful in these wars, he formed a Franco-Ottoman alliance with the Muslim sultan Suleiman the Magnificent, which was controversial for a Christian king. Francis I (Franz Stefan, François Étienne), born on 8 December 1708, was Holy Roman Emperor and Grand Duke of Tuscany, though his wife effectively executed the real powers of those positions. He passed away on 18 August 1765.

Peking University, also known as Běidà, is a major Chinese research university in Beijing and a member of the C9 League. It is the first modern national university in China, founded as the Imperial University of Peking in 1898, replacing the ancient Taixue or Guozijian, or Imperial Academy. It initially served as the highest administration for education in China. Peking University is consistently ranked as the top higher learning institution in mainland China.
Lemmy was known for his friendly mutton chops, gravelly voice, and distinctive bass playing style.
Global warming poses a threat to food security through decreasing crop yields and the potential abandonment of populated areas due to rising sea levels.
The 2008 film Australia, directed by Baz Luhrmann, is a romantic historical adventure drama starring Nicole Kidman and Hugh Jackman.

Michael Dwayne Vick, born on June 26, 1980, is a former American football quarterback who played 13 seasons in the National Football League, primarily with the Atlanta Falcons and the Philadelphia Eagles.

Canadian folklore encompasses a variety of oral traditions, including songs, legends, jokes, rhymes, proverbs, weather lore, superstitions, and practices like traditional food-making and craft-making.
The First Motion Picture Unit produced over 400 propaganda and training films that were both informative and entertaining. The unit also produced training films and trained combat cameramen.

James Jones is both an author and a basketball player. The author won the 1952 National Book Award for his first novel, From Here to Eternity, which was adapted for film and television. The basketball player averaged 25 points per game as a senior, earning Class 6A Player of the Year and First Team All-State honors. He has won three NBA championships, two with the Heat and one with the Cavaliers. In 2017, he and teammate LeBron James reached the NBA Finals for the seventh consecutive year. He finished third in the NBA in three-point percentage during the 2007-08 season and won the Three-Point Contest in 2011.
Humphrey Bogart was ranked as the greatest male star of Classic American cinema by the American Film Institute in 1999.

Computer animation is the process of generating animated images. Trollhunters is an American computer-animated fantasy television series created for Netflix by Guillermo del Toro and produced by DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You.
Shane McMahon announced his resignation from WWE in 2009, which took effect on January 1, 2010.

Tom Baker is an English actor known for his role as the fourth Doctor in Doctor Who from 1974 to 1981, the longest tenure of any actor in the role. He is also known for narrating the comedy series Little Britain and has done voice work for commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.
Angelsberg is a small town located in the commune of Fischbach, in central Luxembourg.

The Hanford Site is home to a commercial nuclear power plant, the Columbia Generating Station, and various scientific research and development centers, including the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory and the LIGO Hanford Observatory.

The White House Press Secretary is a senior official who serves as the spokesperson for the U.S. government and the President. They are appointed by the President and do not require Senate confirmation. Despite being a non-Cabinet position, the role is significant due to the frequent media briefings they give, which inform the public.

Kentucky, known as the Bluegrass State, is famous for its fertile soil and bluegrass pastures. The Bluegrass Region in central Kentucky includes major cities like Louisville and Lexington. The state is renowned for horse racing, bourbon distilleries, coal, the historic site My Old Kentucky Home, automobile manufacturing, tobacco, bluegrass music, college basketball, and Kentucky Fried Chicken.
The 2006 film Broken Bridges stars Toby Keith, Lindsey Haun, Burt Reynolds, and Kelly Preston. Preston also starred in The Cat in the Hat, Old Dogs, and Broken Bridges.
Kesha Rose Sebert, born on March 1, 1987, is an American singer, songwriter, and rapper, previously known as Ke$ha.
The song "Despacito" was released in two versions on May 5, 2017: an electronic version by American trio Major Lazer and Colombian DJ MOSKA, and an urban version by Sky.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event held from 1983 to 2000 by the NWA and later WCW. It was originally broadcast via closed-circuit television and later via pay-per-view. In 1987, the WWF scheduled Survivor Series on Thanksgiving night and demanded exclusivity from cable providers. Starrcade (1985) was the first NWA event to be broadcast on pay-per-view. In 2014, the WWE Network included previous Starrcades (1983-1986) in the pay-per-view section and rated the show as TV-MA due to the violence in the matches. Starrcade (1997) was the fifteenth annual Starrcade professional wrestling pay-per-view event.
Veeru Devgan is an Indian stunt and action choreographer and film director in Bollywood.
Star Trek: Discovery is the first series developed for CBS All Access and the first Star Trek series since Star Trek: Enterprise ended in 2005.

Terry Crews played as a defensive end and linebacker in the NFL for the Los Angeles Rams, San Diego Chargers, and Washington Redskins, as well as in the World League of American Football with Rhein Fire.

Excuse My French is the debut studio album by American rapper French Montana. It is also a 2014 Egyptian film comedy directed by Amr Salama, based on Salama's experiences at a public middle school in Egypt after returning from Saudi Arabia. Benjamin Paul Ballance-Drew, primarily known as Plan B or Ben Drew, is a British hip hop recording artist, actor, film director, and producer.
A floppy disk is a type of disk storage made of a thin, flexible magnetic medium encased in a plastic carrier lined with fabric to remove dust particles.

Guatemala experienced chronic instability and civil strife in the late 19th century. From 1960 to 1996, the country endured a civil war between the US-backed government and leftist rebels, including genocidal massacres of the Maya population by the military.
Forceps are handheld, hinged instruments used for grasping and holding objects. Outside of medicine, they are commonly referred to as tweezers, tongs, pliers, clips, or clamps.
The Closer, a series that finished its sixth season as cable's highest-rated drama, began its seventh and final season on Monday, July 11, 2011.

Dr. Jack Shephard is the protagonist of the ABC television series Lost, played by Matthew Fox. Lost aired on ABC from September 22, 2004, to May 23, 2010, over six seasons and 121 episodes. The first season averaged an estimated 16 million viewers per episode on ABC.

Matthew David McConaughey is an American actor who has been known for his dramatic roles since 2011. Some of his notable films include The Lincoln Lawyer, Bernie, Killer Joe, The Paperboy, Mud, Magic Mike, The Wolf of Wall Street, Dallas Buyers Club, Interstellar, The Sea of Trees, and Free State of Jones.
Robert Palmer is a writer best known for his books, music journalism, blues recording production, and clarinet playing.

James Lincoln de la Mothe Borglum, born on April 9, 1912, and passing away on January 27, 1986, was an American sculptor, photographer, author, and engineer. He is best known for completing the Mount Rushmore National Memorial after his father, Gutzon Borglum, died in 1941. The project was initially led by Gutzon Borglum from 1927 to 1941, with Lincoln Borglum assisting. After his father's death, Lincoln Borglum took over the project.

The film "Underdog" was directed by Frederik Du Chau and written by Joe Piscatella, Adam Rifkin, and Craig A. Williams. The film features live-action actors Jim Belushi, Peter Dinklage, John Slattery, and Patrick Warburton, along with voice talents Jason Lee, Amy Adams, and Brad Garrett.

The 100 is a TV series that follows a group of teens who are among the first people from a space habitat called "The Ark" to return to Earth after a nuclear apocalypse. The series also focuses on several adult characters, including the teens' parents and other prominent figures on the Ark.
The Concert for Bangladesh, a pioneering humanitarian aid project, was highly successful and influential, generating awareness, funds, and valuable lessons for future projects like Live Aid.
Mani Ratnam is an influential Indian filmmaker who has revolutionized the Tamil film industry and changed the profile of Indian cinema.

The Freeport Doctrine was articulated by Stephen A. Douglas on August 27, 1858, in Freeport, Illinois, during the second of the Lincoln-Douglas debates. These debates, also known as The Great Debates of 1858, were a series of seven discussions between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate for the United States Senate from Illinois, and incumbent Senator Stephen Douglas, the Democratic Party candidate. The debates in Freeport, Quincy, and Alton drew especially large crowds as the issue of slavery was of monumental importance to citizens across the nation.

The 2010 American teen comedy film Easy A, directed by Will Gluck and written by Bert V. Royal, stars Emma Stone, Stanley Tucci, Patricia Clarkson, Thomas Haden Church, Dan Byrd, Amanda Bynes, Penn Badgley, Cam Gigandet, Lisa Kudrow, and Aly Michalka.

Anne Rice, born Howard Allen Frances O'Brien on October 4, 1941, is an American author known for gothic fiction, Christian literature, and erotica. She began her career with the publication of Interview with the Vampire in 1976 and wrote sequels in the 1980s. Her early works received mixed reactions, but she gained popularity in the 1980s. Rice was married to Stan Rice for 41 years until his death from brain cancer in 2002.
