Camden is a city in Camden County, New Jersey, with a population of 77,344 as of the 2010 United States Census. It is the 12th most populous municipality in New Jersey. At the beginning of the twentieth century, Camden's population was mostly European immigrants. A city is defined as a large and permanent human settlement.
Bret Easton Ellis wrote the screenplay for the 2013 film The Canyons, an original work that was directed by Paul Schrader.

The Lincoln-Douglas Debates were a series of seven debates between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate for the United States Senate from Illinois, and incumbent Senator Stephen Douglas, the Democratic Party candidate. The debates were held in seven towns in the state of Illinois.

The ancient Greeks ascribed the name Homer to the author of the Iliad and the Odyssey, two epic poems that are central works of ancient Greek literature. Joe R. Lansdale is an American author who wrote the mystery/suspense novel The Thicket.
Christopher Scott Kyle, a United States Navy SEAL veteran and sniper, was murdered by Eddie Ray Routh at a shooting range near Chalk Mountain, Texas, on February 2, 2013.

Audioslave was a four-piece band that included Soundgarden's Chris Cornell and Rage Against the Machine members Tom Morello, Tim Commerford, and Brad Wilk. Wilk is best known for his work with Rage Against the Machine and Audioslave. Rage Against the Machine was formed in 1991 and consists of Zack de la Rocha, Tim Commerford, Tom Morello, and Brad Wilk. As of 2016, Wilk is playing in the band Prophets of Rage with Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B-Real, and DJ Lord.

Janelle Monáe Robinson is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model. She is signed to her own imprint, Wondaland Arts Society, and Atlantic Records. In 2010, she released her critically acclaimed first full-length studio album, The ArchAndroid, a concept album sequel to her first EP, released by Bad Boy Records.
Winter's Tale is a 1983 novel by Mark Helprin.

Lake Providence is a town in East Carroll Parish, northeastern Louisiana, and serves as the parish seat. The University of Mississippi has about 55% of its undergraduates and 60% overall from Mississippi, with 23% being minorities and international students from 90 nations.
The series "Flaked" was renewed for a six-episode second season, which is set to premiere on June 2, 2017.
Aaron Burr was elected twice to the New York State Assembly, served as New York State Attorney General, was a U.S. Senator from New York, and was elected Vice President of the United States.

The Soyuz rocket was commissioned for the Soviet human spaceflight program, with 8 unmanned test flights followed by 19 manned launches. It is a series of spacecraft designed in the 1960s by the Korolyov Design Bureau, now RKK Energia, that remains in service today. The Soyuz succeeded the Voskhod spacecraft and was originally built as part of the Soviet manned lunar programs.
Steve Ditko studied under Batman artist Jerry Robinson at the Cartoonist and Illustrators School in New York City.

Rage Against the Machine disbanded in 2000 due to growing tensions over the band's direction, with de la Rocha starting a solo career and the rest of the band forming the supergroup Audioslave with Chris Cornell. Audioslave recorded three albums before disbanding in 2007. That same year, Rage Against the Machine announced a reunion and performed together for the first time in seven years at the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival.

The S&P BSE SENSEX, also known as the BSE 30 or simply the SENSEX, is a free-float market-weighted stock market index of 30 well-established and financially sound companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange. Tata Motors is listed on the BSE, where it is a constituent of the BSE SENSEX index, as well as being listed on the National Stock Exchange of India and the New York Stock Exchange.

Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, is the easternmost country on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia. It has an estimated population of 92.7 million, making it the 14th-most-populous country in the world and the ninth-most-populous Asian country. Vietnam is bordered by China to the north, Laos to the northwest, Cambodia to the southwest, Thailand across the Gulf of Thailand to the southwest, and the Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia across the South China Sea to the east and southeast. Since 2000, Vietnam's economic growth rate has been among the highest in the world, and in 2011, it had the highest Global Growth Generators Index among 11 major economies. Vietnam remains one of the world's four remaining one-party socialist states officially espousing communism.
The 2005 American sports drama film Dreamer was written and directed by John Gatins in his directorial debut.
Bhagat Singh was a charismatic Indian socialist revolutionary who became a popular folk hero after his death at age 23. He was known for his dramatic acts of violence against the British in India.
Aparshakti Khurana made his Bollywood debut in the 2016 Indian Hindi-language biographical sports drama film Dangal, directed by Nitesh Tiwari and starring Aamir Khan.

James VI and I, also known as James Stuart, was King of Scotland, England, and Ireland. He advocated for a single parliament for Scotland and England. During his reign in England, he faced many difficulties with Parliament.

Danielle Cormack is a New Zealand stage and screen actress known for her roles in Shortland Street, Xena: Warrior Princess, The Cult, Legend of the Seeker, Separation City, Rake, Underbelly: Razor, and Wentworth. She starred in Wentworth for four years before leaving in 2016.
Rob Sheridan, born on October 11, 1979, is an American graphic designer, director, and photographer, best known for his work with the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade is an actor who starred in or co-starred in several films, including Tommy Boy, Black Sheep, Joe Dirt, Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser, Grown Ups, and Grown Ups 2. He also co-wrote Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser with Fred Wolf, who also directed the film.
Angela Evelyn Bassett is an American actress born on August 16, 1958.

Artpop, an album by Lady Gaga, received mixed reviews but was commercially successful, debuting at number one on the US Billboard 200 with first-week sales of 258,000 copies. It became her second consecutive number-one record in the US and sold 757,000 copies. The album was the ninth best-selling album of 2013, with 2.3 million copies sold worldwide.
John Frusciante released his fifth and final album with the Chili Peppers, Stadium Arcadium, in 2006. He confirmed his departure from the band in 2009.
Margaret Thatcher, a controversial figure, served as Prime Minister and has been lauded as one of the greatest and most influential politicians in British history.

Michael Andrew "Duff" McKagan, born on February 5, 1964, is an American musician, singer, songwriter, and author. He has written weekly columns on various topics for SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker is an English actor known for his acting roles as well as his work as a narrator for commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia, also known as València, is the capital of the autonomous community of Valencia and the third largest city in Spain, with around 800,000 inhabitants in the administrative center. It is also the third largest metropolitan area in Spain, with a population ranging from 1.7 to 2.5 million. The Valencian Community, or the Valencian Country, is an autonomous community of Spain.
Buffy Summers was portrayed by Kristy Swanson in the film and later by Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series.
The series "Make It or Break It" ended after three seasons, with the series finale airing on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition (SR) is a sub-field of computational linguistics that develops methodologies and technologies for recognizing and translating spoken language into text by computers. It involves linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering. Applications include voice user interfaces, call routing, domotic appliance control, search, simple data entry, preparation of structured documents, speech-to-text processing, and aircraft. The field has seen significant advances, evidenced by the surge in academic papers and the adoption of deep learning methods by industry players such as Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, Nuance, SoundHound, IflyTek, CDAC, among others.

Richard Alf was an American businessman and former comic book store owner who co-founded the San Diego Comic-Con International and served as its chairman beginning in 1970. The convention was founded as the Golden State Comic Book Convention in 1970 by a group of San Diegans that included Shel Dorf, Richard Alf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry.
Fist of Legend is a remake of the 1972 film Fist of Fury, which starred Bruce Lee as the lead character.

France's Dubuisson and South Africa's Van Zyl are tied for the lead at 16 under par. Rory McIlroy of Northern Ireland is one stroke behind after carding a third straight five under-par 67, including an eagle on the 12th. McIlroy, who is targeting a third Race to Dubai title in four years, had a strong comeback after a double bogey on the 10th hole. English players Chris Wood and Richard Bland are in fifth and seventh place, respectively.

Sheikh Ali Salman emphasized the need for concrete solutions and a willingness to engage in dialogue to address the ongoing crisis in Bahrain. He highlighted the division within the royal family, with Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa seen as a reformist, while hardliners, led by unelected Prime Minister Sheikh Khalifa bin Salman al-Khalifa, opposed the dialogue process. Salman insisted on the importance of dialogue and negotiations, acknowledging the loss of faith among young protesters in the main opposition parties. He recalled a seven-point agreement with the crown prince that was disrupted by the intervention of GCC troops. Salman expressed hope in US Secretary of State John Kerry's potential to advance human rights and democratic practices, while criticizing the UK's private approach to the crisis. He reiterated al-Wefaq's commitment to peaceful demonstrations and called for the release of opposition leaders and human rights activists, emphasizing their crucial role in the dialogue process.

Christopher Hogwood, a leading figure in the early-music movement and founder of the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM), died at his home in Cambridge following a brief illness. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service planned for a later date. Hogwood, known for his influential work with leading orchestras worldwide, was praised for his generosity, academic prowess, and ability to recreate historical musical conditions. He made significant contributions to the AAM, including directing it across six continents for 30 years and producing over 200 CDs, such as the first-ever complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. Hogwood was also a respected educator, serving as a tutor at Harvard University, an honorary professor of music at the University of Cambridge, and a professor-at-large at Cornell University in the US.

The number of homicide victims in Scotland decreased to 57 in the year to March, the lowest number since 1976 and half the figure from nine years ago. A sharp instrument, primarily knives, was the most common method of killing. 31% of the accused were under the influence of alcohol or drugs. While the decrease in homicides is encouraging, caution is advised as figures have been revised upward in the past. Additionally, sexual crimes and violent crime, excluding homicide, have increased.

The Cherries lost 2-1 to Sunderland, becoming the first team to lose to the Black Cats in the Premier League this season. Dan Gosling scored the Cherries' first goal in three games. Despite creating many chances and having a man advantage after Steven Pienaar was dismissed, the Cherries were unable to equalize.

Mr Abbott stated that preventing migrant deaths at sea requires stopping the boats. Australia detains and processes migrants offshore, a policy criticized as inhumane and illegal by the New York Times. Mr Abbott expressed sadness over the death of a Syrian child but defended Australia's policy. He also sparked controversy by comparing IS to the Nazis, a statement criticized by the Executive Council of Australian Jewry.

The US has suspended its participation in bilateral channels with Russia due to Russia and the Syrian government intensifying their attacks against civilians in Syria, particularly in Aleppo. The US had warned it would halt the talks unless Moscow stopped bombing Aleppo. Russia has regretted the US's move and accused it of shifting the blame for the collapse of last month's truce. Hundreds of people, including children, have died since government forces launched an offensive to take full control of Aleppo after the week-long truce lapsed. The main trauma hospital in the rebel-held eastern part of the city was hit in an air strike for the third time in a week. The US has accused Russia and the Syrian government of targeting critical infrastructure such as hospitals and preventing humanitarian aid from reaching civilians in need. In response, Russia has regretted the US's decision and accused it of failing to fulfill the key condition of the agreement to improve the humanitarian condition around Aleppo.

Downing Street supports a report suggesting selling high-value vacant homes to fund 80,000 to 170,000 social homes annually. Labour opposes the idea, arguing it displaces low-wage families and disrupts communities. Policy Exchange claims the plan could create the largest social housing program since the 1970s, reducing social housing waiting lists by 500,000. Critics argue it would force low-income individuals into new ghettos, while supporters claim it would be popular and reduce social housing waiting lists.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, a 25-year-old from Swansea, died last week. The cause of death has not been determined, but he was diagnosed with measles. An inquest will be held to allow further tests. Since the outbreak began in November, 83 people have been hospitalized for the illness. Mr. Colfer-Williams had asthma and was recently treated at Morriston Hospital. He developed a rash a few days after being discharged and was found dead the following morning. Public Health Wales confirmed the measles diagnosis but further tests are needed to determine the cause of death. The family is unsure how he contracted measles as no close family members have it, including his vaccinated three-year-old daughter.

Vincent Hudson, 54, of Loweswater Avenue, Whitehaven, has been charged with a historical sexual offence against a boy under the age of 16. The attack was reported to have taken place in 2001. Hudson is due to appear before North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

Gateshead, chasing promotion in the National League, faced Guiseley in a match that ended in a 1-1 draw. Guiseley took the lead on 15 minutes, but Gateshead equalized in the 62nd minute. The match saw several substitutions and yellow cards for both teams.

Bristol Sport Ltd, the owner of Bristol City FC, plans to replace two stands at their current stadium to increase capacity, as an alternative to building a new stadium at Ashton Vale, which has been delayed by a town green application. The club's majority shareholder, Steve Lansdown, confirmed that work would begin in May, following approval from Bristol City Council in November. The club will sign the section 106 agreement soon and wait six weeks for the judicial review period to pass.

Cuadrilla Resources has suspended fracking operations in Lancashire after a 1.5 magnitude tremor, the second in two months, occurred. The British Geological Survey (BGS) reported that the April tremor occurred 1.2 miles from the drilling site and shared a similar location and mechanism. Mark Miller, CEO of Cuadrilla Resources, stated that the company is taking its responsibilities seriously and will consult with relevant authorities and experts before deciding on further actions. The BGS is monitoring the situation as a precaution, as any process that injects pressurized water into rocks at depth can cause earthquakes. The April tremor was felt by at least one person in Poulton-Le-Fylde, and data from temporary instruments close to the drill site indicate that the event occurred at a depth of approximately 2km.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old Liverpool busker, was found guilty of one count of fraud for playing bagpipes with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner, giving the impression he was collecting funds for the charity. He was cleared of two other counts of fraud. Carpenter, who usually wears a kilt and piper's regalia, claimed he was busking and not collecting funds for the charity. He had permission to display the banner but not to use it for fundraising. Carpenter, a familiar face on match days at Anfield, will be sentenced in January.
23-year-old Wells scored 373 runs in the T20 Blast last season, with a strike rate of 138.66. He praised the club's direction and the elite performance environment created by the coaches.

The Reds, currently fifth in National Two South, defeated third-placed Chinnor 29-12, marking their second consecutive victory. Key players Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams were instrumental in the win, with the front row and front five making over 70 tackles. The Reds face seven teams below them in the next eight games, along with league leaders Old Elthamians. Despite the win, coach Churcher believes there is still room for improvement and emphasizes the importance of building on their recent performance.

The police allege that 28-year-old Nazrul, also known as Nazu, raped a 74-year-old nun. Nazrul, allegedly a Bangladeshi citizen, was arrested at a railway station in Kolkata. The incident caused outrage in India and led to street protests in many cities across the country. This marks the sixth arrest in the crime. Police have identified eight suspects in the attack, of which two still remain untraced. All five previously arrested suspects have named Nazrul as the rapist. Police acted on a tip-off that Nazrul, who had fled to Bangladesh after being identified from CCTV footage of the attack, was due to return to Kolkata by train. In May, the police said they had arrested Milon Sarkar and described him as the leader of the gang which attacked the convent. It was not clear what role he had played in the case. During the attack in Ranaghat town on 14 March, money was stolen from the convent school and the building ransacked, before the nun was raped in the convent itself.

The interactive video by Robert Opie, founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising in London, explains why consumers' purchasing habits change. Factors include the advent of domestic freezers, washing powder, and cheaper imports. The video also explores changes in ownership and ranking of major UK brands. For non-interactive content, click the provided links.

A 71-year-old woman from Sandyhills was tricked by someone claiming to work for BT, while a woman in Stranraer lost money to a caller who claimed to be from BT technical support. The Stranraer incident occurred seven days after the Sandyhills incident. PC Siobhan Pellett emphasized the ease with which these scammers gain access to victims' computers and the substantial sums of money being taken. She urged people to be very careful when answering cold calls from individuals trying to gain remote access to their computers to rectify an alleged fault and advised against giving out any banking details or account numbers over the telephone.

Duffy, 37, has joined Featherstone on a one-year contract after leaving Swinton Lions. He will lead Featherstone in their final league game against Toulouse on Saturday before the upcoming Super 8 Qualifiers. Duffy, who played for Leigh, Widnes, and Salford during a 16-year playing career, has been replaced by his former assistant Stuart Littler at Swinton. Mark Campbell, the chairman of Featherstone, praised Duffy's efforts at Swinton and expressed excitement about his leadership.

A Porthcawl RNLI crew, including a medic and a coastguard search and rescue helicopter, was dispatched to Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve at 12:50 GMT on Sunday. A crew member reported that the injured rider had head injuries and was very cold from lying unconscious on wet sand. The rider was treated at the scene before being flown to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales.

A UN conference in Geneva decided to dedicate part of the radio spectrum to a global flight tracking system, aiming to improve the current ground-based radar system. This decision was influenced by the disappearance of MH370 in 2014, which highlighted weaknesses in the existing system, leaving around 70% of the world's airspace uncovered. The new system will enable satellites to receive transmissions from aircraft, allowing for real-time tracking anywhere in the world. The International Civil Aviation Organisation has set a deadline for adopting new tracking guidelines by November 2016, which will include aircraft sending their position at least every 15 minutes or more frequently in case of emergency.

A boy, Julian Hernandez, who disappeared at the age of five, was found living with his father, Bobby Hernandez, in Cleveland. Bobby Hernandez was arrested after the FBI received a tip that the teenager may be the long-missing child. The agency worked with Alabama police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children to confirm the boy's identity. Bobby Hernandez is charged with tampering with records in Ohio to obtain a driver's licence in 2012. He is being held at the Cuyahoga County Jail in Ohio with a $250,000 bail. Authorities suspected that Bobby Hernandez was possibly the culprit around the time of the boy's disappearance.

Firefighters were at the site in Duncan Street for several days following a fire on 2 March, which reduced train services and caused travel delays. The Environment Agency suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste after the fire. The firm was broadly compliant with fire safety law, according to the fire service. The Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service visited the premises nine times in the last 12 months and raised concerns to the EA in February over the impact a fire could have on nearby residents, transport, and the environment. The EA decided to revoke the environmental permit of Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited, which means the company will no longer be able to operate from that site after 7 August. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

A Just Russia, a pro-Kremlin party, has introduced two bills related to the situation in Ukraine, specifically focusing on the Crimea region. The bills propose that a referendum or a plea from a territory's leaders would be sufficient to trigger the new provisions. The first bill allows for the acceptance of territories whose people have expressed a desire to join Russia, even in times of disintegration. The second bill expedites the process for issuing Russian passports to Ukrainians, removing the requirement for previous residence in Russia, sufficient funds, and Ukrainian citizenship. The bills aim to support Russian-speaking Ukrainians facing what is referred to as the "brown threat," a reference to World War Two fascists.

McLaren, a Formula 1 team with a rich history, has experienced a significant decline in performance since 2013. Despite having two world champions as drivers, the team has struggled with car design and engine issues. The team's last constructors' title was in 1998-99, and they were disqualified from the championship in 2007 due to illegal possession of Ferrari technical information. McLaren's history is marked by cycles of triumph and decline, with the current slump being compared to past downturns. Despite the challenges, team principal Ron Dennis remains optimistic about the team's future, believing that they will return to their winning ways.

Thomas Baker, a 44-year-old man from Everton, was shot and killed at Stanley Meat Market in the Old Swan area of Liverpool on 27 January. The three suspects, all Liverpool men aged 29 and 32, remain in police custody. Merseyside Police reported that Baker had left Phoenix Gym shortly before the shooting while getting into his car. Detectives believe the suspects had been waiting outside the gym for about an hour. A silver VW Polo was seen leaving the scene at speed and is being sought by police. Additionally, several people captured on CCTV near the meat market have yet to come forward with information that could be key to the investigation.

The passage discusses various ways to enjoy Christmas online, including virtual church services, a fantasy game, and social media use by churches. It also mentions the popularity of a Star Wars-themed sermon and the success of a nativity video told through social media updates. Additionally, it highlights the efforts of a charity to share the nativity story through manga-style books, with a focus on reaching refugees.

The eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is examining a request to take over 250 hectares (600 acres) of common land. Backers, including Blaenau Gwent council, have offered around 320 hectares (800 acres) of replacement land. The inquiry has heard conflicting accounts from experts over claims that the circuit would damage habitats and plant life by building on the common land. Natural Resources Wales said it was "difficult to conclude" that the replacement land was of equal value, but it was not opposing the development overall. An ecology report presented by the developers said there would be a "net gain" in biodiversity because the plans included work to enhance other habitats nearby, which the Gwent wildlife trust argued against. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will make a recommendation after the inquiry in Ebbw Vale, before Welsh government ministers have the final say on whether the plans can go ahead.

On 1 April, Novaya Gazeta reported that more than 100 people had been detained in Chechnya on suspicion of being homosexual, and that at least three had been killed. The Chechen Muslim clerics met on 3 April and said the report had insulted their faith and the dignity of Chechen men. The Russian LGBT Network, in touch with victims in Chechnya, told the BBC that the report was true. A spokeswoman for the LGBT Network said detainees were tortured with electric shocks and beatings at a prison near Argun, 20km (13 miles) from the city of Grozny. Chechens have been linked to the murders of two Novaya Gazeta reporters who investigated crimes in Chechnya, Anna Politkovskaya and Natalia Estemirova. The LGBT Network says it is helping people to flee the persecution in Chechnya and accuses the Russian authorities of ignoring the abuses. If Russia fails to prosecute anyone, it says it will file a case at the International Criminal Court in The Hague.

Investing Solutions, a letting agent, and Fresh Start Housing, a charity, have been working together to house single homeless men over the age of 35 in London. The letting agent makes money by putting several unrelated people in one house and charging housing benefit for each person, rather than the property. Fresh Start Housing finds clients from London homeless charities, and neither the charity nor the company act illegally. However, a homeless group says the relationship is "a new low". Investing Solutions is one of the largest recipients of housing benefit in the UK, making the venture hugely profitable. One tenant, Nigel McCann, described the properties he was housed in as wholly unsuitable, with problems including lack of heating and hot water, rats, and damp. He said he became aware of how profitable Investing Solutions was after doing some work for them in 2014. Wandsworth Council in south London has paid the lettings agency more than £2.1m over the past two years.

London 2012 Olympian Andrew Lawrence scored 14 points, and NBA player Ben Gordon added 13. Coach Joe Prunty's team led for most of the first three quarters before being overtaken by the Dutch in the last 10 minutes of a well-contested game. Prunty turned to his strongest lineup in the final warm-up match before cutting the roster for the six-game qualifying program. The Netherlands, led by 18 points from Worthy De Jong, scored the first 10 points of the fourth quarter to lead 71-60 and held on to win despite the hosts' comeback in the last six minutes. Prunty was pleased with Gordon's contribution, who has joined the team despite missing out on a place for London 2012.

The Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) received a necessary waiver from Conor McGregor on Wednesday, hours before the deadline, for the upcoming fight against Floyd Mayweather. The NAC rules state that fights at 154 lbs require 10oz gloves, and the matter will be debated on 16 August. Mayweather had previously stated that he would be wearing 8oz gloves, but had not submitted the necessary waiver at that stage. The NAC's number one policy is the health and safety of the fighters, and any deviation from the regulations would be determined by the chairman and commissioners. McGregor, who has used 4oz gloves in his UFC career, welcomed Mayweather's Instagram post and stated that he was coming "sprinting at you with bricks. Know that. Brittle hands." The NAC will debate the matter publicly before announcing its decision.

J.K. Rowling, the author of the Harry Potter series, has expressed her belief in standing up to bullies on Twitter. She faced criticism for donating £1m to the campaign for a No vote in the Scottish independence referendum. Rowling revealed that she had been called a traitor for her political views and had blocked some abusive Twitter users who she believed were supporters of the Scottish National Party (SNP). Despite this, she also engaged in positive discussions with SNP supporters and found common ground with many of them.

The University of Edinburgh's study found that children from deprived backgrounds are twice as likely to face police action for the same crimes as their better-off counterparts. Poverty increases the likelihood of violence among both boys and girls, and a history of being in trouble with the police is the strongest predictor of whether a young person is not in education, employment, or training by age 18. Poorer young people are about five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision than their better-off counterparts. The study also found that household poverty increases the likelihood of young people offending, even when other risk factors are considered. Boys are three times more likely than girls to engage in violent acts, and girls from poorer backgrounds are twice as likely as girls from more affluent households to be involved in violent crime. The findings highlight that poverty increases the risks of violence, and contact with the juvenile justice system increases the risks associated with poverty. The study suggests that the recent fall in crime rates in Scotland has not benefitted areas with the most chronic rates of crime, as victims of the most crime continue to be within the most deprived communities.

Mr Haugh, 25, was stabbed in a laneway in the Marian estate in the early hours of Sunday. Robbie Walsh was charged with assault causing serious harm to Mr Haugh and has been remanded in custody. Two other men arrested over the killing were released without charge. It is alleged that Mr Walsh and two others entered the estate looking for Mr Haugh, leading to a fight where Mr Haugh was fatally stabbed. A knife handle and blade were recovered at the scene.

Fermanagh MLA Phil Flanagan tweeted in May 2014, questioning Tom Elliott's past as a member of the UDR, suggesting he may have harassed and shot people. Elliott, who served in the UDR for 10 years and now serves as MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone, has a clear MoD record. The tweet was deleted within an hour, and Flanagan apologized, admitting the tweet was untrue. The apology must be posted on Twitter before the end of Friday. The High Court heard the case on Friday, with the insurance firm refusing to cover Flanagan for compensation and costs. Elliott expressed disappointment at the delay but was delighted with the result, stating he has been totally vindicated.

Hawick Knitwear, established in 1874 and recently acquired by managing director Benny Hartop, has increased its production of sweaters to 9,500 per week from 7,500 due to high demand. The company supplies private label garments to customers in Europe and worldwide, with the recent launch of its Hawick Knitwear-branded range contributing to the increased sales. The company employs over 230 staff and has seen growth in both its new and established business lines.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries in an accident outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. Brian Wright, 55, of Kempston, is charged with causing serious injury by dangerous driving. Wright claims he was blinded by the setting sun and failed to stop at a red light. Mrs. Blackburn is now in residential care. Wright expressed deep remorse for the incident, stating he has thought of nothing else since it happened. The trial continues.

South Sudan, the world's youngest country, is on the brink of genocide and ethnic cleansing, with violence spreading and causing a mass exodus of refugees into neighboring Uganda. Over 340,000 South Sudanese have fled to Uganda, with 2,500 more crossing the border daily. The violence is primarily between the Dinka and Nuer tribes, with Equatorians becoming targets since July. Despite the influx, Uganda has managed to provide refugees with land and resources to start anew. However, the country is beginning to struggle with the sheer number of refugees, as supplies like water are scarce. The international community is being urged to intervene and pressure South Sudan's leaders to end the violence.

McKenzie, a former footballer turned professional boxer, will fight Jahmaine Smyle at York Hall on 12 November for the English super-middleweight championship. He has a record of eight wins and one draw from his nine fights. McKenzie is the son of former British and European champion Clinton and is trained by his uncle, former three-time world champion Duke McKenzie.

Bridgwater Community Hospital is set to be replaced as part of a £330m investment in new NHS facilities across England. The new hospital will have 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, and space for X-ray and mobile scanners. The current hospital, built in 1813, is cramped and outdated, with maintenance issues. The new hospital will cost £33m, with the remaining balance paid by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust. Construction is expected to be completed by autumn 2014, with planning permission pending.

A man was fatally shot outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, close to the city centre. The victim was found with a gunshot wound to his chest and was taken to Northern General hospital, where he died from his injuries. The man was either in or close to a black Mercedes car he had been driving when he was shot. The victim was a member of a family who live close to the scene of the shooting, and relatives had been gathering for a family celebration when the attack occurred. There have been a number of shootings in Sheffield in recent weeks, although all the previous incidents have been in the north of the city and not close to the Upperthorpe area.

The passage describes the activities of three hacker groups: Ukrainian Cyber Troops, Cyber Berkut, and Anonymous International. Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, are known for their DDoS attacks and hacking into Russian servers and email accounts. They also monitor CCTV systems in rebel-held areas and have hijacked network printers to spread pro-Ukrainian messages. Cyber Berkut, on the other hand, is a pro-Russian group that has hacked Ukrainian government websites and electronic billboards. They claim to have leaked confidential documents and disrupted electronic vote-counting systems. Anonymous International, known for publishing leaked Kremlin documents, focuses on Russia's domestic affairs but has also covered Ukraine, leaking information about the separatist forces and Igor Girkin, a key rebel commander.

Tricia Marwick, the presiding officer, was visibly emotional after Duncan McNeil and Alex Salmond gave their farewell speeches to the parliament. Salmond, who served as first minister between 2007 and 2014, used his valedictory address to express his belief that Scotland was not divided but diverse. He welcomed the transfer of powers to Holyrood under the Scotland Bill but insisted it did not fulfill the pledges made by unionist politicians in the last days of the referendum campaign. McNeil, who served in the parliament since its establishment in 1999, used his address to warn that Holyrood had things to learn from Westminster, particularly with regard to the committee system. He said it was the parliament's responsibility to ensure there was accountability, scrutiny, and even opposition when necessary.

Older People's Commissioner for Wales Sarah Rochira is conducting a review on the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales. She aims to gather experiences from pensioners, their families, and friends to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. Rochira emphasizes the importance of hearing from older people and those who care for them. She has observed positive impacts of high-quality care and expresses concern over variations in care quality across Wales. The review will assess factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. While Care Forum Wales supports the review's aims, they criticize the lack of representation from care home providers on the advisory panel.

Harbro Group, an Aberdeenshire-based company, saw a pre-tax profit increase of £800,000 to £3.5m in the year to the end of June 2016, despite a £1m fall in turnover to just over £100m. International sales grew over the year, both in Europe and in new markets further afield. The company manufactures and supplies feeds for the beef, sheep, dairy, pig, and poultry sectors and has a network of 19 shops across Scotland, operating under the Country Store brand. The stores cater to farming and rural communities with a range of products, including fireside supplies, country clothing, and footwear. The company said in accounts filed with Companies House that the outlook for agriculture is difficult to predict, but the industry is robust. The impact of Brexit is still to be fully understood, but the board is confident that the group will be well-positioned for whatever business challenges this may bring about.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house in Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted, on Saturday afternoon. A man in his 80s was taken to hospital. Detectives want to question 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin, also known as Ian John Baker, and have warned people not to approach him. The investigation is still in its early stages, but the death is being treated as murder. McLoughlin is described as white, about 6ft (1.8m) tall, with straight, greying, collar-length hair and of average build. He is believed to have been wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter length trousers and a dark blue, light blue and white checked short-sleeved shirt with a button-down collar. Anyone with information has been urged to contact police or Crimestoppers. Officers have been conducting additional patrols in the area to provide reassurance to residents.

The IMF's latest assessment of the global economy indicates a weakening trend, with a likely downgrade of the 3.4% global growth forecast in April. This assessment follows weaker-than-expected trade figures from China, where exports dropped by 25% year-on-year.

The council leader, Dave Stewart, announced that the ferry crossing at Cowes would be free until 2 July due to the problems the new vessel has faced. The council has ordered a review of the project by auditors, as the ferry has faced issues such as breakdowns, running aground, and suspension due to training issues, as well as causing damage to cars. Shopkeeper Angie Booth expressed concerns about the impact on local businesses, asking if they would receive compensation similar to that for damaged cars. Transport councillor Ian Ward acknowledged the issues as teething problems and stated that compensation was under discussion. He also mentioned that ramp extensions were authorized to address vehicle scraping and that seamanship issues had been resolved.

A multi-vehicle crash occurred on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott at about 07:30 GMT on Thursday. A 32-year-old man was pronounced dead at the scene. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road was closed between Thursley and Liphook until early evening while officers investigated the scene.

Matching Models, an international temp agency, posted job ads for a personal assistant and a female driver with specific physical attributes, which the Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) called "appalling, unlawful, and demeaning to women." The EHRC's chief executive, Rebecca Hilsenrath, stated that the agency would be asked to clarify its hiring practices. The Fawcett Society's chief executive, Sam Smethers, said the ads were "straight out of the 1970s" and "almost certainly fall foul of equality legislation." Employment lawyer James Lynas said the ads were "clearly unlawful" and could be discriminatory against older women. Matching Models' founder, Nathalie Jansen, defended the ads, stating that "looks are important" and that the agency had hired 5,000 people worldwide, including for clients like MTV, Louis Vuitton, Coca-Cola, the Renault Formula 1 team, and Harrods.

A shooting occurred at a hostel attached to the private Pragati Residential School in Bangalore city. The alleged gunman, Mahesh, was working as an office assistant at the school. He is accused of shooting two female students, killing one and severely injuring the other. Mahesh was arrested after a manhunt and is currently remanded until 12 April. The motive for the shooting is unclear.

Glaad's analysis of shows from June 2016 to May 2017 found 278 LGBT characters, with the number of transgender characters rising from seven to 16. However, more than 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters were killed off, including Poussey Washington in Orange is the New Black and Bea Smith in Wentworth. The report also noted a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television, thanks to shows like Empire, Luke Cage, and How to Get Away with Murder. Glaad's president Sarah Kate Ellis said it was "heartening to see progress being made" but emphasized that numbers were "only part of the story."

David Mackintosh, the Conservative MP for Northampton South, announced his decision to step down ahead of a local party meeting where his candidacy was expected to be challenged. The BBC reported that millions of pounds of public money loaned to Northampton Town FC appeared to have vanished. Mackintosh, who was the leader of the borough council at the time, was criticized over the loan to Northampton Town Football Club to rebuild Sixfields stadium and develop nearby land. About £10.25m of the loan is now missing and is subject to a police investigation into alleged financial irregularities. The football stand remains half-built. A majority of his party's local executive council said they would vote to deselect him when contacted by the BBC last week. In a statement, Mackintosh said, "It has been a huge honour to be the member of Parliament since 2015, but I now feel it is the right time for my constituents to have a new representative."

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old police officer, fired a rifle into a car carrying five teenagers, killing 15-year-old Jordan Edwards. The incident occurred in April when police responded to reports of underage drinking at a house party in Balch Springs, a suburb of Dallas. Oliver was fired from the police force a few days later for policy violations. He is currently free on bail and faces five to 99 years in prison if convicted of murder. If convicted, he would be the first police officer convicted of murder in Dallas county since 1973. The Edwards family's lawyer expressed caution, noting the rarity of police convictions in Texas.

A 72-year-old man died in Inverness on 27 October. The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc), Kate Frame, is investigating the initial police response to the man's call. Police Scotland is cooperating with the investigation, and Pirc will submit a report to the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS) upon completion.

A yellow warning of wind was issued, predicting gusts of up to 75mph, particularly west of the mountains, with an unusual easterly direction potentially increasing the impact. Disruption to travel on roads and at sea is likely in the counties of Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys. A tree fell in Menai Bridge on Anglesey, closing one of the main routes into the town, with the council expecting Telford Road to remain closed for most of Monday for clean-up work.

The Giants, led by player-coach Derrick Walser, faced the Panthers in a game where Jeff Dimmen scored to tie the game. The Giants took the lead in the second period with a powerplay goal by Mike Forney, but Andy Bohmback equalized for the Panthers. Mike Radja and James Desmarais scored for the Giants, while David Ling scored for the Panthers. The Giants and Panthers are set to meet again on Saturday night. Nottingham leads the league with 28 points, followed by Sheffield Steelers with 27 and Belfast with 25.

The Chinese Grand Prix was marked by an incident-packed opening, with several collisions on the first lap leading to the introduction of the safety car on lap four. World champion Hamilton started from the back, suffered a broken front wing on lap one, and did five pit stops. Despite colliding with his team-mate, Sebastian Vettel came second. Ferrari's decision to use soft tires for the final stint gave them an advantage over Mercedes. Hamilton faces an uphill battle to overcome a 36-point deficit in the remaining 18 races of the season.

Thomas Hitzlsperger, a prominent footballer, came out as gay to advance the discussion of a topic that was "simply ignored" in German football. His former teammates and leading figures in German football administration praised his announcement, seeing it as a courageous and important step in the fight against homophobia in football. Hitzlsperger's announcement is seen as a watershed moment in Germany, which has struggled with homophobia in football. The German FA is now urged to embolden active players to follow suit and break down this taboo.

Sidwell, a 34-year-old midfielder, has played a crucial role in Brighton's promotion to the Premier League, making 32 Championship appearances. With his contract ending this season, he hopes to sign a new deal to continue contributing to the team's success in the Premier League. Sidwell has previously played in the Premier League with several clubs and believes he deserves another chance at the top level. He has expressed confidence in Brighton's ability to stay in the Premier League and is eager to finalize a new contract.

Blackpool and Colchester United played to a 1-1 draw. Nathan Delfouneso scored for Blackpool in the 12th minute, and Kurtis Guthrie equalized for Colchester United in the 23rd minute. Blackpool had several chances to win the game, including a header from Tom Aldred that went wide in the 75th minute. Colchester United finished the game with 10 men after Sean Murray was shown a red card in injury time.

The 29-year-old player made 37 appearances for the Sky Blues last season, which ended in relegation from League One. He has also had spells with Charlton, Bradford, and Preston. He could make his debut for the U's in the EFL Cup first-round tie against Championship side Aston Villa on Wednesday. Colchester started the season with a 3-1 defeat at Accrington on Saturday.

PC Keith Palmer's murder prompted a call for a permanent memorial to honor over 1,400 officers and staff who have lost their lives in the line of duty. The UK Police Memorial Trust is seeking £1.5m towards the construction of the memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum, which will include a brass screen with leaf shapes given to the families of fallen officers. The government has committed £1m towards the £4m needed for the memorial, which is expected to be completed by 2019.

Manchester United won 1-0 at Sunderland, maintaining a 15-point lead at the top of the table with eight games left. Manager Sir Alex Ferguson emphasized focusing on upcoming games, including the derby against Manchester City. Despite injuries to Rafael, Anderson, and David De Gea, Ferguson expressed confidence in the team's depth and determination. Changes are expected for the FA Cup quarter-final replay at Chelsea, with key players returning from injury and international duty.

Google paid Â£10m in UK corporate taxes between 2006 and 2011. Mr Schmidt said it was up to the government to change its tax system if it wanted companies to pay more taxes. He said that paying taxes is not optional and that Google will comply with whatever the tax system dictates. Margaret Hodge, head of the Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee, suggested a new committee should be established to oversee the tax arrangements of major firms. Google, most of whose UK sales are routed through Ireland, is one of the multinationals strongly criticized for organizing their tax affairs in ways that minimize the amounts they pay in the UK. European Union leaders agreed to tackle tax avoidance through an "automatic information exchange between tax authorities" to monitor the situation. Mr. Schmidt has previously argued that corporate taxes should be levied in the country where it conducts economic activity and takes risks, rather than where products are consumed. He has also called for a debate on international tax reform.

NHS Improvement is pushing for further progress in reducing the NHS agency bill, which amounted to £3.6bn last year. A cap introduced in October has saved £600m so far, limiting payments for agency staff to 55% above normal shift rates, excluding senior managers. Despite this, the NHS is behind schedule in achieving its target, with a shortfall of 10%. NHS Improvement aims to enhance transparency by publishing league tables of trust performance and scrutinizing high earnings among agency staff.

The Longford Town Centre, once a symbol of Ireland's economic boom, now represents the aftermath of the Celtic Tiger's fall. Local traders, like Matt O'Brien, have experienced a downturn in business but are beginning to see signs of recovery. Despite this, they believe more could be done to support local businesses, such as eliminating parking charges. The government points to the Center Parcs development as a positive step, promising job creation, but local opposition parties and traders argue that more targeted investments are needed, such as improved broadband infrastructure.

The competition finishes on 29 May in the same stadium. There are eight teams taking part, facing each other twice, with the top four sides qualifying for the play-offs. Leading run-scorers: Warner (294), Kohli (267), De Villiers (249), Most sixes: Warner (12), De Villiers (12), Kohli (8), Highest score in an innings: De Kock (108), Warner (90*), Gambhir (90*), Most wickets: McClenaghan (9), Kumar (8), Rahman (7). Four current or former England players will take part in the tournament: Eoin Morgan will play for Sunrisers Hyderabad, Jos Buttler is with Mumbai Indians, Sam Billings plays for Delhi Daredevils, Kevin Pietersen will play for Rising Pune Supergiants.

The number of plastic carrier bags in England has increased by 200 million since 2013. These bags often end up in landfills and rivers, causing environmental problems. From October, people in England will have to pay 5p for plastic bags to encourage reuse. This charge has already led to a decrease in bag use in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland. Campaigners hope the charge in England will reduce the number of bags being thrown away and help the environment.

A school roof was partially ripped off in Rhosgadfan, Gwynedd, causing power cuts to hundreds of homes across Wales. The adverse weather also led to train delays, speed and lane restrictions on major bridges, and cancellations of Irish Ferries fast sailings between Holyhead and Dublin. The National Trust closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle in Wrexham due to the expected high winds. Winds eased into Friday evening, but a blustery forecast for the Christmas weekend has led to the postponement of Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip in the sea.

The Hollywood Reporter interviewed Michael B. Jordan, who expressed excitement about his new role in the film Black Panther, which will be directed by Ryan Coogler. Jordan also mentioned his eagerness to work with Lupita Nyong'o and Chadwick Boseman. The film is set to be released in February 2018.

The theatre, founded in 1875, is set to be used for theatrical performances, cinema screenings, comedy, and live music. The BBC studios will also be repaired and refurbished. The theatre and studios are part of a larger east wing restoration project to transform Alexandra Palace into a new cultural destination. The Heritage Lottery Fund is contributing £18.8m, and Haringey Council is contributing £6.8m towards the £26.6m project. The theatre, which has been unused for decades, still has much of its original decor and stage machinery in place.

James Milner, a 30-year-old former Manchester City player, won 61 caps for England after making his senior debut in 2009. He was a squad member at two World Cups and two European Championships but only played three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner also holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player, with 46 caps. He scored his first and only international goal in a 5-0 victory over Moldova at the 2014 Fifa World Cup qualifiers.

Marcy Smith and her family escaped a house fire in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, thanks to her son David, who was awake on FaceTime with his father and noticed the flames. The family lost their house and pets in the fire, which was caused by burning rubbish in the wood stove. Despite the tragedy, the community has supported them with donations of clothing and other essentials.

The energy drinks giant is considering a £200m offer for West Ham United, which Sullivan and Gold bought in 2010 for £105m. They now own more than 85% of the club, which moved to London Stadium in August. The club has also been linked with takeovers from Qatari and Chinese groups, and Sullivan mentioned the possibility of selling a minority shareholding to clear debts, although he and Gold intend to pass ownership on to their children.

The 2015 MTV Movie Awards, held in Los Angeles, was a night of fan-voted awards, including best kiss and best shirtless performance, with Zac Efron winning the latter. The Fault in Our Stars was the big winner, taking home best movie, while its star Shailene Woodley won best female performance, the Trailblazer Award, and best kiss. Other winners included Bradley Cooper, Channing Tatum, Meryl Streep, Jennifer Lopez, Jennifer Lawrence, Seth Rogen, and Rose Byrne. Kevin Hart brought his kids on stage to accept the comedic genius award, emphasizing his desire to leave a legacy for them. The event also served as an unofficial promotional platform for upcoming summer blockbusters, with clips from Pitch Perfect, Trainwreck, and Ultron shown.

Cammy Smith, a 21-year-old player, was loaned to United by the Dons in July. He has scored five goals this season and has four goals in 89 appearances for Aberdeen. St. Mirren's boss, Jack Ross, expressed his excitement about acquiring Smith, stating that he is a good player and a good fit for the team, providing another option in the attacking area. St. Mirren, who are at the bottom of the Championship, will host Falkirk on Saturday.
Northumberland County Council is using Jetpatcher machines to fill 145 potholes daily for the next four months. Additionally, extra staff will repair drainage systems and clear debris from gutters.

In December 2016, six Wood Group contractors on EnQuest's Thistle platform, off Shetland, were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) while removing pipework. The exposure was less than 1% of the level reportable to the Health and Safety Executive (HSE), but the workers were not informed until two-thirds of the way through their shift. The workers, who have since faced cancer fears and are undergoing blood tests, claim they were not provided with the proper personal protective equipment (PPE). EnQuest and Wood Group have since taken additional precautionary measures to prevent future exposure. The Unite union has criticized the handling of the incident, emphasizing the importance of transparency in workplace safety incidents. The HSE was aware of the incident but did not carry out an investigation as it was not reportable under the RIDDOR system.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) bought the bronze sculpture of Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari for $650,000 from New York dealer Art of the Past in 2007. The sculpture is believed to have been stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu, India. The decision to return the sculpture was made after discussions between Singapore's National Heritage Board and the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), following the manager of Art of the Past confessing to trafficking looted Indian antiquities. The ACM will take legal action for compensation for the apparent fraud.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck 35km north of Lucca at a depth of 15.5km, felt as far away as Milan and Florence, with no immediate reports of injuries or damage. Italy is prone to earthquakes, with a significant one in L'Aquila in 2009 resulting in almost 300 deaths and six scientists and an ex-official convicted of manslaughter for providing falsely reassuring information. The recent earthquake caused phone lines and power supplies to be cut in the Garfagnana area, with schools evacuated and checked for damage. The tremor was also felt in Bologna and Modena, with people pouring into the streets in Lucca.
The fruit is still attached to the plant and not yet ripe enough to eat. Austin Grant from Sheffield had doubts about the suitability of South Yorkshire's climate, but has finally seen some results.

Rockstar has delayed the release of the latest version of the open-world adventure game until 24 March. The delay is to allow for additional testing and polish. The company also announced that online heists are coming to consoles before the PC release. Screenshots from the PC version have been released, promising greater detail and support for up to 4K resolution. The minimum specifications required to run the game have also been published.

The 76-year-old artist, Simpson, won the Â£25,000 prize for his painting, Squint (19), at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery. Simpson has been a shortlisted artist for the John Moores Painting Prize, one of Britain's oldest art awards, on multiple occasions. Judge Ansel Krut described Squint (19) as "quite extraordinary" and "a difficult painting to look at" but also "a little bit like a tone poem" that gradually builds a picture. Simpson plans to spend the prize money on materials for his art.

The Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit offices were attacked by four masked assailants in the early hours of Thursday. The Yeni Safak building was set on fire, but firefighters quickly extinguished it. The Yeni Akit offices are located 20km away from the Yeni Safak building, and both attacks occurred almost simultaneously. Windows in both buildings were shattered by gunfire, and numerous spent bullet casings were found at both scenes. No group has claimed responsibility for the attacks.

A 24-year-old player, who spent the first half of the season on loan at Crawley, scoring three goals in 23 appearances, will officially join the Stags on 1 January. The ex-Burton player becomes Bignot's first signing for the Mariners.

Arsene Wenger has been linked to the England manager job, but he is focused on his current role at Arsenal. Gareth Southgate, the current interim manager, has the opportunity to secure the position permanently with upcoming matches. Wenger also addressed speculation about Hector Bellerin's future, stating that the defender would be offered a new contract. Additionally, Aaron Ramsey is expected to miss one or two more games due to a hamstring injury.

A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker around 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police and the Health and Safety Executive are jointly investigating the incident, with the company fully cooperating.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced a new charter arrangement to resolve a long-running dispute over seafarers' pay, with contracted services returning to Serco Northlink from next month. The RMT union had claimed that workers on board two freight boats were paid less than £4 an hour, with Seatruck, the operator contracted by Serco Northlink, arguing that the national minimum wage did not apply to the crew, many of whom are non-UK residents. Serco Northlink had offered to bridge the pay gap and backdate it, but Seatruck declined to accept. The new arrangement will see all crew members paid at least the minimum wage, with the agreement in principle subject to financial and regulatory details being finalised. Serco Northlink was awarded a six-year £243m contract in 2012 to operate three ferries and two cargo boats to the Northern Isles on a heavily subsidised route by the Scottish government.

Ken Dickie, 64, died in hospital on 14 May, six days after an incident at the Rockley Park site in Poole. Jamie Mitchell, 35, admitted intervening in an argument between Mr Dickie and his mother. He was visibly shaken after a jury at Winchester Crown Court found him guilty. The trial heard that Mr Mitchell had been in a relationship with Mrs Mitchell for several years and they were going through a "down phase" when Mr Mitchell visited his mother on 7 May. Mr Mitchell got "tanked up" on alcohol at the holiday park bar and had a confrontation with Mr Dickie outside, which was broken up by members of the public. Mr Mitchell had pleaded guilty to common assault in relation to the fight. He and his mother Samantha, 57, also admitted attempting to pervert the course of justice by lying about the course of events. The pair will be sentenced on 6 February.

Rod Temperton, a British songwriter known as The Invisible Man, passed away at 66 after a brief battle with cancer. He was best known for writing hits like Off The Wall, Baby Be Mine for Michael Jackson, and Boogie Nights for his band Heatwave. Temperton's songwriting prowess was influenced by his father, who played Radio Luxembourg to him as a child. He won a Grammy Award in 1990 for his work on Birdland and was nominated for two Oscars in 1986 for his work on The Color Purple soundtrack. Temperton's private funeral has already taken place, and his family has requested privacy during this difficult time.

Dr. Neil Loader and Emeritus Prof Alayne Street-Perrott, along with a team of researchers from various universities, discovered ancient earthworks in Acre state, western Brazilian Amazon. These earthworks, possibly 2,000 years old, were hidden by bamboo-dominated rainforest until modern deforestation revealed them. The function of these geoglyphs is still not well understood, as they do not appear to be villages or defensive structures. Instead, they may have been used as ritual gathering places, similar to the Maya pyramids or Stonehenge. Dr. Loader's analysis of soil samples suggests that the geoglyphs were built among taller vegetation, unlike other ritual sites. The research also indicates that the Amazonian forests were not pristine ecosystems before the arrival of Europeans, as previously thought. Instead, humans transformed the environment by concentrating on economically valuable trees, similar to a prehistoric supermarket. The team suggests that the biodiversity of some of Acre's remaining forests may still reflect these ancient agroforestry practices.

Nick Kyrgios, ranked 12th in the world, defeated world number 29 Sam Querrey 6-4 6-4 in 53 minutes to progress to the second round. Kyrgios cited tiredness and boredom as reasons for not being his usual vocal self. He attributed his fatigue to his recent success in Japan and the traveling involved in playing at the Qi Zhong Stadium, an hour from Shanghai city centre. Last year at the Shanghai Masters, Kyrgios was fined $1,500 for a foul-mouthed outburst, describing the tournament as a "circus".

The human papilloma virus (HPV) jab is believed to protect against head and neck cancers, in addition to cervical cancer. The Welsh government is currently awaiting advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation regarding the expansion of the vaccination programme to include boys. Charities and medical organisations are urging the government to take this step, highlighting the increasing number of head and neck cancer cases, which are affecting younger people, particularly men, and are more prevalent among non-smokers. The HPV virus is responsible for 5% of global cancer cases. In 2008, a vaccination programme was introduced for girls aged 12 and 13, with 85% of Welsh girls now vaccinated.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old West Calder High School pupil, was diagnosed with a rare form of blood cancer called gamma delta T-cell lymphoma in August. Despite his illness, Jak maintained a positive attitude and documented his life and treatment on social media through the Jak's Journey Facebook page, which attracted over 28,000 Likes. Jak briefly attended a school prom held in his honor on Saturday but had to leave due to illness. He was greeted at the event by former Rangers captain Barry Ferguson. Jak's family collected his Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy for overcoming adversity at the party. Jak passed away, and his story touched the hearts of many people in West Lothian and beyond.

Egypt scored a late goal against Uganda, with Mohamed Salah assisting Abdallah El Said in the 89th minute. The win keeps Egypt in contention for the top spot in Group D, while Uganda is eliminated from their first tournament since 1978. The game was marked by a disallowed goal for Uganda due to offside and a strong defensive performance from the Cranes. Egypt will face Ghana on Wednesday, with top spot still at stake, while Uganda will play Mali.

Lancashire County Council has identified two potential sites for a new railway station in Skelmersdale, a former sports college and an unused college campus. The decision follows a comparative study by Network Rail. The council plans to partner with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council to establish two direct trains to Liverpool per hour. County councillor John Fillis, cabinet member for highways and transport, described the decision as an "exciting step forward" and emphasized the preferred location's potential for future expansion, good highway access, and connectivity. The authority will now begin the process of acquiring the relevant land. Skelmersdale, designated a new town in 1961, is one of the largest towns in the north west of England without its own railway station.
A man in his late 40s was arrested after police found plants in an elaborate grow house during a search of a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning.

A 28-year-old German woman of Kurdish origin was found with serious injuries on a pavement in Hamelin, Lower Saxony, after being dragged by the neck through several streets. Her ex-partner, a 38-year-old man from nearby Bad Muender, handed himself in to authorities. The motive for the attack is not yet clear, and police are calling for witnesses to come forward.

The study found that women are as likely as men to ask for a pay rise, contradicting the "reticent female" theory. However, men are 25% more likely to receive a pay rise when they ask for one. The study, which compared full-time and part-time male and female workers, found no evidence that women are less likely to ask for a pay rise due to fear of upsetting their boss or deviating from a perceived female stereotype. The research considered factors such as employer size, industry, parenthood, and qualifications. The study was based on data from the 2013-14 Australian workplace relations survey. The researchers suggested that there may be an element of pure discrimination against women in pay negotiations. The study also found that women and men under 40 ask for and receive pay rises at the same rate, suggesting that negotiating behavior may be changing.

Oxford City Council has been searching for a new burial site for many years but has not found a suitable location. Two cemeteries are still available but are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021. The council has not given up and is still exploring options. The last increase in burial space in Oxford was in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) will take place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July. Visitors to the festival will be able to use an app to trigger online information from items such as signs and posters on the site. Videos and band interviews will be among the online material available to view on phones and tablets. The app will also allow people around the world to interact with the festival and capture a flavour of its atmosphere at any time. The message will be updated in the run-up to HebCelt and during the event, allowing people to instantly access information and interviews, buy tickets, and get a taste of the unique festival wherever they are.

A 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, Many Clouds, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed that the horse suffered from a severe pulmonary haemorrhage. Despite the rarity of such incidents, the authorities are determined to understand the causes and prevent such occurrences in the future. Many Clouds had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia but had never collapsed before. The horse had no significant underlying health issues, and questions have been raised about whether a previous condition was linked to his death. However, the report concludes that the cause of death was a rare haemorrhage on the racetrack.

A 15-year-old girl met David Ayrton in a Portsmouth garage in 2004. Ayrton, now 34 and called Davina, denied the charge of rape. Ayrton, who has learning difficulties, attempted suicide last summer. Ayrton spoke about her sexuality during the trial and said she had not made any physical changes or taken any medication. Ayrton raped the teenager while two others were asleep in the garage. Ayrton will be sentenced on 4 March and is likely to be held in a male prison in Winchester.

The Serbs lost to Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio with a score of 6-4, 6-4. This loss came a day after Djokovic was knocked out of the singles by Argentine Juan Martin del Potro. Djokovic is the world number one and 29 years old. He suffered a surprise third-round defeat at Wimbledon in July when he lost to American Sam Querrey. However, he came back to claim his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics.

More than 20 carvers from various countries will compete in the event in Carrbridge, Cairngorms, using only chainsaws to carve logs into animal and human shapes. Pete Bowsher, the previous year's winner, will return to defend his title and the Claymore Trophy.

Webb, a Welsh rugby player, has been out of play since suffering a foot injury in September. He is now close to a return and is going through a pre-season stage. He is aiming to return at the beginning of February, with the hope of scraping a couple of weeks off his recovery time. Webb has renewed his national dual contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, turning down other offers to stay with his home region. He is set to play for Wales in the Six Nations campaign against Ireland on 7 February.

On Tuesday morning, US border agents encountered two men carrying backpacks near the Canadian border in Sumas, Washington. One of the men ran and fired a weapon at the agents, while the other, Jeffrey Laviolette, was taken into custody. A search for the fugitive led to the arrest of Nathan Hall in British Columbia. The backpacks carried by Hall and Laviolette contained a total of 58 pounds (26 kg) of MDMA. Investigators also arrested Kali Henifin and her boyfriend Ryan Lambert, who were allegedly involved in the smuggling operation. The three defendants face conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution charges. The area where the incident occurred is a known smuggling route for drugs and firearms.

The NSPCC's Childline service reported a significant increase in the number of children seeking help for online abuse, with over 4,500 children counselled in the past year compared to about 2,400 in 2011-12. The charity emphasized the growing problem of cyber-bullying, which can cause misery and humiliation for thousands of children. The president of Childline, Dame Esther Rantzen, called the figures a wake-up call and stressed the importance of adults, parents, and teachers intervening to protect children from cyber-bullying. The report was released at the start of Anti-Bullying Week, coordinated by the Anti-Bullying Alliance, which is working with parents, schools, and other organizations to combat the problem.

The US abstained from a UN Security Council vote calling for an end to Israeli settlement construction, which infuriated Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. More than 500,000 Jews live in settlements in the West Bank and East Jerusalem, which are considered illegal under international law. Netanyahu recalled Israel's ambassadors to New Zealand and Senegal, cut aid to Senegal, and cancelled a visit by Ukraine's prime minister in response to the resolution. The Jerusalem Planning and Housing Committee postponed a vote on authorizing 492 new homes in two settlements at the request of Netanyahu's office to avoid further straining relations with Washington.

The Queen, accompanied by the Duke of Edinburgh, visited Windsor's Royal Mail delivery office as part of a series of events to mark her 90th birthday. She was welcomed with singing from the Royal Mail choir and viewed an exhibition. The Queen, along with the Prince of Wales, Prince William, and Prince George, featured on stamps released to mark her birthday. Prime Minister David Cameron and Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn expressed their anticipation for wishing the Queen a happy birthday. Prince William paid tribute to the Queen in a BBC interview, praising her as a "guiding example" of what a good monarch should be. He also discussed his own royal duties, stating that he takes his responsibilities seriously but is not yet fully engaged. The Queen will light a beacon on her actual birthday, setting off a series of over 900 beacons across the UK and around the world. US President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama will join the Queen for lunch at Windsor Castle on Friday.

The Premier League side West Ham United defeated the League Two side Cheltenham Town 2-0 in the EFL Cup. Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew scored for West Ham in the first half. Cheltenham had opportunities to score, including a volley from Harry Pell that was cleared off the line by James Collins. West Ham made seven changes to their lineup following recent losses to Manchester United and Southampton. Cheltenham's exit from the competition ended League Two's representation in the EFL Cup.

A hospital radiographer, Aidan McNicholl, died in a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion. Andreas Werner, who failed to see McNicholl on his motorbike, was found guilty of causing death by careless driving. He was fined £1,000 and banned from driving in the UK for two years.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old from Southall, west London, is facing life imprisonment for his role in the Syrian conflict. He left the UK last January, calling himself Abu Daigham al-Britani, and joined the group Rayat al Tawheed, affiliated with Islamic State. Khawaja was involved in propaganda efforts, including videos and pictures of his activities. He was considered so dangerous that he was held in a special unit for high-risk terrorism suspects at London's maximum security Belmarsh prison. Khawaja has admitted four offences, and his cousin Tahir Bhatti has pleaded guilty to assisting an offender.

Wrexham's 22-year-old forward, Jackson, scored four goals in 36 appearances last season. He is Barnsley's third signing for the upcoming season, ahead of their League One play-off final at Wembley. Jackson turned down a contract offer from Wrexham and will fit in well with Barnsley's playing style due to his pace and ability to take on defenders.

A container of 'Vanish' bottles is believed to have gone overboard from a ship during stormy weather near Land's End in May. The National Trust is clearing the bottles away from Poldhu Cove and other nearby coves as they pose a risk to wildlife, with some bottles having leaked detergent. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency stated there is no evidence that the bottles washed up on the Cornish coast are from the lost container, but the National Trust and Cornwall Council are monitoring the situation and advising the public to avoid the bottles.

A crash occurred on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness at about 14:00. Several people received minor injuries, and the road was closed with diversions put in place via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road. Police Scotland stated that inquiries into the incident were ongoing.

Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back, made 14 appearances last season, helping Wanderers secure promotion to the Championship. He joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014 and has made 83 appearances in all competitions. Dervite has signed a new contract with Bolton, following the footsteps of David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan.

The Lib Dems and Labour have previously collaborated to defeat government bills on various issues, including Brexit. However, their cooperation ended when MPs rejected their amendments, leading to accusations from the Lib Dems that Labour was giving in to the government's plans. Labour, in turn, accused the Lib Dems of creating false hope and grandstanding. Despite this, Baroness Ludford expressed optimism about future collaboration, while a Labour source predicted ongoing tensions.

Barcelona paid £48.6m for Neymar, with his parents receiving £34m of the fee. The total cost of the player, including signing-on fee, wages, agents fees, and this latest tax payment, is £106.8m. Last month, Sandro Rosell resigned as Barcelona president following accusations he misappropriated money.
