In one case, an offender had completed just 17 months of work in 17 months since being sentenced. The Ministry of Justice said it was acting on the report's recommendations. Anything from 40 to 300 hours of unpaid work may be given for offences like shoplifting, theft, drug offences, or criminal damage. Inspectors looked at 100 cases and interviewed 86 offenders from different probation divisions for their report. The report outlined 15 recommendations for improvement. Some of the problems identified were:

* The government, then led by Gordon Brown, placed an order for 10,000 orange bibs for offenders doing unpaid work under a re-branded scheme known as "community payback".
* The coalition, which came to power in 2010, promised to make unpaid work more physical and intense, with unemployed offenders required to complete their sentences more quickly.
* The difficulty has always been organisation. Getting people who lead chaotic lives - many of them with drink or drug problems - to work on time is a task

The comedian Brand has been accused of hypocrisy for campaigning for economic and political revolution to help poorer people while living in a luxury home. Brand has addressed these accusations in the past, acknowledging his wealth and stating that he believes in personal change and sharing wealth. However, he argues that without systemic change, his individual efforts may be futile. Brand has also criticized the focus on his personal wealth, suggesting that it is used to distract from the broader issue of economic disparity.

Dr. Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, is known for his competitive approach to mapping the human genome, which led to controversy within the scientific community. Despite criticism, he has been recognized for significantly accelerating the process of human genomics. After this achievement, he embarked on creating a synthetic life form, resulting in the creation of Synthia. Dr. Venter has also been involved in oceanic genetic research, using his yacht to collect samples for sequencing. His work has the potential to revolutionize industries and environmental practices.

The survey, conducted by researchers, found that four out of five children in England who ate school lunches had tried new foods at school that they had not tried at home. Half of the parents questioned said their children had asked for foods they had eaten at school to be cooked at home. The survey, of about 1,000 parents, found the most popular vegetables were carrots, sweetcorn, and peas. Aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were among the least popular. Of the parents questioned, 628 had children who ate school lunches. England's School Food Trust commissioned the research after a survey by the Mumsnet website suggested some parents gave their children packed lunches because they thought they were too fussy to eat anything else. Trust chairman, Rob Rees, said: "Every parent knows it's a nightmare watching their child push food around the plate. "School meals can be a great way to help parents encourage their children to try new foods and to increase the variety of foods in their diet." Mumsnet co-founder, Carrie Longton, said: "Getting children to eat healthily is every parent's dream, but meal times at home can often be a battlefield and emotionally charged

Alvaro Morata, a 23-year-old Spanish footballer, joined Juventus in 2014 after four seasons with Real. Juventus has the option to buy him back for up to 30m euros (£23m). Morata, who has scored three goals for Spain in Euro 2016, was previously a target for Arsenal and Chelsea. He scored 27 goals in two years for Juventus, winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias. Morata played in back-to-back Champions League finals, scoring in Juventus' 3-1 defeat by Barcelona in 2015. He came through the ranks at Real, making his first team debut at 18, and scored 10 goals for the La Liga side.

Wilson, a 30-year-old player, rejoined Championship side Forest from Celtic for £2.5m in August 2013. He has been without a team since being released in May. He made 51 appearances in his second spell at the City Ground, having spent four seasons at the club prior to signing for Celtic. He has also previously had spells with Preston North End and Notts County.

Tesco, the British supermarket giant, has been looking to dispose of its loss-making US food chain, Fresh & Easy, for some time. Around 4,000 of Fresh & Easy's 5,000 employees will transfer to the new business as part of the deal. Tesco will loan the new business around £80m. Fresh & Easy, which operates 200 stores across California, Nevada, and Arizona, has been operating at a loss since its opening in 2007. Tesco will incur a £150m cost to dispose of the Fresh & Easy brand, but part of that is a loan which may be paid back. If Yucaipa is successful and the business becomes profitable, Tesco has the option to buy a stake. Yucaipa is a Los Angeles-based private equity company focused on supermarket and restaurant businesses and is run by billionaire investor Ron Burkle. In April of this year, Tesco reported its first fall in annual profits for 20 years.
The athlete initially faced racial abuse but overcame it and is now targeting a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. He considered representing France but has since changed his mind.

The ice fields slipping down Mont Blanc and the surrounding mountains of the European range covered some 375 sq km in the late 1960s/early 1970s. By the late 2000s, this area had fallen to about 275 sq km, representing an average loss of some 26% over the last 40 years. The greatest losses have been seen in the southern sectors, with glaciers almost completely disappearing in the Belledonne Massif and more than three times stronger retreat in the Ecrins Massif compared to the Mont Blanc Massif. The retreat is less important in the northern Alps than in the southern Alps, which is thought to be due to the lower elevation of the mountains in the south and different climatic conditions, with more precipitation and cloud cover in the north. The northern region includes the biggest French glacier of all - La Mer de Glace, which falls over 1,000m in altitude down Mont Blanc itself. Its area today is just over 30 sq km, a shade smaller than the 31.5 sq km in the late 1960s/early 1970s.

The Scots have won all five qualifiers and are set to host Iceland at Falkirk Stadium on Friday. A victory would almost secure their place in the finals. The Scots are ranked 21st in the world, while Iceland is ranked 20th. The Scots are in pole position to reach the finals next summer in the Netherlands without the need for a play-off.

Stuart Campbell, a Scottish blogger known for his pro-independence views and the founder of the Wings Over Scotland blog, was arrested in England on harassment charges. The allegations, which Campbell denies, involve tweets that he claims were not threatening. Campbell has been released on bail and has accused the media of sensationalism. He also announced that he would be reducing his online activity due to circumstances beyond his control.

People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (Peta) wants the Jolly Fisherman mascot replaced with a modern, animal-friendly version. Peta suggested a fish with the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice." The mayor of Skegness said all suggestions are welcome but doesn't think there would be much support for replacing Jolly. The original Jolly Fisherman poster was commissioned in 1908 to encourage visitors to take the train to Skegness. The poster has become synonymous with the Lincolnshire resort. However, Dawn Carr of Peta said the Jolly Fisherman "evokes images of cruelty to animals." Skegness's mayor, Carl Macey, said the Jolly Fisherman is loved by adults and children alike and is just accepted as happy and friendly. He said the suggestion will go before the council, but if it isn't broken, they won't try to fix it.

Widnes beat Castleford 38-32 in a closely contested match. Widnes led 14-6 at halftime, with tries from Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, and Chris Bridge. Castleford's Paddy Flynn scored two tries, one against his parent club. Widnes extended their lead to 26 points in the second half, but Castleford fought back with three tries in four minutes. However, Widnes held on for the win, with Lloyd White and Joe Mellor scoring additional tries. The victory moved Widnes above Wakefield into seventh place, while Castleford remains in sixth.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old Kuwaiti national, was released from Guantanamo Bay after a US review panel concluded he was not a significant threat. He had been detained since 2002 on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, a charge he denies. After a US Supreme Court challenge, he was released to a militant rehabilitation center in Kuwait for at least a year. His release reduces the Guantanamo Bay detainee population to 148.

Anzac Day, commemorating the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces in World War One, was marked by a service at Westminster Abbey and a parade ending with wreath-laying at the Cenotaph. Thousands attended the early morning service at Hyde Park Corner, with up to 400 people participating in the parade. The national anthems of New Zealand and Australia were sung at the service's conclusion. The first Anzac Day service in the capital was held in 1916, attended by King George V. The day is significant for thousands of expatriate and visiting New Zealanders and Australians, who honor the sacrifices of their countrymen and women in all wars.

Clarkson, a 30-year-old player, has returned to Premiership Well for a second spell and may debut for St Mirren in the Championship against Alloa on Saturday. He scored nine goals for Dundee last season and has primarily been a substitute this term. Clarkson has been fit and training hard, making sure he is match-fit and ready for his time to come. He has been capped twice for Scotland and has almost 400 senior appearances at club level, with previous teams including Bristol City, Brentford, and Bristol Rovers. St Mirren is currently eighth in the Championship, seven points clear of bottom side Alloa.

The turkey firm, Bernard Matthews, was sold to Ranjit Boparan, also known as the "chicken king," on Tuesday. There were concerns about the new ownership taking on the existing workers' pension scheme, but Unite regional officer Steve Harley confirmed that all current agreements will be honored after productive talks. Unite stated that the Bernard Matthews final salary pension scheme was closed in 2004, and its members currently have an alternative pension scheme that is unaffected by the takeover. The Boparan Private Office confirmed that the current pension arrangements with Bernard Matthews would continue under the new ownership. Harley also mentioned that the new owner wishes to restore Bernard Matthews to its former position as a highly profitable business by greater investment in the business, cost savings, and utilizing the present spare capacity at Bernard Matthews to process chicken as well as turkeys.

The council leader, Dave Stewart, announced that the ferry crossing at Cowes would be free until 2 July due to the problems the new vessel has faced. The council has ordered a review of the project by auditors. The ferry has faced multiple issues since its launch on 14 May, including breakdowns, running aground, and suspension due to training issues. Vehicles have also been damaged while boarding and disembarking. Angie Booth, a local shopkeeper, expressed concerns about the impact on businesses, which have suffered from a loss of trade. Transport councillor Ian Ward acknowledged the issues but defended the project, stating that teething problems are expected with a prototype. He mentioned that electrical problems have been resolved, and measures have been taken to address vehicle scraping and grounding issues.

The UK fishing industry, which only contributes to 0.5% of GDP and employs 12,000 fishers, is at risk of being marginalized in the Brexit negotiations. The EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) has been largely unpopular among British fishers, who see Brexit as an opportunity to regain control over UK waters and become a leading fish-exporting nation. However, the Lords review warns that most commercial fish stocks are in shared waters, and a successful industry needs continued market access to the EU, which may come at a price. The report also suggests that many CFP elements should be retained post-Brexit, and the UK should continue to base total allowable catches and quotas on scientific advice. The report raises concerns about the potential for four different fisheries management regimes in the UK post-Brexit. Despite this, many in the industry remain optimistic about the opportunities presented by Brexit. The EU's recent agreement on new quotas under the CFP has been seen as a positive development for the UK, with significant increases in allowable catches for certain species. The government has stated that it aims to ensure British companies have maximum freedom to trade with and operate in the single market while reviewing fisheries

Timothy Geanya was removed from the teaching register after admitting to downloading child sexual abuse images over a decade. He was sentenced to a community payback order and a sex offenders program, but the General Teaching Council for Scotland deemed his actions fundamentally incompatible with teaching. The panel found a pattern of behavior and a high likelihood of reoffending, leading to his removal from the register.

Firefighters were at the site in Duncan Street for several days following a fire on 2 March, which reduced train services and caused travel delays. The Environment Agency suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste after the fire. The firm was broadly compliant with fire safety law, according to the fire service. Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service visited the premises nine times in the last 12 months and raised concerns to the EA in February over the impact a fire could have on nearby residents, transport, and the environment. The EA decided to revoke the environmental permit of Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited, which means the company will no longer be able to operate from that site after 7 August. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

Syria missed the deadline to hand over its entire stockpile of chemical weapons. Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad stated that a shipment of weapons was attacked twice on its way to the port of Latakia, and the second shipment was intercepted by terrorist groups. Mekdad also condemned US Secretary of State John Kerry's recent remarks about the government's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, describing them as "absolutely unacceptable." The Syrian government denied reports that rebels had seized most of Aleppo's central prison, but the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights claimed that rebels now completely control the prison, which holds at least 3,000 detainees in horrific conditions. Mekdad stressed that Syria is committed to fulfilling its obligations regarding the destruction of chemical weapons.

England won the match against Pakistan by a day to spare at Old Trafford, leveling the series. England's Joe Root was named man of the match after scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 off 48 balls in the second. Root also took four catches in Pakistan's first-innings 198 and claimed a wicket in his only over as Pakistan were bowled out for 234 on Monday. Pakistan's captain Misbah-ul-Haq expressed disappointment, stating that the team was short of confidence and shot selection really cost them.

Older People's Commissioner for Wales Sarah Rochira is seeking experiences of residential care from pensioners and their loved ones to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The review aims to improve the quality of life and care for older people in Wales, highlighting both good and poor care. Rochira emphasizes the importance of hearing from older people and those who care for them. The review will assess factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. While Rochira has seen positive impacts of high-quality care, she has also received increasing complaints about the quality of life and care in residential homes. The review will involve speaking to care providers, social care staff, and public bodies. Despite support for the review's aims, Care Forum Wales criticizes the lack of representation from those with direct experience in the care home sector on the advisory panel.

Sheerin, a former Dons midfielder, has been appointed as the new player-manager at Pittodrie, replacing Neil Cooper. Arbroath, the team Sheerin previously managed, was relegated to Scottish League Two after finishing bottom of League One in the 2013-14 season. Aberdeen's chief executive, Duncan Fraser, stated that Sheerin was chosen by boss Derek McInnes after a comprehensive process. Despite Arbroath's desire to keep Sheerin, his wish to return to Aberdeen was understood by the club's chairman, John Christison. Sheerin, who has also played for Swedish club Östersunds and featured for Scotland's Under-21 team in the mid-1990s, won the Scottish Third Division title and promotion with Arbroath in 2011, securing their first national trophy in history.

Curtis and Paul Williams will manage the upcoming match against Bournemouth following Bob Bradley's dismissal. Swansea aims to quickly appoint a new manager, with Paul Clement being their top choice. Curtis, who has been with the club since their rise from near bankruptcy, believes the team has lost its identity since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014. Curtis is confident that the current squad is capable of avoiding relegation and emphasizes the importance of staying in the Premier League to the players.

Dr. Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, is known for his competitive approach to mapping the human genome, which led to his vilification by the scientific community. Despite criticism, he has been instrumental in advancing human genomics and creating a synthetic life form called Synthia. Dr. Venter's work has been driven by a sense of urgency and a desire to make a significant impact on the world. He has also ventured into the field of synthetic biology, using his yacht Sorcerer II to collect genetic samples from marine life.

The Sutton Trust warns that many apprenticeships in England are low quality and too short, with only 200,000 of the 520,000 annual apprenticeships being rated at level three, equivalent to A-levels. The report suggests creating up to 300,000 new apprenticeships annually, with the majority at level three or higher, to boost the economy and improve job prospects for young people. In contrast, Germany, which has a highly regarded vocational education system, offers 570,000 apprenticeships to young people, with 90% being equivalent to A-levels. The report also highlights the need for more standardized qualifications, as England has 18,000 different qualifications compared to Germany's 330. The Department for Education is reforming apprenticeships to drive up standards, with plans to be published later this month.

Sarah Storey, Britain's most decorated female Paralympian, won the time trial at the Para-cycling Road World Championships in Nottwil, Switzerland, finishing more than two minutes ahead of Poland's Anna Harkowska. Storey, who has won 21 world titles across cycling and swimming, is targeting further success at the 2016 Paralympic Games in Rio de Janeiro. She has won 11 gold, 8 silver, and 3 bronze medals across six Paralympic Games. Storey, who began her sporting career in the pool, won four golds at the 2012 Games in London and will compete in the road race on Saturday.

Hereford United, a football club, faced financial difficulties and was expelled from the Conference after failing to meet a deadline to pay their creditors. The club's debt amounted to £148,000, and despite efforts to raise funds and offers to buy the club, they were unable to secure the necessary assurances from the league. As a result, Chester FC, who were reinstated to the Conference Premier, took their place. The club's financial troubles began after their relegation from the Football League in May 2012, and despite efforts to raise funds, they were unable to clear their debts.

James Milner, a 30-year-old former Manchester City player, won 61 caps for England after making his senior debut in 2009. He was a squad member at two World Cups and two European Championships but only played three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner also holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player, with 46 caps. He scored his first and only international goal in a 5-0 victory over Moldova during the 2014 Fifa World Cup qualifiers.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and founder of the Academy of Ancient Music, passed away at his home in Cambridge after a brief illness. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service planned for a later date. Hogwood was known for his work with leading orchestras worldwide and his influence on the early-music movement. He made significant contributions to the Academy of Ancient Music, including directing it across six continents for 30 years and producing over 200 CDs, such as the first-ever complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. Hogwood was also a celebrated keyboard player and musicologist, with positions at prestigious institutions like Harvard University and the University of Cambridge. He was remembered by colleagues and friends for his generosity, kindness, and dedication to historically informed music.

A boy from Northern Ireland, whose identity is protected, had to be removed from mainstream schooling in June due to not coping. His parents requested a place for him at a special school, but they are still waiting for a spot. In September, they were informed that all special schools in the South Eastern Education Board area were full, with no timeframe for when a place would become available. The boy's mother expressed concern about his isolation and the strain on the special needs school system. The Education Authority is reviewing the profile of need for special school places in Northern Ireland to ensure availability close to children's residences, with changes expected to take effect from 2016.

The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) is bidding to take over Newport Gwent Dragons and views Rodney Parade as a rugby venue. County has a lease to use the ground until 2023, with primacy of fixtures if they remain in the Football League. The WRU plans to install an artificial surface, which is against Football League rules. County is two points clear of League Two relegation with two games remaining and can secure survival this weekend. Relegation to the National League would be a significant blow to the fans and the city of Newport, according to Foxall.

The country was declared free of the virus that killed almost 4,000 people in the country over the past 18 months. The interviewee had a normal family life before the civil war in 1991. At 15, he was kidnapped by the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) rebels and taken to the jungle, where he was trained to use a gun and initiated into the group. He managed to escape from the jungle without being killed and went to the capital, Freetown, but was unable to find his relatives. He lived alone and teamed up with some guys doing things like pick-pocketing and was caught. He met a preacher called Richard Cole, who was the founder of a project called Lifeline Nehemiah, which aimed to give hope and a home to people like him who felt they had lost hope. He encouraged him to continue with his schooling and told him that guys like him would be leaders of the nation and help rebuild it. He taught him that it was God who was taking him through all these troubling times, and he also learned that it was important to give back what was invested in him. When the Ebola crisis came to Sierra Leone in 2014

The Wedgwood Museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire, faced the potential auction of its 80,000-piece collection to help pay off a pension debt. A public fundraising campaign led by the Art Fund successfully raised the necessary funds in just a month, preventing the collection from being sold and scattered. The collection will remain on display at the museum and will be gifted to the Victoria and Albert Museum before being loaned to the Wedgwood Museum. The campaign's success was described as "incredibly satisfying" by administrator Bob Young, who emphasized the role of goodwill and determination in the negotiations. The collection is significant to Staffordshire and Britain's cultural development, according to Wedgwood descendant Alison Wedgwood and MP Tristram Hunt.

Billericay Town FC is currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points away from a play-off spot. The club was recently taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who is willing to invest £10,000 per week. The Sun reported that 30-year-old Dean Wright, who was a runner-up in I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here in 2011, will become a club director. Wright played non-league football for several clubs, including Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds. Billericay recently signed former England international Paul Konchesky, 35. The finer points of a deal that could see Wright buy 20% of the club have yet to be released.

Blackpool and Colchester United played to a 1-1 draw. Blackpool took the lead in the 12th minute with a goal from Jamille Matt, but Colchester equalized in the 20th minute with a goal from Kurtis Guthrie. Both teams had several chances to score, with Blackpool's Sam Slocombe making a sensational save and Colchester's Tom Eastman missing a close-range effort. Colchester finished the game with 10 men after Sean Murray was shown a red card in injury time.

Fawley Waterside developers plan to transform the disused Fawley power station into the tallest chimney attraction south of London's Shard, serving as the centerpiece of a £1bn "merchant city" development. The power station, which closed in 2013, was commissioned in 1971 and could power one million homes. The development will feature a petal-shaped glass structure, a marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. The outline planning permission application is due later this year, with building work potentially starting in 2018.

The 23-year-old cyclist earned GB's second medal at the Hong Kong championships, taking bronze in the men's scratch race. He chased down gold medalist Adrian Teklinski of Poland and silver medalist Lucass Liss of Germany. In the men's team pursuit, GB was beaten to the bronze medal by Italy. Joe Truman, the sole British rider in the men's keirin, was outclassed in his semi-final. The women's team pursuit squad finished fifth in the heats and failed to make the bronze-medal ride. Olympic gold medallist Chris Boardman praised Latham's final charge, timing, and sprint. Six-time Olympic gold medallist Sir Chris Hoy commended Latham's positioning, energy conservation, and sprint at the end.

Grant Mitchell, a memorable character from EastEnders, will make a brief return to the show to reunite with his family following the announcement of Dame Barbara Windsor's character's death from cancer. Kemp, who last played Grant in 2006, was approached to return for Windsor's final episodes and could not turn down the opportunity. The Mitchell brothers will be reunited with their mother, Peggy, in emotional scenes set to air in the spring.

Spurs disappointed in their match against second-placed Spurs, with Sadio Mane scoring twice in 138 seconds. Mauricio Pochettino criticized the team's lack of desire and inability to cope with pressure, emphasizing the difficulty of challenging for the Premier League under such circumstances. Spurs have struggled on the road, winning only twice since 24 September, including defeats at Chelsea and Manchester United. In their past 17 meetings with top-six sides away from home, Spurs have won only once. Pochettino expressed concerns about Chelsea potentially extending their lead to 12 points. Former player Danny Murphy criticized Spurs' performance, particularly their defense, and emphasized the need for improvement, especially when playing away from home.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of 28 governor posts in the recent elections, marking the Peoples Democratic Party's (PDP) most significant defeat since military rule ended in 1999. APC leader Muhammadu Buhari will be inaugurated on 29 May after defeating President Goodluck Jonathan. The PDP lost in key northern states like Katsina and Kaduna, as well as in Adamawa, one of three states affected by Boko Haram's insurgency. However, the PDP retained control of Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub. The APC failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, which could pose a problem for President-elect Buhari as militant groups could disrupt oil production. The elections were more peaceful than in previous years, raising hopes for Nigeria's democracy. The PDP will need to undergo introspection and rebuild under a new leader after 16 years in power.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) will take place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July. Visitors to the festival will be able to use an app to trigger online information from items such as signs and posters on the site. Videos and band interviews will be among the online material available to view on phones and tablets. The app will also allow people around the world to interact with the festival and capture a flavour of its atmosphere at any time. The message will be updated in the run-up to HebCelt and during the event, allowing people to instantly access information and interviews, buy tickets, and get a taste of the unique festival wherever they are.

The Birmingham academies Park View and Nansen Primary, rated inadequate by Ofsted, will have their funding agreements terminated. The Park View Educational Trust may be removed from running the schools. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School, also rated inadequate, were warned they could lose funding unless concerns were addressed. A head teacher at one of the Trojan Horse schools said parents tried to undermine her authority and descended on the school during an Ofsted inspection. The watchdog published 21 reports into schools allegedly targeted as part of a hardline Muslim takeover. Birmingham City Council said it would work with Saltley School, the only local authority school placed in special measures, and the Department for Education to install a temporary governing board. In a letter to Park View chairman Tahir Alam, education minister Lord Nash said there were "deep concerns" about the way Park View School was run. Lord Nash criticized the trust for failing to promote "spiritual, moral, social and cultural development of pupils." A similar letter about Nansen Primary School said it would have its funding arrangement terminated. Both letters invited the trust to respond before 4 July. A spokesman for Park View School said they would challenge the Ofsted report through the appropriate legal channels.

Honey Rose, an eye specialist, is on trial for gross negligence manslaughter in the death of Vincent Barker, who died five months after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. The prosecution claims that Rose failed to detect Barker's swollen optic discs during the test and did not refer him for further investigation, which led to a fatal build-up of fluid in his brain. The prosecution argues that Barker's death could have been prevented if Rose had performed her job properly.

Clive Weatherhogg was found guilty of coercing a woman to engage in sexual activity and intercourse with a man between September 10, 2013, and September 17, 2014. He was also convicted of intentionally causing the woman's sister and father to look at sexual images and behaving in a threatening or abusive manner on December 25, 2014. Weatherhogg was placed on the sex offenders register and denied the charges but was found guilty following a trial at Dundee Sheriff Court. He was sentenced to reflect society's abhorrence at such conduct.

Ireland made 165-5 in Greater Noida, with Stuart Thompson hitting 56 and Gary Wilson and captain William Porterfield adding valuable runs. However, it was not enough as Afghanistan reached the target with two overs to spare, thanks to Samiullah Shenwari's 56 and Mohammad Shahzad's 47. Ireland suffered an early blow when opener Paul Stirling was dismissed for a duck. Afghanistan's Shahzad and Najeeb Tarakai put on an opening stand of 51. Afghan spinner Amir Hamza took 2-23, the only bowler to take more than one wicket. Ireland's captain William Porterfield felt they fell short with both batting and bowling. Ireland will also miss paceman Boyd Rankin for the T20s due to a back problem, but he is expected to return for the five ODIs against Afghanistan.

Barcelona paid £48.6m for Neymar, with his parents receiving £34m of the fee. The total cost of the player, including signing-on fee, wages, agents fees, and this latest tax payment, is £106.8m. Last month, Sandro Rosell resigned as Barcelona president following accusations he misappropriated money. A judge in Spain ruled there was sufficient evidence against Barcelona to continue investigations into the transfer. The club denies any wrongdoing and has made a complimentary tax declaration of 13,550,830.56 euros.

The bodies of David Miller and Hannah Witheridge were found on a beach in Koh Tao on 15 September. Metropolitan Police officers flew to Thailand to work with Thai police, who are holding two Burmese suspects. The UK detectives will compile a report and update the families of Hannah and David on their findings. The two suspects, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, both migrant workers from Myanmar, are alleged to have confessed to the killings. They are charged with conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape, and robbery, and could face the death penalty if found guilty. The UK Foreign Office expressed concerns about the police investigation, specifically around the verification of DNA samples and allegations of mistreatment. The UK police visit came after the Thai Prime Minister met with Mr. Cameron and agreed to a delegation of British officers traveling to Thailand. Post-mortem examinations found that Mr. Miller died from drowning and a blow to the head, while Miss Witheridge died from head wounds. Thai police claim that DNA found on Ms. Witheridge matched samples taken from the suspects.

The Scots have won all five qualifiers and are set to host Iceland at Falkirk Stadium. A victory would secure their place in the finals. The team is determined to avoid another play-off loss, as they have experienced heartbreak in the past. Iceland, ranked one place above Scotland, is also unbeaten. The outcome of the upcoming matches against Iceland will likely determine who tops the group. With the best six group runners-up qualifying automatically, Scotland is in a favorable position to reach the finals. The team benefits from having players who compete in top leagues worldwide, bringing diverse experiences and skills to the national team.

Apple introduced a two-step verification system to prevent unauthorized access to iCloud, requiring users to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted device in addition to their username and password. This system was not previously active for iCloud backups, allowing hackers to use software like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker to download complete backups. The new measure makes the two-step verification system mandatory for iCloud backups, sending notifications to users when a backup is downloaded. While some experts support this change, others criticize the recovery key system for being hard to remember and potentially vulnerable to theft.

UKIP, the winner of the May election, spent £2,956,737, while the Tories spent £2,980,815. The Lib Dems spent £1,580,575 and lost all but one of their MEPs, and Labour, which came second, spent £1,027,339. UKIP's campaign spending was 68p per vote, Labour's was 26p, the Conservatives' was 79p, and the Lib Dems' was £1.45. The Green Party, which came fourth, spent £534,249, or 43p per vote. Including the SNP's £267,372, the six highest-spending parties spent a total of £9,347,087 on campaigning, according to the Electoral Commission. All but Labour spent more than they did during the 2009 European election campaign.

Anderson, a 27-year-old centre-back, has left Barrow by mutual consent to join their National League rivals. He has previously played for Aldershot, Exeter, and in Italy. Keating, a 21-year-old striker, has joined Torquay United, recommended by Micky Adams. He has previously played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps. Both players' moves are subject to international clearance. Torquay United are currently four points above the relegation zone and have won only one of their last six games.

A 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, Many Clouds, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed that the horse suffered from a severe pulmonary haemorrhage. Despite the rarity of such incidents, the authorities are determined to understand the causes and prevent such occurrences in the future. Many Clouds had no significant underlying health issues, although he had previously received treatment for a tendency to overheat.

Tricia Marwick, the presiding officer, was visibly emotional after Duncan McNeil and Alex Salmond's farewell speeches to the parliament. Salmond, who served as first minister between 2007 and 2014, used his valedictory address to express his belief that Scotland was not divided but diverse. He welcomed the transfer of powers to Holyrood under the Scotland Bill but insisted it did not fulfill the pledges made by unionist politicians in the last days of the referendum campaign. Salmond also joked about facing competition from a "major attraction down south today" and wished everyone standing in the forthcoming election good luck, "albeit with varying degrees of enthusiasm." McNeil, who is stepping down as an MSP after serving in the parliament since it was established in 1999, used his address to warn that Holyrood had things to learn from Westminster, particularly with regard to the committee system. He said, "It will be this parliament's responsibility to ensure there is accountability, there is scrutiny and even opposition when that is necessary." Former Scottish Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie is also bowing out of Holyrood.

The film, which will be released in US cinemas on 17 March 2017, is a live-action adaptation of the 1991 animated version of the film. Emma Watson will play Belle, Dan Stevens will play the Beast, and Luke Evans will play Gaston. Josh Gad will play LeFou, Gaston's sidekick. Kevin Kline will play Maurice, Belle's father. Bill Condon will direct the film, which begins filming in May at Shepperton Studios.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will announce its decisions regarding potential charges related to the 1989 Hillsborough stadium disaster, in which 96 football fans were unlawfully killed. The announcement will be made to victims' relatives at a meeting in Warrington. The CPS will inform them of the decisions regarding 15 files of evidence related to the causes of the disaster and 8 files related to an investigation into the conduct of the police following the disaster. The families have been waiting for a long time for these decisions and are determined to seek accountability.

Chelmsford Prison has experienced numerous incidents of contraband being thrown over the wall. A former inmate reported that the jail is notorious for having a lot of mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. The Ministry of Justice stated that staff work hard to prevent contraband from entering prisons, but more needs to be done. A nearby resident reported witnessing packages being thrown over the wall four times in two weeks. A former inmate claimed drones were used to fly contraband to prison windows, but the Ministry of Justice said there was no evidence of drones at Chelmsford. Laws have been introduced that mean people who smuggle packages over prison walls could be jailed for up to two years.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries in an accident outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. Brian Wright, 55, of Kempston, told Luton Crown Court he had been blinded by the setting sun and accepted he had struck Mrs Blackburn but denied causing serious injury by dangerous driving. Mrs Blackburn is now being treated in residential care. Mr Wright's VW Golf failed to stop for a red light, and the jury heard that he could not remember if the traffic lights were red or green. Mrs Blackburn, a married mother of three, had been on duty in Bedford Road as pupils left school when the traffic lights turned red. She was wearing appropriate clothing and stepped out to escort a woman and her six-year-old daughter across the road. Prosecutor Sally Mealing-McLeod said traffic in the other direction had stopped, but Mr Wright did not, and hit her. The court heard the sun was 10 minutes from setting and could have been shining into Mr Wright's eyes. The trial continues.

Laura Muir, a middle-distance runner, will miss the 2024 Commonwealth Games in Australia due to her veterinary medicine exams scheduled for May. Despite this, she expresses confidence in her team's potential success and her future in athletics, including the possibility of participating in at least two more Olympics. Muir is also considering targeting the World Indoor Championships in March. She recently achieved a new outdoor personal best time of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds in the 5,000m race at the World Athletics Championships in London.

Trevor Deely, a 22-year-old man from County Kildare, was last seen walking home from a Christmas party in December 2000. A search for his body began in Chapelizod, Dublin, on Saturday morning, involving excavations and expected to take several weeks. Earlier this year, detectives reviewed his case and enhanced CCTV footage, which showed Deely talking to a man in black outside his workplace and later following him. The man has not yet been identified, and gardaí renewed their appeal for him to come forward.

Juan Martin del Potro, ranked 165th in the world, defeated Stan Wawrinka in a four-set match at Wimbledon. Del Potro, who missed more than two years due to injury, is now in the same half of the draw as Andy Murray. Nick Kyrgios, the 15th seed, also won his match against Dustin Brown in a thrilling five-setter. Kyrgios will next face Feliciano Lopez, who also won his match in five sets. Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga both won their matches in straight sets.

Tunisia faced expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations until they apologized to Caf for complaints lodged during the 2015 Nations Cup. Morocco was only able to enter the 2017 qualifying draw after the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned a ban on their participation. Both nations are now preparing for a positive future in the competition. Morocco was punished in February after refusing to host the 2015 tournament due to Ebola fears, with Equatorial Guinea stepping in to host. Tunisia's participation in the 2017 tournament was in doubt until a meeting with Caf president Issa Hayatou led to a resolution. Tunisia will face Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti in Group A, while Morocco will face Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome in Group F. Tunisia has the chance to reach their thirteenth straight Nations Cup, which would be a record.

McLaren, a Formula 1 team with a rich history, has experienced a significant decline in performance since 2013. Despite having two world champions as drivers, the team has struggled with car design and engine issues. The team's current focus is on improving their performance and returning to their former glory.

Joe's Bar in Dungiven was closed for three months after a sudden death occurred there on 6 October 2014. The bar was found to be serving alcohol as late as 04:49 BST, with several people still present. The license holder, Colleen O'Neill, and James Thomas were charged with allowing the consumption of liquor outside licensing hours. The judge expressed concern over the appalling record of the premises and the lack of proper management. O'Neill was fined £3,000 and Thomas £1,000.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most three-pointers in a season, scoring 45 points to help the Golden State Warriors defeat the Portland Trail Blazers 116-105. Curry hit six three-pointers before halftime and eight overall, teaming with Klay Thompson to overcome a 13-point deficit. Curry also had nine assists, and Thompson scored 26 points. Lamarcus Aldridge had 27 points and six rebounds, and Damian Lillard added 20 points and eight assists for the Blazers. In another game, the Chicago Bulls overcame a 19-point halftime deficit to defeat the Miami Heat 89-78. Pau Gasol had 16 points and 15 rebounds for the Bulls, who moved back into the No. 3 spot in the Eastern Conference standings.

Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic were surprised when YouTube star Bas van Velzen arrived at Melwood, posing as a competition winner. Van Velzen showcased his free-kick skills, surprising the players with his abilities. The players also had the opportunity to showcase their skills, with Balotelli scoring a perfect free-kick. Van Velzen, who has become a YouTube sensation for his free-kick videos, enjoyed the experience and the opportunity to meet the Liverpool players. He also surprised Balotelli by unveiling the player's infamous slogan on a t-shirt.

Angelina Jolie, who carries the BRCA1 gene, underwent a double mastectomy and later an oophorectomy to reduce her risk of breast and ovarian cancer. A study found that women with the BRCA1 gene who had their ovaries removed after a breast cancer diagnosis had a 62% lower risk of death from breast cancer and a 65% lower risk of overall mortality. The protective effect was evident immediately after diagnosis and lasted for 15 years. The study also found that the procedure was particularly effective for women with estrogen-receptor negative breast cancer.

A married couple, Derek Lowe, 38, and Tina Lowe, 33, were struck and killed by an Amtrak train on Easter morning in Durham, North Carolina. The incident occurred shortly before 10 am as the train, headed north from Charlotte to New York City, passed over property owned by Norfolk-Southern. None of the 166 passengers on the train were injured, although a man who fell ill during the delay received treatment. The train resumed its route after a delay of about two hours and 45 minutes. The couple may have lived in a homeless camp, according to a man who met them while collecting scrap metal.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former DEA informant, faces deportation after 27 years of service. He fears for his life if deported to Colombia due to his work with the DEA and the Medellin cartel. Toro's information led to the prosecution of cocaine overlord Carlos Lehder and former Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega. Despite promises of US citizenship, Toro remains in limbo, unable to collect social security benefits or secure a green card or passport. He is now technically living in the US illegally after declining health forced him to retire.

The US body that regulates internet addresses, ICANN, is investigating a Canadian company, Vox Populi Registry Ltd., for using the new '.sucks' domain name to extract exorbitant sums from celebrities and companies. Vox Populi began accepting registrations for '.sucks' domains on March 30, with trademark holders and celebrities given priority. ICANN is seeking to determine if Vox Populi's actions are illegal, as the company has been recommended to resell '.sucks' domains for around $2,499 a year. ICANN may declare Vox Populi in breach of its contract if regulators find their actions illegal.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, was ordered to pay compensation to a passenger, Kristopher Hicks, who suffered severe brain injuries after jumping out of a moving taxi. Young had mistakenly believed Hicks was planning to evade the fare and decided to drive him back to the rank as a lesson. Hicks, now 27, jumped out of the taxi while it was traveling at more than 20mph, resulting in devastating brain injuries and requiring round-the-clock care. The judge ruled that Young had unlawfully imprisoned Hicks and was therefore entitled to damages, which are set to be around 50% of what the family had requested, thought to be hundreds of thousands of pounds. The exact amount of compensation is yet to be decided, with a further hearing to determine the amount.

Several storms brought tornadoes to Kansas on Wednesday night, with a tornado reported about 6 miles northwest of Goddard, less than 15 miles west of Wichita. The storm moved northeast, missing Wichita but posing potential risks to other communities. Chad Myers, a CNN severe weather expert, warned that nighttime tornadoes are the most deadly and dangerous. Other tornado sightings were reported in southwestern Kansas, and a possible tornado touched down in Potosi, Missouri, about 70 miles from St. Louis. The storms also caused damage and flooding in Potosi, with one Instagram user posting a photo of a fallen tree and aerial footage showing damage to roofs and a street overtaken by water. In Leadington, a Twitter user reported seeing baseball-sized hail. More storms are expected in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes on Thursday.

Luke Rockhold is set to face Lyoto Machida in New Jersey, aiming for his fourth consecutive victory and a title shot. Rockhold plans to be the "bull" to Machida's "matador," utilizing his diverse skill set to dominate the fight. Machida, confident in his abilities, believes he can exploit Rockhold's weaknesses and earn a title shot. Both fighters respect each other's skills but are determined to emerge victorious.

A light general aviation aircraft approached the Aero Acres Residential Airpark in Fort Pierce, Florida, and touched down without its landing gear deployed. The plane skidded along the runway, causing the propellers to ricochet off the ground and the wings to bounce up and down from the impact. The pilot then re-engaged the engines and took off back into the air. The plane's propellers were damaged in the collision with the runway, and the pilot was likely to crash. The plane scratched along the runway, creating a sound that the video maker described as unforgettable. The belly and tips of the propellers impacted the runway. Once the pilot realized his mistake, he gave full throttle, and both propellers pulled the front of the aircraft down, causing the propellers to make a second impact with the runway. The engines stayed on, and the pilot was able to regain control while leaving the airport. The plane's pilot, Chris Georgaklis, 85, managed to fly 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale after the incident and landed safely. The most common cause of a gear-up landing is human error, when the pilot simply forgets to deploy the landing gear before touchdown. The FAA is investigating the

Manuel Pellegrini has expressed disappointment in Yaya Toure's performance but vowed to support him until the end of the season. City is considering offers for Toure in the summer to overhaul an aging squad. Pellegrini has also been criticized for his performance this season, with City taking only 18 points from the last 39 available. Despite this, Pellegrini retains the backing of the dressing room, with goalkeeper Joe Hart insisting the players should take responsibility for their performances. Meanwhile, West Ham manager Sam Allardyce has warned Aaron Cresswell not to make the same mistake as other English players by moving to City, citing the examples of Jack Rodwell and Scott Sinclair, who had limited playing time at the club.

Mr. Mole, ridden by AP McCoy, is one of the three 7-2 co-favorites in the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday. This will be McCoy's last ride in a Grade One race. The other two co-favorites are Irish raider Special Tiara and Sprinter Sacre, ridden by Cheltenham Gold Cup winner Nico de Boinville. The other runners include Mick Channon's Somersby. McCoy's book of rides for his final day as a professional jockey will be finalized on Friday morning.

Virginia Trimble Ritter, whose daughter Marcia was raped and choked to death by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975, recently viewed crime scene photos of her daughter's body. Marcia's body was found 33 days after her disappearance, and Ritter's then-husband advised her against seeing the photos. Ritter now regrets not viewing the photos sooner and wants revenge. Barrett was found guilty of second-degree murder in 2009 and sentenced to 44 years in prison.

Rory McIlroy believes it is unthinkable that he will not win the Masters at some point to complete the career grand slam. He views his final-round collapse at Augusta National in 2011 as the most important day of his career, as it taught him a lot about himself and his game. McIlroy is looking to claim his first green jacket and become just the sixth player to win all four major titles. He hopes to use the golf course as his sanctuary from the pressure and hype surrounding Augusta.

This week's trending stories include:

1. Four rainbows appeared in the New York area after heavy rain.
2. Hiring exotic dancers for wakes is becoming common in rural China.
3. RDJ became agitated during a UK interview about his private life.
4. Lip plumping by sucking on a jar is the latest trend to look like Kylie Jenner.
5. A 102-year-old woman went back in time with the help of filmmakers.
6. A prom-posal referencing bombs caused controversy at a school.
7. Ewan McGregor will play Lumiere in "Beauty and the Beast."
8. Johnny Depp is nearly unrecognizable in the "Black Mass" trailer.
9. A pregnant woman announced her pregnancy by referencing "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air."
10. A military dad photobombed his son.

Hundreds of children were admitted to hospital last year after being born brain damaged following exposure to alcohol in the womb. In total, 272 youngsters left disabled by foetal alcohol syndrome were hospitalised in England over the past 12 months, according to data from the official health and social care information centre. However, the actual number affected by their mother's drinking could be far greater, experts have warned. Research by the World Health Organisation suggests that at least one in 100 babies born in the UK could suffer learning, behavioural and physical problems such as deformed limbs because of exposure to alcohol, according to the Sunday People. That equates to about 7,500 every year. Elizabeth Mitchell, of the National Organisation for Foetal Alcohol Syndrome, told reporter Nicola Fifield: "Children born with the syndrome don't get better. It is an enormous problem and one that is terribly sad and vastly under-diagnosed." One teenager who was born with foetal alcohol syndrome is 15-year-old Niamh Brown. She needs help getting dressed, has no sense of danger and will never be able to live independently. Niamh was three when her adoptive parents Julia and Simon first

Shaun Andrew McKerry, also known as Boomerang Boy, was jailed for six years after his attempt to rob a store was thwarted by the shopkeeper and his wife. McKerry, a former juvenile offender with a long history of crimes, entered Shildon Post Office and Stores waving an axe and demanding cash. However, he was tackled by the shopkeeper, Sab Dhillon, and hit twice with a baseball bat by Dhillon's wife, Sam. McKerry was disarmed and later arrested by the police. He pleaded guilty to attempted robbery and was sentenced to six years in prison.

Four Royal Navy sailors, Joshua Finbow, 23, Simon Radford, 31, Craig Stoner, 24, and Darren Smalley, 35, have been charged with gang rape in Canada. They appeared in court in Dartmouth, Nova Scotia, and were granted bail under unusual conditions, requiring them to live on a Canadian naval base. The sailors, who were part of a Royal Navy ice hockey team, are accused of sexually assaulting a young woman after a party at a Canadian barracks. They are forbidden to contact the victim and six witnesses and must remain employed by the navy. The sailors face charges of sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault, which carry a maximum sentence of 14 years in prison.

Rail firms have come under fire for planning fare hikes of up to 87%, just ten days after the general election, despite party leaders' pledges to freeze prices. Prime Minister David Cameron has requested First Great Western to urgently review its decision to almost double some fares on the route between London and the Cotswolds, which passes through his Witney constituency. Passengers traveling from Charlbury, the nearest station to Cameron's constituency home, can currently purchase an off-peak return to London for £33.30. However, from May 17, these customers will be forced to pay £62.40 if they want to return on one of these trains, an 87% increase. First Great Western has insisted the reason for the change is to bring the North Cotswolds route in line with its other services. The firm is also offering some customers a cheaper option in advanced single tickets, potentially allowing them to buy a return for £20 if they book ahead.

Derbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton has signed a new one-year contract extension with the county, rewarding him for his successful return from injury. Poynton, 25, missed the entire 2014 campaign due to leg injuries sustained in a road accident in which his father died. He underwent ankle surgery but made a comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi. Poynton will be available for the start of the season and has committed to the county until the end of 2016. Elite performance director Graeme Welch praised Poynton's character and hard work in his recovery, expressing hope that the new contract will give him the confidence to perform well this summer.

Jack Grealish, a 19-year-old Aston Villa player, is at the center of a tug of war between the Republic of Ireland and England regarding his international future. However, his manager, Tim Sherwood, wants him to focus on his club career first. Sherwood believes that if Grealish continues to perform well for Aston Villa, he will have the option to choose between the two countries. Sherwood shared his experience with a similar situation involving Nabil Bentaleb, who chose to play for Algeria over France. Grealish's father, Kevin, agrees that his son should focus on his club football before making any international decisions.

A Labrador named Cooper and a small female dog named Daisy visited a McDonald's drive-thru for ice cream. While Daisy licked her ice cream ladylike, Cooper ate his in one bite. Cooper always eats quickly, so Daisy is fed first. The video of Cooper's ice cream outing has been watched over seven million times. Some viewers criticized Cooper's owner for feeding him ice cream, but she insists it's fine as Cooper is healthy. Cooper and Daisy also visited a Starbucks for a "pup-uccino," which is just whipped cream in a cup.

Gary Locke, who joined Kilmarnock as an assistant to Allan Johnston last summer, has been appointed as the permanent manager after a successful interim period. Locke, who will speak at a press conference on Friday, has lost only once in seven games since taking over. He has signed a three-year deal with the club.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, claims her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, was threatened with suspension from Seminole County Elementary School due to the essential oils he wears, which the school deemed a distraction. Kemp applies the oils, manufactured by Doterra, to Logan's head and neck to help him stay calm and focused. Despite using the oils all year, a teacher's aide recently complained, leading to the threat. Kemp received a letter from the school board stating the oils caused a problem for staff and students. Kemp argues that natural oils should not be an issue when chemicals could be used instead. The Lake County School District has since stated that Logan would not be suspended, citing the issue as a health matter. The family uses Doterra oils with scents like lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood, which the company describes as "beautifully and powerfully fragrant."

A beach-side apartment complex in the Hamptons, known as the Sandpiper complex, was obliterated by a fire on Wednesday afternoon. The fire started at 3 pm and spread through 90 condos, causing the building to collapse. The cause of the fire is unknown, but it is being investigated. The fire was so intense that it melted the paint off nearby buildings and could be seen from three miles away. Twelve fire teams were deployed but could not get inside any of the summer homes. The building manager, who lived and worked in the complex, lost everything. The complex is used as a holiday home by residents between May and November.

The Queen, who is 88, was seen riding her black fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, in Windsor Great Park. Despite her age, she continues to ride, although she has cut down due to a knee injury. She has been encouraged to wear a riding helmet for safety but prefers not to, as she does not want to ruin her hairstyle. The Queen has been riding since she was four years old and has owned several horses, including her favorite, Burmese, which she rode during Trooping the Colour. She breeds fell ponies at her Hampton Court stud and is known to take a keen interest in all her horses and ponies.

A dispute between two Brisbane neighbors over noise levels resulted in one man's death and another being charged with manslaughter. Leon Yeaman, 55, was allegedly killed by a single punch from Phillip Pama, 28, during a confrontation in front of their homes. Pama, a married father of three who works a 3 am shift, was reportedly asleep when Yeaman was making noise in his yard. Pama's defense lawyer stated that Yeaman was known for being loud and confrontational, and Pama acted out of self-defense. Yeaman was pronounced dead at the scene, and Pama was granted conditional bail.

A 52-year-old music teacher, Yulia Simonova, was filmed by an undercover police officer attempting to hire a hitman to torture and murder her 15-year-old ex-lover, Damian Vanya. Simonova offered 100,000 rubles (approximately £1,400) to have Vanya beaten, his arms and legs broken, and his kidneys damaged to cause him to bleed out. She was arrested after handing over some expense money and now faces 15 years in prison on charges of attempted murder. Vanya expressed relief over the arrest and hoped Simonova would remain in prison.

Chelsea Football Club's manager, Jose Mourinho, is a devoutly religious man who prays daily but never discusses football with God or his family. He and his family have worked with the World Food Programme to fight hunger. Despite his strong faith, Mourinho has been fined for claiming bias against his team. He strives to keep his professional and personal lives separate, emphasizing his role as a good family member and friend.

Bob Barker, the former host of "The Price is Right" for 35 years, returned to the show for the first time in eight years on April 1. Barker, 91, hosted the first game, "Lucky Seven," before handing over hosting duties to Drew Carey.

Secret Service agent Arthur Baldwin was arrested in Washington D.C. on Friday morning for allegedly attempting to break into a house at midnight. He was taken into custody by the metropolitan police and charged with felony attempted burglary and destruction of property. Baldwin's security clearance was revoked, and he was placed on leave following his arrest. The incident occurred on the 3200 block of D Street SE, where Baldwin was arrested by officers returning to the scene. Baldwin is a member of the Foreign Missions Branch, which works with the State Department on U.S. diplomatic activities. The arrest comes two days after a high-ranking supervisor was also placed on leave following allegations of misconduct.

Freelance photographer Atif Saeed, 38, from Lahore, Pakistan, captured an image of a hungry lion from just a few feet away in a city safari park. Saeed exited his car and crept to within 10 feet of the lion, lying on the ground to take a couple of frames before retreating to safety. The clicking sound of the camera's shutter alerted the lion, forcing Saeed to retreat rapidly. Saeed stated that he wanted to show the character and status of the lion and that the encounter finished in a few seconds as the lion aggressively jumped towards him. Although Saeed was laughing at the time, he now believes he would not be able to do it again.

A woman, believed to be between 25 and 45 years old, was found unconscious on a Brooklyn street on March 22 and was pronounced dead that evening. The New York City Police Department has released an image of a tattoo on her right leg, hoping to identify her. The tattoo is a heart with the name "Monique" etched across a ribbon, topped with a rose. Anyone with information is asked to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a solar-powered, two-bedroom home on the back of a 1986 Hino flatbed truck after returning from the UK. Unable to afford property, they constructed their cozy, wood and steel home over a year and a half. The home features a wood-fired stove, stained glass windows, and is nearly self-sufficient with solar power, gas-powered heating, and water from a nearby spring. The total cost was around $25,000.

Children who share iPads in class perform significantly better in early literacy tests than those who do not, according to research by Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern University. In her study, kindergarten students who shared iPads scored around 30 points higher than those who used the devices alone or in classes without iPads. Blackwell suggests that the collaborative learning around the technology, rather than just the collaboration itself, is what makes the difference. She recommends that schools reconsider how tablets are used, especially in earlier grades, to maximize their effectiveness.

A piglet born without hind legs in Sichuan province, China, has become an internet sensation for learning to walk on its front trotters. The piglet, nicknamed "super pig," balances on its front legs and forages for food, often nearly tipping over but always regaining its balance. The video of the piglet has captured the hearts of thousands.

A pit crew member, Todd Phillips, was injured when struck by a car during the IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana. The incident occurred when Francesco Dracone, who had come in for tires and fuel, spun while exiting his pit box and clipped Phillips' leg. Phillips was taken to the infield care center, received stitches for a cut on his leg, and was later released. Many cars struggled with traction during the race due to hours of rain before the start. Dracone did not finish the race and finished 23rd.

A husband, Milton Vieira Severiano, 32, was captured on CCTV footage brutally murdering his dancer wife, Cicera Alves de Sena, 29, in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. Severiano confessed to the crime, stating he was driven by jealousy over other men looking at his wife. The footage shows Severiano dragging his wife into the garden, smashing her head into concrete 11 times, punching her 10 times, and then shooting her five times in the face. Neighbors reported hearing a heated argument just days after the couple's marriage. Severiano attempted to flee but was apprehended by police after crashing a stolen car. He was found with multiple firearms and a bulletproof vest.

Journalist and author Sarah Wilson, 41, has revealed her personal battle with mental illness, including a close brush with suicide. Wilson attributes her struggles to mounting stress, anxiety, thyroid disease, and a sense of isolation due to not having a husband or children. She believes that depression and anxiety are intrinsically linked and that acknowledging this connection is crucial for addressing the rising rates of anxiety among Australian women. Wilson also noted that anxiety is becoming the "new depression," with one in three Australian women expected to experience it in their lifetime.

An Oregon woman, Elena Curtin, was charged with second-degree assault after beating her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar in November 2014. Curtin, who was seven months pregnant at the time, found her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend shooting heroin in her bathroom and asked her to leave, but the ex-girlfriend refused. Curtin was justified in her actions under Oregon law, which allows the use of physical force against an intruder who refuses to leave a resident's home. Curtin gave birth in January and was set to go to trial this week, but prosecutors dropped the charge on Monday because she was "completely justified in her outrage." Curtin's defense attorney, Casey Kovacic, stated that the ex-girlfriend was "jealous and bitter" that her boyfriend was in a relationship with Curtin and had harassed and threatened Curtin in the past. The ex-girlfriend and Curtin's boyfriend had a history of drug use and have a five-year-old child together. Curtin's boyfriend has not been involved in his new child's life. If Curtin had been convicted, she would have faced a mandatory prison sentence of

A pit bull named Gemma was filmed in California being fed treats, including a broccoli spear, which she immediately spat out in disgust. Her owner hopes that her human children do not follow her lead and learn to love their greens. Other videos show that Gemma enjoys sleeping and hanging out with her human family when she is not eating.

HSBC has apologized after a link on its official website directed visitors to a pornographic page. The issue arose because the URL address, which would usually connect to a third-party website, transferred visitors to a porn site instead. This happened after the registration for the young entrepreneur awards page was allowed to retire in 2011. HSBC has since removed the hyperlink from its main website and stated that it is not associated with the external site. The bank has apologized to the public for any inconvenience caused and assured that its website remains secure.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy, Marcus, called 911 when his family's home caught fire on Sunday morning. He and his 9-year-old sister, Aaliyah, were trapped in a second-floor bedroom due to the heat in the hallway. Marcus stayed calm during the 11-minute call, soothed his sister, and provided the dispatcher with directions to their location. Firefighters entered the room through the home, broke a window, and rescued Marcus and Aaliyah. The siblings were taken to a children's hospital with non-life-threatening injuries, while the other family members were taken to a different hospital after escaping on their own.

Blue fluorescent algae have illuminated Australia's east coast, with images taken in Jervis Bay, New South Wales. Photographer Andy Hutchinson described the sight as a "beautiful supernatural scene" caused by millions of plankton emitting light. A similar display occurred in Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014. Iain Suthers of the University of New South Wales explained that the algae, called noctiluca scintillans, blossoms in the spring and autumn and gives off a luminous glow as a defense mechanism.

Breast cancer patients may be spared chemotherapy thanks to new tests that pinpoint genetic markers in the tumor and determine its aggressiveness. After surgery, the cancer cells are sent to a lab where they are screened, and women can be told within days whether they have a high or low risk of the disease returning. For some women, the test can accurately tell if the risk is as low as five percent, which is as good as or better than the odds for those who have chemotherapy. The majority of women who have breast cancer are routinely given the grueling drug treatment following the removal of the tumor to prevent recurrence. Although the medication kills off cancer cells, the side effects, including complete hair loss, nausea, sickness, weight gain or loss, and extreme fatigue, can be difficult to live with. For some women, the prospect of chemotherapy is more daunting than the surgery itself. Experts have long believed that the risk of cancer recurrence for certain women is a lot less than for others, and that for some, chemotherapy may not be necessary. If the newest of the tests, called Endopredict, shows a low score, patients can opt not to have chemotherapy. Most of the tests are available only privately and cost about £2,500,

More than 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy, with at least one woman from HMS Illustrious, nicknamed "HMS Lusty" by the crew, among them. Eighteen other ships, including HMS Dragon, HMS Enterprise, and HMS Richmond, also had emergency evacuations. A strict "no touching" rule is in place at sea, suggesting the women conceived before boarding the ships or during leave. Women have been serving on Royal Navy ships since 1990, with around 9% of personnel being female in 2014. Nearly 100 female British soldiers were sent home from Afghanistan after discovering they were pregnant, with 99 servicewomen on operations flown back to the UK between January 2006 and December 2013.

A drone carrying traces of the radioactive material cesium was found on the rooftop of Japan's equivalent to the White House on Wednesday. The discovery came on the same day a Japanese court approved a government plan to restart two reactors at the Sendai nuclear power plant. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's push to restart the reactors is unpopular among many Japanese, who view nuclear energy as too dangerous. A staff member spotted the drone Wednesday morning on the roof of Abe's residence. Dozens of police investigators were dispatched to the roof to investigate the origin of the drone, which had four propellers and was 50 centimeters (20 inches) wide. Police say the drone was equipped with a small camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle containing small traces of a radioactive material believed to be cesium, a common byproduct of nuclear reactors. The amount inside is not immediately harmful to humans. Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga said the discovery is raising concerns about terrorism. "There might be terrorism attempts in the future at the Olympics and G7 summit using drones," Suga said. Japanese law restricts drone flights around airports to prevent problems with aircraft, but there are no flight restrictions for most of Tokyo, including

A security guard from China, Lu Xincai, takes his 84-year-old mother, who suffers from Alzheimer's, to work with him every day on the back of his motorbike. He ties a sash around both of their waists to ensure her safety. His mother used to get lost when left alone, so he decided to take her with him after his father passed away earlier this year. His wife works in a different city, and his son is still in school. Lu Xincai checks on his mother throughout the day to ensure her safety, as she has her own room at his workplace, a bank. He feels it is his duty to care for her, as she devoted her life to caring for him and his siblings.

The study, conducted by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington, found that heavy drinking among Americans increased by 17.2% between 2005 and 2012, with a significant rise in women's drinking habits. Binge drinking, defined as four or more drinks for women and five or more drinks for men on a single occasion, also increased, with women's rates rising more than seven times that of men nationwide. The study, which tracked adult drinking patterns at the county level, found that 8% of Americans were considered heavy drinkers and 18% were binge drinkers in 2012. The increase in drinking rates is attributed to changing social norms, increased affordability due to lower taxes, and increased alcohol advertising. Public health experts suggest that the rise in binge drinking is linked to changing social norms, with women trying to catch up to men in drinking habits.

The United Nations has warned that doctors are performing caesarean sections too readily, putting the health of women and their babies at risk. The procedure should only be carried out when medically necessary due to the risks of infections and even death. In England, just over a quarter of women now have a caesarean, a rate that has more than doubled since the early 1990s. The World Health Organization recommends that the rate should ideally be between 10% and 15% due to the dangers and costs involved. A planned caesarean costs the NHS an average of £2,369, compared to £1,665 for a natural birth. The WHO also said that doctors were carrying out the procedure too often and underestimating the risks.

A woman, Michelle Filkins, 44, of West Wareham, was arrested after allegedly breaking into a home on Martha's Vineyard, living there for at least a week, and selling items belonging to the owners in a yard sale. She was discovered by the owner, Mark Conklin, on April 17. Filkins was charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. She fled the scene in a gray Nissan pickup truck but was later arrested after attempting to re-enter the home. Filkins is scheduled to appear in court on May 14. The police are asking anyone who received items from the home to return them to the Edgartown Police Department.

A lost iPhone was returned to its owner, Bella Crooke, after police at Albury Police Station posted a series of humorous photos and messages on her Facebook page. The officers used the unlocked phone to post selfies and humorous updates, assuring Bella that her phone was safe and in good hands. Bella, who had lost her phone at a friend's birthday party, was eventually able to reclaim it without providing her name, as the officers recognized her from her Facebook page. The police's lighthearted approach was well-received by Bella and her friends, who praised the officers for their sense of humor and quick action in returning the phone.

A five-day-old hippopotamus was caught in a fight between two adult hippos in Isimangaliso Wetland Park, South Africa, and was thrown into the air. The calf was killed hours later, with its mother watching in horror. The mother had tried to protect her calf from other hippos, but the calf was grabbed by one of the adults during the fight. The mother attacked the hippo to get her calf back, but the calf was flicked into the air and died from its injuries.

Starbucks announced that a computer outage affecting registers at 8,000 stores in the US and Canada has been resolved. The outage, which began in the early evening on the east coast and late afternoon on the west coast, prompted baristas to give away free drinks. The company did not explain the cause of the outage, which affected 7,000 stores in the US and 1,000 in Canada. Starbucks released a statement saying the outage was caused by a failure during a daily system refresh and that they are actively working to resolve it.
